Two days before Valentine’s Day, Vera Swensen visited her son’s grave at St. Raymond Cemetery in the Bronx, as she had most days since he died in 2007 at age 28.
 
As she often does on special occasions, she left him some gifts: balloons that said “I Love You,” a box of chocolates and a tulip-shaped solar-powered light that glows at night.

Less than two weeks after Christie’s announced that it was increasing the fees it charges buyers, Sotheby’s followed suit. On Thursday afternoon, when the auction house reported its 2012 financial results, it announced that it would increase what is known as its buyer’s premium – or the fees it charges buyers — for the first time since 2008.
 
Both companies had been charging 25 percent for the first $50,000; 20 percent on the amount from $50,000 to $1 million and 12 percent of the rest. Now shoppers at Sotheby’s will be charged 25 percent on the first $100,000; 20 percent from $100,000 to $1.9 million and 12 percent of the rest. For more than 98 percent of lots sold this change will represent an increase of 2 percent or less, the company said, and no sales will see more than a 3.6 percent increase in the final purchase price.

After spending four years under the microscope as he led investigations of some of the world’s biggest banks, Lanny A. Breuer hasn’t lost his swagger.
 
The 54-year-old prosecutor, with a Rolodex as thick as his Queens dialect, will leave the Justice Department on Friday, emboldened after mounting recent cases against banking giants. But Mr. Breuer, the department’s criminal division chief, also leaves somewhat bruised, having taken criticism for not throwing Wall Street executives behind bars after the financial crisis.

NEU--John L. The Bard College community mourns the untimely passing of John L. Neu. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Wendy and are forever grateful to have known John as a friend, mentor, and employer. David E. Schwab II, Chair Emeritus Charles P. Stevenson, Jr., Chair Leon Botstein, President Max Kenner, Executive Director, Bard Prison Initiative Alumni/ae of the Bard Prison Initiative

LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland , hammered by losses, announced plans on Thursday to sell assets and pare back its investment banking business, in an effort to appease regulators and its biggest shareholder, the British government.
 
R.B.S. said it planned to sell a stake in the Citizens Financial Group, the American lender it bought in 1988, through an initial public offering in two years. The bank will also continue to reduce its investment banking operations, with plans to cut risky assets and eliminate jobs.

Goaltender Rick DiPietro, waived last week by the Islanders and sent to the American Hockey League, said in a television interview Thursday that he had battled depression and even had suicidal thoughts over his inability to live up to the 15-year $67.5 million contract he signed in 2006.
 
DiPietro, 31, who has yet to play for the Bridgeport Sound Tigers since being demoted Saturday, made the comments in an interview with News 12 Long Island . He later told ESPN.com that his words were not meant to be taken literally but were intended to credit the support of his wife, Cassie.

Andrew Mason, the irreverent programmer and musician who turned a failed social action site into the daily deals phenomenon Groupon , was dismissed Thursday as chief executive.
 
A day earlier, Groupon reported weak fourth- quarter earnings, which caused investors to shave off a quarter of the Chicago company’s value. The news about Mr. Mason, released after the market closed, sent shares up more than 4 percent in late trading.

An article on Thursday about Royal Dutch Shell’s decision to suspend drilling in the Arctic for this year described incorrectly the work of an Interior Department panel whose members include Lois N. Epstein of the Wilderness Society, who commented on Shell’s move. The panel, the Offshore Energy Safety Advisory Committee, advises the department on safety and environmental concerns raised by offshore drilling ; it is not charged specifically with reviewing Shell’s operations.

Alaska Airlines’ roots go back to the 1930s, long before Alaska’s statehood, and to this day many of its destinations are inaccessible by road. But over the last 20 years, the airline has expanded into Mexico, Hawaii and elsewhere in the United States.

YOUNG--George Warren, 82, died Sunday evening, February 17, 2013 in Lenox, MA. Born in NYC, November 8, 1930, the only son of Theodore J. and Janet Blossom Young, he was a graduate of Salisbury School in Connecticut and Princeton University, where he majored in History and Oriental Languages. Mr. Young was a Veteran of the Korean War and was honorably discharged from the US Army Reserves in 1960 with the rank of First Lieutenant. He built his career at J.P. Morgan starting in 1954 as a security and credit analyst with Morgan's Corporate Research Department. He retired as Vice President and Chairman of the Departmental Credit Committee in 1986. Mr. Young was a Trustee and, at various times, headed the Alumni Association at Salisbury School. He was active in Republican politics and served as President and Treasurer of the Coliseum Republican Club in NYC. Mr. Young was also a Vestryman of Christ and St. Stephen's Church and St. Ignatius Church, both in Manhattan, and a Treasurer of the U.S. Conference of World Council of Churches. Mr. Young supported a wide variety of cultural and charitable causes in NYC where he resided for much of his life. He was predeceased by his sister Jane Noel Lanier and is survived by her children, Ian, Jessica, and Ross Lanier, and his great-niece and nephew, Jorie and Ian C. Lanier. A Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at Trinity Church in Lenox, MA, Sunday, March 3rd at 2pm. A memorial service will be held on May 25th at 11am at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church in New York City. Donations in George's memory may be made to Episcopal Charities of New York or the Diabetes Action Research and Education Foundation.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the recent benchings of the Nets’ All-Star center, Brook Lopez, misstated his playing time in the fourth quarter of Friday’s loss to the Houston Rockets. He played the final six minutes; it is not the case that he “never left the bench” in the fourth quarter. (It was in a game against the Memphis Grizzlies on Sunday that he did not play in the fourth quarter.)

McKEE--James W. James W. McKee Jr. passed away February 27, 2013 in Naples, FL, after a brief illness. The son of James W. and Isabel McKee, he was born in Pittsburgh, August 19, 1922. Business relocation took the family to Montreal in 1934, where Jim graduated with distinction, first from Lower Canada College, and then from McGill University. During World War II he was a pilot who served initially as an instructor, before being assigned as a command pilot to the 9th Air Force in England and in France. In 1946 Jim joined Corn Products Refining Company (name changed to CPC International in 1969), a diversified food manufacturer of well known trademarks including Mazola, Hellmann's (mayonnaise), Thomas's (English Muffins), Skippy (peanut butter), and Knorr (soups and sauces), as well as the world's leading corn wet milling company. He spent his first 17 years with CPC on international assignments, primarily in Italy, Brazil and Cuba. In 1969, five years after relocating back to the United States he was appointed company president, followed by the appointment to CEO in 1972, the youngest CEO in the company's history. During his tenure as president and CEO, and until he retired in 1984, the company's sales quadrupled to exceed $4.3 billion and earnings growth compounded at just under 9% per year. In addition to CPC International, Jim served on a number of corporate boards of directors, including Marine Midland Bank, Melville Corporation, CVS, and Singer. He was president of the Conference Board; a member of the Council on Foreign Affairs; head of the Grocery Manufacturer's Association; and head of the American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in the early 1960's. He served as a trustee for several organizations, including St. Vincents Hospital, The College of New Rochelle, and the Committee for Economic Development, among others. The government of Brazil honored him twice with the country's highest civilian award, the Cruzeiro Do Sul medals for his contributions to Brazil's economy and to Brazilian/American relations. He also received honorary citations from the Geographic Society of Brazil, and the Union Cultural, among others for outstanding contributions. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from St. John's University for his academic and professional contributions in the field of economics, in particular, operating in inflationary environments. In retirement, Jim researched the McKee family genealogy, and self published the results in 2002: The Descendents of William and Mary Wilson McKee. Among his hobbies were his golf game (three holes-in-one), his computer, visiting hardware stores, reading books and newspapers, and managing investments. Jim is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Jayne (Finnegan); daughter Bettina McKee of Naples, FL; son James W. McKee III (wife, Pamela) of Charlotte, NC; daughter Sheila McKee of Boston, MA; two grandsons and two great-granddaughters. He was preceded in death by his brother, Robert McKee. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Monday, March 4, 2013 at 10am at St. William Catholic Church, 750 Seagate Drive, Naples. Interment will be in St. Mary's Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. Donations in Jim's memory may be made to NCH Healthcare System, P.O. Box 413029, Naples, FL 34101; www.NCHmd.org. Online condolences may be made at www.fullernaples.com
TITELBAUM--Caryle, died on February 26. Services will be held on March 1st at 1pm at Riverside, 180 W. 76th St.

UNDER PRESSURE Clients continued to withdraw money from the Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund, in the final quarter of 2012, raising the stakes for the new chief executive, Emmanuel Roman, below, in trying to win back investors.
 
Man Group’s funds had $2.7 billion of net outflows in the three months that ended Dec. 31, the sixth quarter of outflows in a row. Assets under management fell to $57 billion at the end of December, the company said in a statement on Thursday.

NEU--John L. We are deeply saddened by the sudden death of John L. Neu, our esteemed Chairman. A brilliant businessman, philanthropist, environmentalist, animal rights and community activist, politically engaged citizen and voracious reader with an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. John was associated with Hugo Neu Corporation for 50 years after graduating with honors from Harvard Law School. Initially working at the side of his beloved father, the late Hugo Neu, a pioneering visionary in the international metals recycling business, John assumed the leadership of the company in the early 1980's. Through hard work and determination, deliberative and wise decision making, excellent market judgment and dedication to initiating best practices in scrap metal operations, and with active assistance and encouragement from his dear wife and our CEO, Wendy Kelman Neu, John grew the business and brought Hugo Neu Corporation to an unparalleled position in the international metals recycling industry as one of its largest, most profitable and respected members. On a more personal note, we will remember John for his wisdom, gentleness, honesty, intellectual rigor, strength of character and frequent unstinting efforts and generosity on behalf of people less fortunate. Most recently, John and Wendy spent days serving meals on site to the victims of Superstorm Sandy and petitioning governmental leaders to take more rapid action. We extend our sincere condolences to Wendy, all of the members of John and Wendy's immediate and extended family, including his adored Luke, as well as his wide circle of friends. The Board of Directors, Officers and Employees of Hugo Neu Corporation

An article on Tuesday about a coming measles - rubella vaccination campaign in Rwanda misstated the source of the vaccine and some financing for the campaign. The vaccine and financing are being provided by the GAVI Alliance, not by the Measles and Rubella Initiative.

The Deal Professor column on Wednesday, about financial transaction taxes, referred incorrectly to the time period covered by a study by Anna Pomeranets and Daniel G. Weaver on New York State’s experience with such a tax. While the tax itself was in effect nearly eight decades, the study covered the period from 1932 to 1981; it did not span “eight decades.”

The Tribeca Film Festival will begin with a taste of Brooklyn and a nonfiction film on the Brooklyn (by way of Cincinnati) rock band the National , organizers for the festival said Thursday.
 
“Mistaken for Strangers,” a documentary that chronicles a tour by the National, the indie-rock quintet behind “High Violet” and other albums, will have its world premiere on the festival’s opening night, April 17, followed by a performance by the band.

An article on Thursday about a primary election in Massachusetts for the Senate seat relinquished by John Kerry misstated the timing of a decision by Representative Stephen F. Lynch, one of the Democratic contenders, to drop his opposition to same-sex marriage . He changed his position several years ago; he has not done so “since entering the race.” The article also overstated the degree to which Mr. Lynch has altered his positions since deciding to run. He has shifted on one — not “some” — issues. (He has softened his opposition to abortion, though he still calls himself “pro-life.”)

The acclaimed documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” about the genesis of the AIDS epidemic, could become a television miniseries. The Hollywood Reporter said Thursday that ABC Studios, a production company owned by the Disney/ABC Television Group, had bought the rights to the documentary so it could develop a dramatic miniseries about HIV-positive young men who, as the title implies, beat the medical odds.
 
 David France , who co-wrote and directed the documentary, said, “We’d like it to be an extended story that’s not just about AIDS and what AIDS wrought, but about this tremendous civil rights movement that grew from the ashes of AIDS and the dawn of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender movement.” He said that ABC Studios was a logical home for such a miniseries: “ABC is the network of ‘Roots.’”
In the rarefied world of haute couture jewelry, Taffin’s designer James de Givenchy offers a unique combination of elegance and edginess. It’s a mix he loves, and lives by.

CAREY--Dennis J.,95, of Greenport NY, formerly of Remsenburg and Sands Point, NY and North Palm Beach FL died on February 26th in Greenport. Born on January 5, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Denis and Margaret Collins Carey. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Clare and children Robert, Gregory (Diana), Geoffrey and Cynthia Lalone (Charles), eight grandchildren, brother Martin (Millicent) and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his son Denis (DJ) and brothers Edward, Hugh, John and George. A gifted athlete, Dennis was a graduate of St. Francis Prep, St. Johns University and St Johns Law School, where he edited The Law Review. A decorated Veteran and pilot (Bronze Star, Army Air Medal), he served with distinction in World War II and the Korean War. Dennis served for many years as president and CEO of Peerless Petrochemicals. Active in charities, he was a Knight of Malta and the Holy Sepulchre. Dennis loved language, literature, history and golf. The Carey's wish to express their gratitude to the staff of the Shores at Peconic Landing. Friends may visit Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Horton-Mathie Funeral Home in Greenport. Funeral Mass, Saturday March 2, 11am, St. Agnes Church, Greenport. Gifts in his memory may be made to St Agnes Church or East End Hospice.

Yes, the October storm felled about 300 trees in the Thain Family Forest at the New York Botanical Garden. But some of them have been reclaimed, and, in a simulation of a tropical rain forest, dressed in epiphytic orchids and other plants that live and grow on trees. They can be seen at the annual Orchid Show, this year designed by Francisca Coelho, below. The show opens on Saturday and runs through April 22. The garden is at Bronx River Parkway (Exit 7W) and Fordham Road, Bedford Park, the Bronx. More information: (718) 817-8700 or nybg.org .

7:15 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble , reporting a sharp drop in sales of its Nook tablets, said on Thursday that it would pull back on its ambitions for its device business, shrinking it in size while focusing more on digital content.
 
Calling Nook sales over the holiday period an “obvious disappointment,” the bookseller’s chief executive, William Lynch, said the company was taking “significant actions to right size investments” in its digital hardware division through steep cuts in advertising and the manufacturing of devices. Mr. Lynch made his remarks in a conference call with analysts shortly after Barnes & Noble reported a 26 percent decline in the fiscal third quarter for the Nook segment, which includes digital tablets and e-readers.

GRANITO--Frank H.,Jr. Frank H. Granito, Jr., of Stamford, CT died suddenly on February 27, 2013 at the age of 81. Affectionately known as Ditto, he was born August 8, 1931 in New York City to Dr. Frank and Nora Granito. Frank grew up happily in the Bronx and attended Cardinal Hayes High School (where he was elected to the Hall of Fame in 2004), the University of Chicago, Fairfield University and St. John's Law School. During the 1950's and 60's, Frank served as a Naval Aviator with the Pacific Fleet and with the Naval Reserve, flying a variety of fighter and attack aircraft. A renowned aviation law specialist, Frank spent the past 46 years with his firm, Speiser, Krause, Nolan & Granito and for the past 25 years practiced law with his son Frank. He was a mentor to many. As an active trial lawyer representing families of aviation disasters, Frank was involved in nearly every major aviation case of the past 50 years. Notably, among the cases Frank participated in were the following air disaster litigations: Mohawk Airlines, Rochester (1963); United Airlines, Parrotsville (1964); Canadian Pacific Airways, Tokyo (1966); Overseas National Airways, St. Croix (1970); TWA 707, Ionian Sea (1974); Eastern Airlines Flight 66, JFK (1975 ); Texasgulf Aviation (1981); Spantax DC-10, Spain (1982); LOT Polish Airlines, Warsaw (1987); Pan Am Flight 103 (1988); Avianca Flight 052 (1990); Action Air B-99, Bridgeport (1994); USAir DC-9, Charlotte (1994); USAF CT-43, Croatia (1996); TWA Flight 800 (1996); Swissair Flight 111 (1998); Egyptair Flight 990 (1999); AA Flight 587 (2001) and the litigation arising from the 9/11 tragedy. Frank was instrumental in continuing the fight of the Pan Am 103 families in holding Libya accountable for the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The historic settlement resulted in compensation for the Pan Am 103 families and the framework for renewed diplomatic relations between Libya and the United States. Frank and his colleagues who negotiated the settlement with Libya were awarded the 2009 Public Justice Trial Lawyer of the Year Award. Frank was an adjunct professor of aviation law at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University and a frequent lecturer at Fordham and St. John's Law Schools. He lectured and wrote extensively about aviation, choice of law and trial practice. His expertise was renown. When he wasn't at work, he was most times painting or attending to his memoirs, with a keen ability to recall events of many decades ago with mystifying detail. Extremely proud of his Bronx roots, Frank maintained lifelong friendships with his pals from Clason Point, Cardinal Hayes and St. John's. Equally proud of his service to our country, he held annual reunions with his squadron mates. And his cadre of warhorse aviation lawyers, the Sunshine Boys, held monthly "lunch meetings" to reminisce of days gone by. Frank was a devout Catholic and a person who quietly but generously supported those many causes near and dear to his heart. He was happiest when surrounded by his family, especially his wonderful grandchildren of whom he was so proud, and his beautiful bride whom he cherished so dearly. Frank is survived by his wife of 56 years, Helen Elizabeth "Betty" Altieri. He was the proud father of Catherine and Tim Langan, Frank III and Monica, Nora and Dan Harris and John and Luci. Frank was blessed with 16 grandchildren: Timmy, Matty, Mark and John Langan, Frank IV, Jimmy Joe, Jake, Catherine and Gunnar Granito, Cathleen, Will, Peter and Charlie Harris, John and Julia Granito. Frank was predeceased by his grandson Luke Langan. Brother of Nora (Cass) Chomicz, Gennaro (Maureen), Eileen (Andy) Simons, Sheila (Don) Dunphy. Predeceased by his sister Margaret Rose and brother John Teeple. Brother-in-law of Richard (Sharon) Altieri, Jimmy (Geri) Altieri and Johnny (Kathleen) Altieri, and loving uncle to many nieces and nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. Visiting hours will be held Sunday, March 3, 2013 from noon to 6pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT 06905. A funeral Mass will be held on Monday, March 4, 2013 at 11am at St. Leo Roman Catholic Church located at 24 Roxbury Rd., Stamford, CT 06902. A private interment will be held on Tuesday morning. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Betty and Frank Granito Scholarship Fund at Cardinal Hayes High School, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx 10451.

Steven Spielberg may have gone home empty-handed at the Academy Awards on Sunday night, but on Thursday he was bestowed another prestigious cinematic honor (besides the fact that, you know, he gets to be Steven Spielberg every day of his life): He will serve as president of the jury at the Cannes Film Festival in May, its organizers said . 
 
Mr. Spielberg, an Oscar winner for “Schindler’s List” and “Saving Private Ryan” and most recently a nominee for “Lincoln,” has shown his motion pictures at Cannes, including “The Sugarland Express,” which won the festival’s best screenplay award in 1974; his blockbuster “E.T. the Extra Terrestrial” had its world premiere there as the festival’s closing film in 1982. “Ever since,” Gilles Jacob, the president of the Cannes festival, said in a statement, “I’ve often asked Steven to be jury president, but he’s always been shooting a film. So when this year I was told ‘E.T., phone home,’ I understood and immediately replied: ‘At last!’”
An Op-Ed essay on Thursday about Benedict XVI’s legacy misstated the last time a pope resigned. It was nearly 600 years ago, not nearly 700.

The Tony Award-winning actress Idina Menzel will return to Broadway next spring for the first time since “Wicked” to star in a new musical, “If/Then,” about a woman who moves to New York seeking a fresh start as she prepares to turn 40, the show’s producer, David Stone, announced on Thursday.
 
“If/Then” will also be the first Broadway production by the composer Tom Kitt and the lyricist and book writer Brian Yorkey since their critically acclaimed 2009 musical, “Next to Normal,” which won three Tonys – including one for best score – as well as the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

A report in the National Briefing column on Thursday about a vote by the Arkansas House to override Gov. Mike Beebe’s veto of an abortion bill misstated the point in a pregnancy at which a fetus can feel pain, according to some opponents of abortion. It is the 20th week — not, of course, the 20th month. (The bill calls for outlawing most abortions starting in the 20th week.)

Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers will play five nights at the Beacon Theater in May, a rare string of shows at a 2,900-seat hall for a veteran rock group that can easily fill arenas, the group announced on Thursday. 
 
Live Nation, the concert promoter, said it would be the first time Mr. Petty and his group play the Beacon in the band’s 35-year career, though that statement could not immediately be confirmed. The band will appear at the Beacon on May 20, 21, 23, 25 and 26; tickets go on sale March 25.

Dozens of readers wrote to us with their company’s parental leave polices after reading the  Your Money column , which discussed how American public and private organizations offer the least generous paid leave policies in the world.
 
Some readers were stunned that even the largest companies offered so little paid time off, especially during a newborn’s critical early months when nursing can benefit both mother and child. Several Canadian readers, whose a country has a more liberal policy, chimed in with their thoughts and went as far as calling the American way barbaric. Other readers agonized about how to make sure their infants will be cared for when they return to work, while others viewed child care as the individual parent’s problem.

Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, “ The Behavior Gap ,” was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog. 

 
A recent New York Times article highlighted the sad trend of investors getting fleeced after putting their money in exotic, alternative investments they hoped would help them recover from past investing losses.

Two Brooklyn public media organizations are among 13 winners of a 2013 MacArthur Award for Creative and Effective Institutions, being announced Thursday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. 
 
 StoryCorps , which records and collects oral histories, and its occasional collaborator American Documentary , which produces the PBS series “POV,” will receive $1 million each. Dave Isay, StoryCorps’ founder and a 2000 MacArthur Genius Grant winner, said in a telephone interview that in addition to bolstering reserves, the money would go toward making StoryCorps’ digital archive of more than 45,000 (and growing) stories publicly available. StoryCorps owns the stories’ rights, but “we have to be very, very careful,” Mr. Isay said, citing concerns about privacy and identity theft.

Susan Boyle, the Scottish singer with the big voice who enjoyed a period of international fame in 2009 after appearing on a British talent show, has landed a part in a Christmas movie, Reuters reported .
 
Ms. Boyle, 51, will appear in “The Christmas Candle,” a film based on the novella by Max Lucado about a magic candle that changes life for people at the turn of the 20th century in a dull village with a skeptical minister. The producers did not say what part Ms. Boyle would play, or whether she would sing. Samantha Barks, Hans Matheson and Lesley Manville also appear in the film, which began production this week on the Isle of Man.
Gyorgy Matolcsy, who has spearheaded Hungary’s unorthodox financial policies as economics minister, was appointed as the country’s central bank chief on Friday.

HADDAD--Dr. Jamil R.,of New York, NY died peacefully at home on February 24, 2013, of heart failure at the age of 89 years. Dr. Haddad was retired Director, Dept. of Pathology & Clinical Laboratory at the General Hospital Center at Passaic, NJ. Previously, he held a similar position at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center, NYC. He had also held positions at Bellevue Hospital, NYU School of Medicine, the Sloan-Kettering Center for Cancer Research and the Dept. of Cell Biology of Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was born in Mosul, Iraq on August 18, 1923. Dr. Haddad, beloved husband of the late Mary Lou Haddad (nee Scorsone) and beloved father of the late Ralph J. Haddad, is survived by his sons James of NYC, and John of Houston, TX; seven grandchildren; four brothers: Edward of Albuquerque, NM; Antoine of Baghdad, Iraq; Naji of Speyer, Germany; and Jawdat of Houston, TX; and his sister Bassima Haddad-Rammo of Richmond Hill, Canada. Visitation on Sunday, March 3, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC, Funeral Mass Monday, March 4, 10:00am at The R.C. Church of the Epiphany, 239 E 21st Street, NYC with interment at St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NYC. The family appreciates any donation in memory of Dr. Jamil R. Haddad, in particular, to the Catholic Near East Welfare Association (www.CNEWA.org) or The American Cancer Society.

Kenneth Branagh will return to the stage to do Shakespeare for the first time in more than a decade at this year’s Manchester International Festival, playing the title role in “Macbeth” at a deconsecrated church.
 
That production, to be directed by Mr. Branagh and Rob Ashford, is one of several highlights of the July festival, which specializes in staging new work and one-off events across the disciplines of theater, music and the visual arts.

Peter Jackson has pushed back the release date for the third installment of his Hobbit trilogy, “The Hobbit: There and Back Again,” for five months to December 2014, Warner Brothers announced. The news of the delay came as the first film in the series, “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” neared the $1 billion mark in worldwide box-office sales, thanks in part to strong demand in China. 
 
The second installment, “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug,” remains on schedule to open this December. No reason was given for the delay, but Warner Brothers, the distributor, portrayed it as good news. “We’re excited to complete the trilogy the same way we started it, as a holiday treat for moviegoers everywhere,” Dan Fellman, president of domestic distribution for Warner Brothers, said.

KENT--Lillian J. Lillian passed away peacefully in her sleep at her home in Manhattan's Upper East Side on February 11th. She was 96 years old. Lillian was born on May 27, 1916 in Brooklyn to Ellis Jaffe and Anna Blumberg. Extraordinarily bright, determined and ahead of her time, Lillian earned her Bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College in 1936 and her Master's Degree from the University of Michigan in 1937. She worked in advertising sales for many years before founding her own highly regarded advertising agency at a time when it was extremely unusual for a woman to do so. She went on to serve as the president of Advertising Women of New York. She married Jack Kent in 1951, who treasured her until his death in 1973. Along with the deep love of her family, Lillian earned the unwavering friendship, respect and admiration of a multitude of people. She enjoyed life to the fullest and loved to take in all that New York had to offer particularly the ballet, theatre, museums, and restaurants. While she traveled extensively, she believed that there is no better place in the world than New York City. Lillian was well known for her generosity, volunteerism and deep desire and sense of responsibility to help others in need. She feared nobody and was known to speak her mind with honesty and passion. She followed current events closely, reading The New York Times from cover-to-cover each day. She had a remarkable ability to relate to younger generations, and despite the difference in age, her nieces and nephews (and great-nieces and great- nephews) routinely looked to her for guidance and friendship in all aspects of life. She is preceded in death by her husband, her parents, her brothers Harold and Herman Jaffe, whom she adored and who adored her, her sister-in-law Trude Jaffe, and her aunt, Tilly Strysower, who was like a mother to her. She is survived by her youngest brother Daniel Jaffe and his wife Lori, her cousin Joan Levitt, niece Susan Jaffe, nephew David Jaffe and his wife Maureen, nephews Brian Jaffe and Edward Jaffe and Edward's wife Sandy, great nephews Andrew Jaffe and Michael Jaffe, and great nieces Hilary Jaffe and Sarah Jaffe. Her family will greatly miss their mentor and friend. She will forever be in their hearts. A celebration of Lillian's life will be held at a future date to be announced. Contributions in Lillian's memory may be sent to Save the Children Foundation, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, CT 06881.

Over the last half-century, Warren E. Buffett has built a reputation as a contrarian investor, betting against the crowd to amass a fortune estimated at $54 billion.
 
Mr. Buffett underscored that contrarian instinct in his annual letter to shareholders published on Friday. In a year when Mr. Buffett did not make any large acquisitions, he bought dozens of newspapers, a business others have shunned. His company, Berkshire Hathaway , has bought 28 dailies in the last 15 months.

An article on Feb. 19 about the debate over a $2.6 billion effort to build two bridges linking Kentucky and southern Indiana misstated the reason that the River Fields conservancy group opposed the construction of one of the bridges. It is because of concerns about overdevelopment and environmental impact, not “because it would affect historic homes in Jeffersonville, Ind.” The article also misidentified a bridge that could potentially affect those homes in Jeffersonville. It is the so-called East End bridge, not the Downtown bridge.

The National Book Critics Circle handed out its annual awards on Thursday night at the New School’s Tishman Auditorium, with an old hand among the winners.
 
Robert A. Caro won in the biography category for the fourth volume in his epic life of Lyndon B. Johnson, “The Passage of Power.” The first two books in Mr. Caro’s series also won the Book Critics Circle award, and the third volume was a finalist. Michiko Kakutani wrote that in his latest book, Mr. Caro uses “the intimate knowledge of Johnson he’s acquired over 36 years to tell [the] story with consummate artistry and ardor.”

An article on Thursday about the fear of political gridlock in Italy after Beppe Grillo, leader of the party that holds the third-largest bloc in Parliament, ruled out joining a government alliance, referred incorrectly to President Giorgio Napolitano’s role in resolving the paralysis. Should a government fail to be formed, new elections can be called only by Mr. Napolitano’s successor, who is to be elected by Parliament in May; Mr. Napolitano would not call the elections.

People use payday loans to avoid borrowing from family and friends, and to avoid cutting back further on expenses. But they often end up doing those things anyway to pay back the loan, a new report finds.
 
The average payday loan — a short-term, high-interest-rate loan typically secured by a borrower’s future paycheck — requires a repayment of more than $400 in two weeks, according to a new report from an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts. But the average borrower can only afford a $50 payment, which means that borrowers end up rolling over the loan and adding to their debt. The Pew report found that borrowers typically experience prolonged periods of debt, paying more than $500 in fees over five months.

Thai Taste in Massapequa Park fires the imagination with dishes like crying tiger (marinated sirloin) and drunken sea (seafood in a chili-fueled sauce) served among hanging fabric and carved wood.

Roman Roth’s 2010 Virgin Berry Riesling is smooth, balanced, concentrated and zippy, and it has a low alcohol content.

The Hybrid Air, which combines hydraulic drive with a conventional gasoline engine, is an experimental vehicle that PSA Peugeot Citroën says is an exemplar of energy efficiency.

Debut albums by Thiefs, Shamie Royston and Curtis Hasselbring stretch across the jazz spectrum. And a new release by singer-songwriter Terry Allen is a return of a master lyricist.

The not-all-new 2013 Honda Civic is a sharper, better-focused, user-friendlier version of the Civic, even though it’s fundamentally the same car.
With the budget impasse, perhaps President Obama could learn a few lessons in enacting transformative legislation from the nation’s first scholar-president.

You don’t need to be a filmmaker to create high-quality travel videos. Daniel Klein, who co-produces an online video series, offers tips on everything from gear to technique.
Richard Hell, the proto-punk rocker and writer, has kept a handmade book for 40-some years, since it was created and given to him by its author.
We gave a few travel agents an assignment: come up with three weeklong vacations for a family of four. The result is nine trips, from thrifty Florida to in-your-dreams French Alps.
As the resort celebrates a milestone anniversary, see how skiing there has evolved.
From a Wi-Fi-equipped gondola to smart lift tickets, the Vail experience has been transformed. A veteran skier returns to the resort to see if new also means improved.

Jane Campion’s TV mini-series “Top of the Lake,” the first TV show to be screened at Sundance, was well-received — not surprising, given how TV watching is changing.
A 10-hour mini-series, “The Bible,” begins on Sunday on History and will rerun on Monday nights on Lifetime.
The debut album of the brothers Raul and Mexia Hernández, sons of the bassist for Los Tigres del Norte, is definitely not Los Tigres 2.0.

The Draft column last Sunday, about crime fiction, misattributed a line from a John Wayne film (“The Searchers,” 1956). It was Ward Bond’s character (the Rev. Capt. Samuel Johnston Clayton) who said that some people “needed killing,” not Wayne’s character (Ethan Edwards).

HOLLAND--Muriel, 94, left us on February 25. Cherished wife of Morton (deceased); adoring mother of Beth Holland Queener and Chuck; passionate "Dee" of Jonathan and Pam Stein and Sara and Mark Richman, and doting great- grandmother of Jacob, Eliot, Abigail, Lindsay and Jessica. Truly a lady, her spirit and strength were inspirational.

LEBER--Marion, born on March 5, 1943, devoted wife of Steve Leber; beloved mother of Michelle Roberts, Jill Weiss and Jordan Leber; supportive mother-in-law of Michael Roberts, Mark Weiss and Lainie Leber; adoring grandmother (Meme) of Matthew, Jack, Dani, Rachel, Jared, Sabrina and Jake; and beloved daughter to the late Julia and Rudy Griffenhagen. After a long courageous battle with cancer she passed away peacefully surrounded by the ones she laughed with, lived for, and loved on March 1, 2013. Marion, a person of exceptional talent in all that she did, whose exquisite taste and beauty was a hallmark of her remarkable life will be forever cherished in our hearts. Services to be held at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation at 11 o'clock on Sunday, March 3 at 21 Old Westbury Way, Old Westbury, New York.

Mashayekhi--Mohammad, of Washington, DC and Tehran, Iran, eminent Iranian scholar, writer, educator, and university president, born in 1913, died on February 14, 2013, after a short illness. He is survived by his wife of more than 70 years, Ashraf Habibi; his three daughters, Afsaneh Mashayekhi Beschloss and Maryam Mashayekhi of Washington, DC and Mina Mashayekhi of Geneva, Switzerland; two sons-in-law, Michael Beschloss and Maarten Smeets; and three grandchildren, Anahita Smeets, Alexander and Cyrus Beschloss. Dr. Mashayekhi was laid to rest after a private family ceremony in Oak Hill Cemetery in Georgetown on February 18, 2013.

NEU--John L. The Board and Staff of NRDC mourn the loss of our dear friend and trusted advisor, John Neu, husband of our devoted and beloved trustee, Wendy Kelman Neu. John was deeply committed to helping the most vulnerable, from the wild creatures of the world to communities most in need. His passion, intellect and generosity were felt throughout our organization, and his personal devotion to the NRDC staff was exceptional. We send our deepest sympathy to Wendy, to John and Wendy's extended family, to his colleagues at Hugo Neu and beyond. Daniel R. Tishman, Chairman Frances G. Beinecke, President Peter Lehner, Executive Director John H. Adams, Founding Director

STREIMER--Ann (nee Ackerman), February 28, 2013, of New York City. Mother of Jane (David) Schultz and Gary (Marie) Streimer, sister of Didi (Alan) Marks and grandmother of Samantha, Max, Sydney and Sophie.
BARLAM--Barnett. 7/8/1922-3/3/2011. Thinking of you every day with love. Melissa, Jeff, Jim, Dana

Inexhaustible homesteading, subdividing, parceling and merchandising of neighborhoods is the lifeblood of New York. And as we all know, it’s historically artists who first sniff out where the next great acronym will sprout.
 
With every last square foot of southern Manhattan long since optimized and Williamsburg and Bushwick well established as on the beaten track, could the next up-and-coming arts ward be … the Donut District? Located in Brooklyn on the corner of Huntington and Clinton Streets, practically underneath the stretch of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway that separates industrial Red Hook from greater Carroll Gardens, the three artist-run spaces here named their micro-neighborhood after its commercial center: the off-ramp Dunkin Donuts across the street.

Whole Journeys , the new travel company affiliated with the Whole Foods Market chain, is setting off on its inaugural tour next month in search of authentic Turkey — the country, not the poultry. The eight-night, $4,395-a-person exploration from the Aegean Coast and the historic area around ancient Ephesus to the lunar landscape of Cappadocia, above, coincides with Festival of the Wild Greens in Alacati, where locals compete to see who can harvest the most herbs, which are then used in regional dishes. The tour is the first of 19 by the travel outfitter to a dozen destinations; prices, $2,800 to $4,500 a person, include guides, visits, hotels and most meals.

JENIK--Thomas M.,67, of Manhattan and Medusa, New York died peacefully at home on March 2, 2013 surrounded by his loving family after battling leukemia. He was an avid art lover, lifetime runner, enthusiastic reader of history and all things New York City. Graduate of All Hallows High School and Saint John's University, he worked for the New York City Department of Probation and then the New York State Division of Parole. After retiring in 2006, he worked for the Stuyvesant Town Recreation Department until last June. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Jane Holland and his two children, Alexandra Jenik and William Jenik. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., NYC Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 11am at Immaculate Conception Church 414 E. 14th St., NYC. Contributions in his memory can be made to All Hallows High School in the Bronx.

ROSENTHAL--Molly, originally of Brooklyn, NY, beloved widow of Samuel, mother of Susan, Maxine and Edward, grandmother of Kevin, Cheryl, Robert, Jeffrey, Jason and Matthew, and great-grandmother of Jacob, Adam, Hannah, Zachary and Dylan, passed away peacefully at the age of 96 on February 22, 2013. She was the matriarch of her family, warm, caring, loving with an ever-positive outlook and love for life. She will be dearly missed, always loved and remembered.

SAYRE--F. Stuart F. Stuart Sayre, age 85, of Delray Beach, FL and formerly of Winnetka, IL and Rumson, NJ, passed away on February 26, 2013. Stuart grew up in Essex Fells, NJ, the son of Austin Bartholomew and Anne Rives Sayre. He graduated from Episcopal High School of Alexandria, VA, Dartmouth College and the Tuck School of Business. For many years a management consultant, he joined the family business, American Abrasive Metals Co., in the late 1960's. Stuart was a longtime member of Rumson Country Club, Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, Seabright Beach Club, Eastward Ho!, and the St. Andrews Club in Delray Beach. He served as Warden of St. George's by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson. Stuart was an avid golfer, bridge and tennis player, a fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Giants, a lover of Cape Cod, cheap chardonnay and expensive Scotch, and a connoisseur of big band music. Husband of the late Nancy Bond Sayre, Stuart is survived by his children, Stephen B., S. Carter, and Anne E. Sayre; his grandchildren, Abigail, Gordon, William and Lucas Sayre, and his brother Austin Sayre, Jr. In recent years, he found great happiness in his loving relationship with Ann (Boo) Sutton, with whom he lived in Florida. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 8, 2013, 11am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 188 S. Swinton Ave., Delray Beach, FL and in Rumson, NJ at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the St. George's by-the-River Memorial Fund, 7 Lincoln Ave., Rumson, NJ 07760. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach in charge of services.

SEASHORE--Edith Whitfield, 84, died on February 23, 2013, in the hours following the memorial service for her late husband, Charles N. Seashore, with her daughters by her side. She was the first child of Nathan and Florence Whitfield of Montclair, NJ and was born on March 8, 1928, fittingly on International Women's Day as she would become a pioneer in a male-dominated field and an agent of change with regard to women's rights. She earned a BA in Sociology from Antioch College, where she was Community Manager and worked with Douglas McGregor. She earned an MA in Social-Psychology from Columbia University. In 1950, Edie went to Bethel, Maine to learn from and work with National Training Laboratories (NTL) in Applied Behavioral Science. She met Charlie Seashore there when he was a participant in a group she was training. They became collaborators and married, celebrating 52 years together before Charles's death in January. While at NTL, Edie became increasing connected to the field of group dynamics. She became first female president of NTL at a critical time in the organization. She was a consultant in organization development (OD) with clients including Bell Telephone Systems, Walter Reed Hospital, the Defense Mapping Agency, and the U.S. Naval Academy. She co-founded the Lewin Institute for Social Change, Action and Research and was the board co-chair for many years. With the late Morley Segal, she co-founded the American University/NTL Masters Program in OD. She taught at numerous other universities including Johns Hopkins, University of Massachusetts, Pepperdine, and Concordia and in many countries. In 2001, she was recognized by the OD Network with a Lifetime Achievement Award. Edie was a true optimist and could weave a great story out of any situation. Recently she wrote a six-word memoir of her life: "Marriage, Family, Career had it all!" She not only saw the good in others, she brought it out. Edie is survived by her daughters Becky and Kim and her sons-in-law C.J. and Jeff, her brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Diane, siblings-in-law Marjorie and Dick Seashore, and grandchildren Benjamin, Natalie, Nathan, Nick, and Ella. She is lovingly remembered and missed by her family, and her many colleagues, students and friends around the world. Donations in Edie's memory can be made to Seashore Memorial Fund at NTL Institute for Applied Behavioral Science (www.ntl.org) at Antioch College (https://donate. antiochcollege.org/). Memorial services will be held March 9, at the Sheraton Columbia Town Center in Columbia, MD and on July 21 in Bethel, ME.
UNGAR--Evelyn, (Shapiro). One year without my beloved mother. Your rich spirit infuses my saddened world. With love & cherishment always, Diane.

An article on Feb. 17 about a decline in field trips for students because of the New York City school bus drivers’ strike referred incorrectly to the 280-pound albino Burmese python at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum. The python, a favorite of schoolchildren, is a “she” (Fantasia), not a “he.”

After work, people who are finally untethered from the desktops they’ve been using all day creep back online for a second shift using tablets, a trend borne out by usage figures that comScore released in a report this month. And once on their iPads, people buy items at rates higher than they do on smartphones.
 
Travel booking sites have taken notice. The latest is Orbitz, which recently released an iPad app , above, that is more than a smartphone app that is magnified. It takes advantage of a tablet’s larger screen size to display the search bar and various filters you’ve chosen, the list of search results and maps or photos of the selected items all at the same time. The app comes after similar ones from Kayak and Travelocity.

Right on Red A standout theme at the recent New York fashion shows, black and white, leaves the jelly-bean colors to youngsters. But don’t forget red and black, which was popular in the late 1930s and early ’40s, and is enjoying a slight revival.

GROSS--Norman J. Gross 1940-2013. Norman J. Gross was born on December 2, 1940, in Far Rockaway, New York. After attending local schools, he received a B.A. degree from Miami University of Ohio followed by a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. As a young man in New York, Norm started his career as a lawyer. Seeking more of a challenge, he embarked on the first of many diversified interests. Norm was founder, builder, and co-owner of the nationally renowned Wall Street Racquet Club. The distinctive tennis bubbles on the eastside piers were featured for many years in movies and New York City postcards. In the early 80's Norm started Diamond Portfolio, Ltd., the selling-arm of a major DeBeers sight buyer. Norm's firm was rated "Best" three years consecutively in an independent survey of 142 gem companies. In the mid 90's Norm accepted a special project in Boise, Idaho. Upon completion of this business, Norm realized Boise was where he wanted to settle. Never idle, Norm formed the Sleepy Hollow Construction Company and designed and built two houses. Norm enjoyed travel, hunting and deep sea fishing in Mexico during the winter. In Norm's last years he devoted all of his time and efforts to the Idaho Humane Society. The years spent in Boise were his "most content and happiest." Norm embraced life fully and with great enthusiasm. Norm will be remembered by many in New York and Boise. If anyone wishes to make a contribution in Norm's memory, please donate to the Easy Fund of the Idaho Humane Society, 4775 West Dorman Street, Boise, ID 83705. Norm is survived by a son, daughter, and grandchildren. At Norm's request, no services will be held.
MCINTOSH--Ann L.,February 26, 2013, age 73 of Monkton, MD. Memorial Service information may be found at www.evansfuneralchapel.com

ROSS--Mary Riepma Cowell. Mary Riepma Cowell Ross, a retired lawyer and past President of the New York Women's Bar Association, died at age 102 on February 2, 2013 at her apartment in the Pierre Hotel in New York. The cause was old age; by her own account, she was "a tough old bird" from a long-lived family. Mrs. Ross was one of the early generation of women lawyers who gained a toehold in major law firms because of staff shortages in World War II. She was also active in arts and educational philanthropy. Born in Oklahoma City in 1910, Mrs. Ross attended the University of Nebraska - Lincoln (where she pledged Delta Gamma) and graduated from Vassar in 1932 and received her law degree from Memphis State University. In the early 1940's she worked for the United States government in Washington, chiefly in the Office of Alien Property. She moved to New York in 1946 to work for what is now Rogers & Wells, where she became an expert in wills, trusts and estates. "I never would have gotten with them if it hadn't been for the war. Of course the head of my department told me, right at the start, they'd never make me a partner because I was a woman" she said in 1993. Mrs. Ross served on various committees of the American Bar Association, Bar Association of the City of New York and the New York Women's Bar Association, including its Committee for Equal Opportunities for Women in the 1940's. She served as President of the womens' group in 1955-1957. She left Rogers & Wells in 1961 to begin private practice, and also became active in philanthropic work, serving on the Board of the Merce Cunningham Dance Foundation, the Central Park Community Fund, the University of Nebraska Foundation, and other organizations. In the 1970's and 1980's she competed in amateur ballroom dance events and in 1989 she established the Mary Riepma Ross Film Theatre at the University of Nebraska. She is predeceased by her brother, Siert F. Riepma, and sisters Freda Riepma, Lt. Col. Marjorie L. Riepma and Anna Marie Riepma Gray. She is survived by one nephew and three nieces and their children, including her fellow Delta Gamma, Olivia Gray, with whom she often exchanged the secret handshake. Her first marriage ended in divorce; her second husband, John Ogg Ross, died in 1966. In the last years of her life, she was attended with great care and tenderness by her long time housekeeper, Sigrid Dias, and Joan Kiernan with her crew of nurses, including Patricia Campbell, Teresa Cassels, Teresa Hanlon, Katherine McSweeney and Marie O'Connor.
STROLY--Henry W. "Buddy", age 81, son of the late Rose and Sidney Stroly. Loved by family and friends. He will be truly missed by many.

The story of how Danny and I were married last July in a Manhattan courtroom, with our son, Kevin, beside us, began 12 years earlier, in a dark, damp subway station.
 
Danny called me that day, frantic, from the exit of the A/C/E. “I found a baby!” he shouted. “I called 911, but I don’t think they believed me.” Danny is a remarkably calm person, so when I felt his heart pounding through the phone, I ran.

This time around all of those razor teeth will really pop. To celebrate the 20th anniversary of “Jurassic Park,” directed by Steven Spielberg and based on the Michael Crichton novel, the film is being released in 3-D on April 5. This hyper-adrenalized hymn to human beings not quite knowing their place in the grand scheme of things stars Sam Neill, Laura Dern, Jeff Goldblum, Samuel L. Jackson and Richard Attenborough — and all of those wonderful dinosaurs, great and small, kind and not so kind. Hey, a carnivore just can’t help but put forth a toothy grin when the hors d’oeuvres come a-knocking of their own volition.

In classical opera, characters tend to get around in swan boats or chariots, but a production of “ Rigoletto ” at New York’s Metropolitan Opera puts a 1960 Cadillac Coupe de Ville in the spotlight. A soprano who has been fatally stabbed is briefly stuffed in its trunk, and the final duet, with the soprano dying in her father’s arms, takes place at the car’s rear, framed by fins and tail lights.
 
Traditionally, that scene is set on a riverbank in Renaissance Italy, bu the Met’s new production of the Verdi opera, directed by Michael Mayer, transports the action to 1960 Las Vegas. The Cadillac is the real thing, bought on eBay, then painted indigo blue with metallic flecks by the Met staff and illuminated by the lighting designer, Kevin Adams, to reach the high C of automotive fantasy.

ARMSTRONG--Raymond, was a shining star that came into our world. He was one of the kindest, sweetest, most gentle and generous souls a true gentleman. We feel blessed to have shared his goodness and will be forever grateful for the joy that he brought into our lives. He will be missed by his loving partner of ten years, Regina Brauer, and her children, Lisa, Amy and Henry Brauer and their families.

BORCK--Alan. The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and esteemed member of over 30 years, Alan Borck. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Virginia and his entire family in their time of sorrow. Marc Friedman, President

KROHN--Lewis Miles, Investment Banker at Lehman Bros, Ira Haupt and Wertheim & Co; Harvard '44 and Harvard Business School '46. His personal clients ranged from Bill Levitt (Levittown) to Charles Bluhdorm (Gulf & Western). Died today February 28, 2013 at the age of 90 at his son and daughter-in-law's Rhode Island residence under hospice care. Lewis was born and raised in Utica, NY in 1922 to Ralph and Rose Krohn. He was married to the late Shirley Rich for 58 years and is survived by his two children Lisa and Steven Krohn and daughter-in-law Samantha Scott Krohn. He served as a Captain in the U.S. Army (Field Artillery). Lewis was a devoted and active alumnus of Harvard. He was the Harvard campaign Class (1944) Chairman 1981-1984 and 1988. He served as President of Temple Beth Ami Synagogue in Scarsdale and Temple Beth Am Shalom in White Plains, as well as Vice Chairman LHP Local Housing Partnership Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield. During the past 15 years he was a devoted and beloved citizen of the Osborn in Rye, NY.

If you have teenage children and have been considering sending them to an expensive private school, you can save a lot of money by watching “Restless Virgins,” a made-for-television movie Saturday on Lifetime that was inspired by real events. This unpleasant tale might lead you not only to home-school the youngsters but also never to let them out of the house again.
 
The story, based on the nonfiction book “Restless Virgins: Love, Sex and Survival in Prep School” by Abigail Jones and Marissa Miley, is set at the fictional Sutton Academy and centers on a scandal precipitated by a student sex tape. The circumstances have been altered considerably, but the story is inspired by a 2005 incident at Milton Academy in Massachusetts that involved members of the boys’ hockey team and led to expulsions.

THESE are hard times for trying to promote, much less make, peace between Palestinians and Israelis. The rise of political Islam, Syria’s civil war and looming implosion, and the Iranian nuclear imbroglio not only dominate the environment, but they also render it forbidding for peacemaking. And while all these factors make Israelis and Palestinians reluctant to take risks for peace, they do not represent the biggest hurdle for ending the conflict. The most fundamental problem between Israelis and Palestinians is the problem of disbelief.
 
Most Israelis and Palestinians today simply don’t believe that peace is possible. I won’t rehearse all the reasons both sides have lost faith. Suffice it to say that Israelis feel that their withdrawal from territory (like southern Lebanon and the Gaza Strip) has not brought peace or security; instead, it has produced only violence. Why, then, should they repeat the same mistake and subject themselves to far greater, even existential, risk in the West Bank? Meanwhile, Palestinians believe that negotiations from 1993 onward failed to produce independence but instead yielded a huge Israeli settler presence in their midst.

In response to Stephanie Rosenbloom’s Getaway column one week ago, which explored how to find peace and quiet on an airplane, we asked our Twitter followers for their tips on staying calm and collected in transit. Some of their responses are below.

For the second time in 14 months, the N.H.L. has drawn up a plan to realign its clubs and devise a new playoff format. It is quite possible that, for a second time, questions raised by the Players’ Association will prevent its implementation.
 
The league had hoped a new realignment and playoff format would be a fait acompli by now.

ABRAMS--Helen Pearl Rosenfeld, 100, of Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully at home on February 6, 2013. Loving wife of the late Harold, peerless mother of Zachary and Judith and her son-in-law Paul Plotz, adored Granny of John and David, cherished great-grandmother of Noa, Helen, Jacob, Daria, and Gideon. An indefatigable teacher to generations of Midwood High School students, a brilliant gardener, and an ever-curious conversationalist up to her last day.

ELBERSON--Robert E. (Bob) Robert E. (Bob) Elberson passed away peacefully in his sleep at his home in Charlotte, NC, on February 26, 2013. He was born in Winston-Salem, NC, the son of Charles E. and Harriet B. Elberson. Mr. Elberson actively supported personal advancement through higher education by establishing and endowing scholarships at Salem College in Winston-Salem, NC. Mr. Elberson also facilitated innovation and entrepreneurship in the non-profit realm through Reemprise Fund, a foundation he began in 2005. Mr. Elberson is a graduate of Princeton University and Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration. He also served in the Air Force for two years. His career included: President of Hanes Hosiery, Winston-Salem, NC, 1968, where he launched the successful L'eggs brand; President & Chief Executive Officer Hanes Corporation, 1972; President & Chief Operating Officer Sara Lee Corporation, Chicago, IL, 1983; Vice Chairman Sara Lee Corporation, 1986. Since his retirement in 1989, Mr. Elberson has focused his resources and time on philanthropic work and travel, both his true passions. Mr. Elberson's immediate family includes daughter Ann Lee and her husband, Eric Lee, of Port Orchard, WA, son, Charlie Elberson and his wife, Lou Kinard, of Charlotte, NC, and his grandchildren, Marshall Hatfield, Joe Elberson and Annie Elberson. There will be a private service for the family. Mr. Elberson will be laid to rest in the Salem Moravian Graveyard, Winston-Salem, NC. Memorial contributions may be made to: Reemprise Fund c/o Foundation of the Carolinas; www.fft.org or Salem Academy and College, c/o Vicki Sheppard, VP Institutional Advancement, 601 South Church Street, Winston-Salem, NC 27101. Services are in the care of Hankins & Whittington Funeral Service; please share condolences online at www.hankinswhittington.com

GARDE--Harriet Merritt Dixon, died peacefully in her home in Greenwich, CT at the age of 83. She was born in Loudonville, NY and raised in Hewlett, LI. She graduated from Miss Porter's School '47 and Columbia Teachers College, becoming a teacher at the Spence School in NYC and Lawrence School in Hewlett. She lived in Lawrence, then Locust Valley, NY. A dedicated and gifted athlete all her life, she played for the Long Island Women's Field Hockey Association. She excelled in club sports, particularly in squash doubles and golf. At the Rockaway Hunt Club she was a ten time women's golf champion. She was a long standing member of the Women's Long Island Golf Association where she served as Membership Chair, as well as being a lifelong member of the Metropolitan Women's Golf Association. She was predeceased by her first husband of 24 years, Lawrence Howland Dixon, a NYC commodities broker with Farr Man. She was also predeceased by her second husband, John F. Garde Jr. She is survived by her daughters, Wendy Dixon Fog of New Canaan, Ct and Meredith Dixon Finan of Greenwich and New Jersey, and her grandchildren Merritt and Courtney Fog and Austin, Peter and Hallie Finan. Services will be held at Woodlawn Cemetery in Bronx, NY in early May. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Visiting Nurse Association of Long Island in Garden City, NY or The Breast Cancer Research Foundation. For further information kindly contact Fred Knapp Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT. 203-869-0315.
GOLDSMITH--Alvin. Adored husband of Jerene for 56 years. Daughter Suzy and Stephen, Son Bill and Nancy, grandson Leo. Funeral at Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam on Sunday, March 3rd at 12:45pm.

ISRAEL--Ira, of New York and Miami Beach, passed away peacefully, on March 1st, after a long illness. A man of high morals with a generous heart filled with kindness and love. He is survived by Mora, his wife of forever and adoring children, Michael, Sarah, and Rich. He will be missed by all who loved him. Donations in Ira's honor may be made to Miller School of Medicine at the University of Miami in care of Fatta B. Nahab, M.D., Assistant Professor of Neurology & Neuroscience.

KARTEN--Mildred. Mildred Karten b. July 23, 1915, d. February 23, 2013. At 97, years old, she was the matriarch of the family. She was predeceased by Marcus and Sidney She lived her life with academic curiosity, generosity and commitment to family. She will truly be missed by her loving and devoted children and their spouses, Howard and Naomi, Laura and Jimmy, and Elaine and Keith; her cherished grandchildren and spouses, Merryl and Dave, Mike and Christina, Shari and Mitch and Amy and Jon; and her adoring great-granddaughter Lia.
LEBER--Marion. To our beautiful friend Marion, what good times we had. Wonderful memories. We send our deepest sympathy to Steve and the entire Leber family. Love, Brenda & Bob Feldman

NEU--John L.,Our firm expresses its profound sorrow on the passing of our dear friend, John L. Neu. A highly successful businessman, John was an intellectual powerhouse, always eager to analyze and solve knotty problems. John would have had a brilliant legal career had he chosen to stay in practice instead of joining his father, who he loved and respected very much, in business. He grasped very complex legal issues with lightning speed and before you could turn around, John had figured out a creative solution to the issue or problem just presented. We enjoyed seeing the wry smile that came across his face at such moments or when he offered a bon mot. John always demonstrated sincere and kind appreciation for efforts made on his behalf. John, together with his adored wife Wendy, have lived their lives with integrity and a steadfast devotion to promoting the public good and to a multitude of charitable activities. Just as a most recent example, we shall never forget how eager John and Wendy were to help the victims of Superstorm Sandy -- to serve meals, give money for a variety of needed supplies, and enlist the aid of government representatives on their behalf. John's goodness was a blessing to his friends and family, but also to many he never knew. We express our deepest sympathies to Wendy, to all the members of the Neu and Kelman families and to the dedicated employees of Hugo Neu Corporation. Herrick, Feinstein LLP

Harriet Tubman Centennial, New York and Maryland A woman leads a military expedition against a brutal regime, helping hundreds of people to escape. Sounds like the plot of a Quentin Tarantino film, but it is the story of Harriet Tubman, above, who died 100 years ago next week. New York State, where she settled, and Maryland, where she led many to freedom, are full of events in her honor, including a wreath-laying at her grave in Fort Hill Cemetery in Auburn, N.Y., on March 9, and a party that same day at the Harriet Tubman Museum in Cambridge, Md. ( harriettubmanbyway.org )
 
“Mirror,” Seattle Seattle’s cloudy days may get a little brighter with the addition of “Mirror,” a permanent installation on the facade of the city’s art museum. Doug Aitken, fresh from a turn at converting a Manhattan gallery into a cave, is mounting tremendous LED panels on the Seattle Art Museum that show images of the Northwest. For the debut on March 24, Mr. Aitken has organized an event with a nod to the ’60s and ’70s: it is called “Happening” and features a performance of a work by Terry Riley. ( seattleartmuseum.org )

An article last Sunday about the financial challenges facing the veterinary profession referred incorrectly to the federal tax treatment of forgiven debt for veterinary students. It is treated as income, not as a gift. The article also referred incorrectly to conditions under which foreign veterinary schools can have their students qualify for United States federal loans. Although a school’s accreditation by the Council on Education of the American Veterinary Medical Association is needed for some loans,  it is not required for all types. The article also misstated the name of the town where Alisha Oehling, a 2009 graduate of Virginia-Maryland Regional College of Veterinary Medicine, once practiced. It is Clarksville, Va., not Sparksville.
 
A chart with the article, showing trends in the profession, reversed the labels in a line graph. The bottom line was for the number of pet dogs and cats in the United States, and the top line for the number of visits to veterinarians. And another line graph in the chart mislabeled veterinary pay figures. The graph showed the average starting pay for veterinarians, not average overall pay in the profession. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/businessday .

The Anti-Met to the Rescue
 
The 1986 Mets are revered as a rowdy band of rogues, playing hard on the field and living harder off it. But when they faced elimination in Game 6 of the 1986 World Series — bottom of the 10th inning, two outs, bases empty, down two runs — their nicest guy saved them.

An article last Sunday about a new development at 21 West 20th being built by Gale International misstated the name of the city in South Korea where another Gale project is located. It is in Songdo, not Songdo Lake.

“It’s like going to the prom,” he said. “Except that everyone except you is famous.”

Norwegian , the first low-cost, long-haul airline to connect the United States to Europe, is searching for planes to lease for its inaugural flights on May 30 after Boeing warned that the Dreamliners, above, on which the airline based its cheap fares may not be flying. After the planes were grounded by the F.A.A. on Jan. 16, the carrier offered refunds to travelers, but few changed their plans. Fares were as low as $379 for flights from New York to Stockholm or Oslo. Last fall, the airline’s chief executive, Bjorn Kjos, called the Dreamliner “the tool” that will enable “low cost airlines in Europe to grow very fast and get very big.”

Everything is scripted for the brokers in an elite group at JPMorgan Chase : the sales pitches; the personal voice mail message; even the preferred desk candy, Glitterati Fruit & Berry.
 
In a three-inch-thick training manual, the bank, the nation’s largest, details how to recruit clients, pitch products and, ultimately, close the deal — or, as JPMorgan puts it, “get to Yes!”

NICHOLSON--Ronald A. Born February 9, 1928. Died at home February 26 from complications of liver cancer. Predeceased by his mother and father, Ethel (Alfond) and Max Nicholson. A consummate story-teller. Lived big with quiet reserve. Quintessential negotiator-dispassionate, analytical and fair. Zealot fan. Thoroughbred owner and breeder. City Journal chronicled poker-playing aficionado. Loved his family and his country. Loyal to a fault. Will be missed only when those who love him can consciously accept his absence. For now we all still hear his laughter. Survived in sadness by his significant other and wife of forty plus years, Pat (Emsworth-Rodgers) and son, Justin, as well as daughter and son Leslie and James by his first marriage to the former Susan Zeckendorf. Ron was an adoring grandfather to Madeleine, Eric, Alison and Scott Goldstein; Amanda, David and Michael Nicholson; a caring older brother to Alfred (Pete); a beloved uncle to his nieces and nephews and a trusted and respected extended family member, friend and colleague. Cremation and burial private. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Wednesday, March 13, 2013 at 3:30pm. Family will receive visitors immediately following the memorial service at the residence of Pat Nicholson, 1016 Fifth Avenue (entrance on 83rd Street), apartment 15A. In lieu of flowers, Ron would revel in knowing you sent your contribution in his name to Wounded Warrior Project, PO Box 758517, Topeka, KS 66675.

National parks, forests and wildlife refuges are to receive $12.5 million in grants to improve access to them while supporting greener travel, according to Ray LaHood, the transportation secretary. One example is a $1,735,000 grant to expand the Rocky Mountain Greenway, a pedestrian and bicycle trail system that will connect the Denver metropolitan area’s trail systems, three national wildlife refuges in the region and Rocky Mountain National Park , above. Another grant will finance new fuel-efficient buses for visitors in Glacier National Park . The grants, announced amid fears of widespread budget cuts to services in national parks due to sequestration, are part of $80 million in funds for transit improvements over the last three years.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about fierce competition in some New York neighborhoods for children’s activities misidentified, in some editions, the library in Bay Ridge that hosts free story-time sessions. It is the Brooklyn Public Library, not the New York Public Library.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With a weak outfield and a rickety bullpen, the Mets will need solid starting pitching if they hope to move up in the standings this season.
 
Yet questions abound. Johan Santana has not pitched in a game this spring and may not be ready for opening day; Shaun Marcum had one poor outing and has been sidelined; Zack Wheeler, the team’s top pitching prospect, was scratched from a start this week because of stiffness in his abdomen.

An article on Feb. 17 about race and film misspelled the surname of the actress who plays Mary Todd Lincoln’s friend and dressmaker in “Lincoln.” She is Gloria Reuben, not Rueben. The article also misspelled the given name of the director of “Beasts of the Southern Wild.” He is Benh Zeitlin, not Behn. And the article misidentified the legislation that had been passed in “Lincoln” right before the character Thaddeus Stevens, played by Tommy Lee Jones, returned home. It was the 13th Amendment, which abolished slavery; it was not the Emancipation Proclamation, an order issued by Lincoln in January 1863 that declared that all slaves in 10 Confederate states should be considered free.

BRIDGES--William Emery 1933-2013. The author, teacher and consultant whose pioneering work on transition transformed the way people think about change, died on February 17, 2013, at his home in Larkspur, California, from complications of Lewy Body Disease. His death was confirmed by his wife, Susan Bridges. He was 79. Through his books, including Transitions and Managing Transitions, his public speaking and the international network of experts he certified to coach people, Mr. Bridges had a global impact upon educators, psychologists, corporate executives, business consultants and non-profit leaders as well as the general public. The Wall Street Journal named him one of the top ten executive development presenters in America. As John Alexander, former CEO of the Center for Creative Leadership, observed, "Bill's contribution was incalculable. He gave us a vocabulary for understanding and talking about change that was entirely absent before. He helped us understand how people actually experience change and what they need to get through it." William Emery Bridges was born in Boston in 1933, the son of Ronald Perkins Bridges and Helen Emery Bridges. He lived as a young child in Maine, Arizona and California. He received his BA in English from Harvard, his MA in American History from Columbia and his PhD in American Civilization from Brown University. He served in the US Army in Germany. He married Ramonda Kump in 1959. Mr. Bridges held the Aurelia Henry Reinhard Professorship of American Literature position at Mills College in Oakland, California, in the late 1960's, when he became interested in the psychology of literature. In 1970, he led a three-week training program in humanistic and depth psychology, bringing some of the era's most influential thinkers together. He would later become President of the Society for Humanistic Psychology. In 1980 he published Transitions: Making Sense of Life's Changes. In it he set forth the idea that, while change was situational, transition was psychological, and needed to be better understood, especially in America where change is both endemic and rapid. Transitions proposed that individuals experience change in three stages: first as an ending, followed by a period of confusion and distress, and then followed by a new beginning. He noted that because Western culture offers few rituals to mark the passage through these stages, people often try to skip from the first stage directly to the last. Instead, he asked individuals to spend time in what he called "the neutral zone" as a way of psychologically accommodating the space between. The book struck a strong chord with readers and it was followed by Managing Transitions: Making the Most of Change in 1991, also a national best-seller and now in its third edition. In 2001, he published The Way of Transition: Embracing Life's Most Difficult Moments, which in part explored the pain of his own transition following the death of his first wife, Mondi, of breast cancer. In 1994, he published JobShift: How to Prosper in a Workplace Without Jobs, which was excerpted and featured on the cover of Fortune Magazine. Exploring the consequences of flattening hierarchies and the disappearance of management jobs that characterized the recession of the early 1990's, Mr. Bridges accurately predicted the explosive growth of self-employment and helped people understand how to prepare for a world in which secure jobs would be increasingly scarce. In the 1980's, he began consulting with individuals and organizations about managing transition. He founded William Bridges & Associates and developed customized training programs for organizations experiencing transition. These programs were conducted worldwide. In 1998, he married Susan Mitchell, a colleague and established leadership development consultant, who joined him as a partner in the business. Mrs. Bridges became President of William Bridges and Associates in 2007. In 2000, Mr. Bridges was approached by Steven Kelban, Executive Director of the Andrus Family Fund, a division of the Surdna Foundation. The Andrus Family Fund makes grants to non-profits working in foster care and community reconciliation. They began a collaboration that Mr. Kelban said has made a substantial difference in helping both young people and damaged communities adapt to change by incorporating transition management principles. Jim Kouzes, author of The Leadership Challenge, noted, "Bill's major contribution was to give us permission to talk about the pain and difficulty of change and acknowledge that it can be very confusing. Americans have shame around pain--success is somehow supposed to be easy. If you're struggling, it's as if you've failed. Bill moved past that relentless optimism and said, yes, you can find real meaning in change but only if you are willing to experience the pain." Tom Yeomans, founder of The Concord Institute, notes that the Emersonian tradition continued to affect Mr. Bridges' work. "Trust informed Bill's process and trust is the core idea of self-reliance--trusting your instinct, what you know, your potential to be more truly yourself, trusting the process of change and moving with it. Bill's work was profoundly consistent, built on the recognition of a deep human pattern, but he found many ways to develop it. Because he remained deeply connected to Emerson and the transcendentalists, he helped open organizations and individuals to the possibility of transcendence." Mr. Bridges is survived by his wife, Susan Bridges, his daughters from his first marriage, Anne Gavin (Curtis Gavin), Sarah Bridges, and Margaret Bridges, seven grandchildren, and his brother, Daniel Bridges. Memorial services are pending. Donations may be made to the UCSF Foundation for the "William and Susan Bridges Neurohospitalist Program Fund B2390" and sent to S. Andrew Josephson MD, Director, Neurohospitalist Program, UCSF, 505 Parnassus Ave, Box 0114, San Francisco, CA 94143.
