Quotes are the mental furniture of my life. From certain angles my inner landscape resembles a gallery hung with the rags and tag-ends of a lifetime of reading and listening. They can be anything at all, the exquisitely chiseled perceptions of poets or the blurts of unscheduled truth-telling by public figures caught in the spotlight; the punch lines of 1930s comedians or the curtain lines of Jacobean dramatists. They are the dangling threads that memory can latch onto when everything else goes blank. 
 
What is the use of quotations? They have, of course, their practical applications for after-dinner speakers. But the gathering of such fragments responds to a much deeper compulsion. It resonates with the timeless desire to seize on the minimal remnant out of which the world could, in a pinch, be reconstructed. Libraries may go under, cultures may go under, but single memorizable bits of rhyme and discourse persist over centuries.

GRANITO--Frank H.,Jr. Frank H. Granito, Jr., of Stamford, CT died suddenly on February 27, 2013 at the age of 81. Affectionately known as Ditto, he was born August 8, 1931 in New York City to Dr. Frank and Nora Granito. Frank grew up happily in the Bronx and attended Cardinal Hayes High School (where he was elected to the Hall of Fame in 2004), the University of Chicago, Fairfield University and St. John's Law School. During the 1950's and 60's, Frank served as a Naval Aviator with the Pacific Fleet and with the Naval Reserve, flying a variety of fighter and attack aircraft. A renowned aviation law specialist, Frank spent the past 46 years with his firm, Speiser, Krause, Nolan & Granito and for the past 25 years practiced law with his son Frank. He was a mentor to many. As an active trial lawyer representing families of aviation disasters, Frank was involved in nearly every major aviation case of the past 50 years. Notably, among the cases Frank participated in were the following air disaster litigations: Mohawk Airlines, Rochester (1963); United Airlines, Parrotsville (1964); Canadian Pacific Airways, Tokyo (1966); Overseas National Airways, St. Croix (1970); TWA 707, Ionian Sea (1974); Eastern Airlines Flight 66, JFK (1975 ); Texasgulf Aviation (1981); Spantax DC-10, Spain (1982); LOT Polish Airlines, Warsaw (1987); Pan Am Flight 103 (1988); Avianca Flight 052 (1990); Action Air B-99, Bridgeport (1994); USAir DC-9, Charlotte (1994); USAF CT-43, Croatia (1996); TWA Flight 800 (1996); Swissair Flight 111 (1998); Egyptair Flight 990 (1999); AA Flight 587 (2001) and the litigation arising from the 9/11 tragedy. Frank was instrumental in continuing the fight of the Pan Am 103 families in holding Libya accountable for the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The historic settlement resulted in compensation for the Pan Am 103 families and the framework for renewed diplomatic relations between Libya and the United States. Frank and his colleagues who negotiated the settlement with Libya were awarded the 2009 Public Justice Trial Lawyer of the Year Award. Frank was an adjunct professor of aviation law at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University and a frequent lecturer at Fordham and St. John's Law Schools. He lectured and wrote extensively about aviation, choice of law and trial practice. His expertise was renown. When he wasn't at work, he was most times painting or attending to his memoirs, with a keen ability to recall events of many decades ago with mystifying detail. Extremely proud of his Bronx roots, Frank maintained lifelong friendships with his pals from Clason Point, Cardinal Hayes and St. John's. Equally proud of his service to our country, he held annual reunions with his squadron mates. And his cadre of warhorse aviation lawyers, the Sunshine Boys, held monthly "lunch meetings" to reminisce of days gone by. Frank was a devout Catholic and a person who quietly but generously supported those many causes near and dear to his heart. He was happiest when surrounded by his family, especially his wonderful grandchildren of whom he was so proud, and his beautiful bride whom he cherished so dearly. Frank is survived by his wife of 56 years, Helen Elizabeth "Betty" Altieri. He was the proud father of Catherine and Tim Langan, Frank III and Monica, Nora and Dan Harris and John and Luci. Frank was blessed with 16 grandchildren: Timmy, Matty, Mark and John Langan, Frank IV, Jimmy Joe, Jake, Catherine and Gunnar Granito, Cathleen, Will, Peter and Charlie Harris, John and Julia Granito. Frank was predeceased by his grandson Luke Langan. Brother of Nora (Cass) Chomicz, Gennaro (Maureen), Eileen (Andy) Simons, Sheila (Don) Dunphy. Predeceased by his sister Margaret Rose and brother John Teeple. Brother-in-law of Richard (Sharon) Altieri, Jimmy (Geri) Altieri and Johnny (Kathleen) Altieri, and loving uncle to many nieces and nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. Visiting hours will be held Sunday, March 3, 2013 from noon to 6pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT 06905. A funeral Mass will be held on Monday, March 4, 2013 at 11am at St. Leo Roman Catholic Church located at 24 Roxbury Rd., Stamford, CT 06902. A private interment will be held on Tuesday morning. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Betty and Frank Granito Scholarship Fund at Cardinal Hayes High School, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx 10451.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from Feb. 22 to 28.
 
1. LAST-LAP CRASH IN NASCAR RACE INJURES FANS A 12-car crash sent debris into the stands at the end of the Nationwide Series race at Daytona.

Why do European countries have lower levels of poverty and inequality than the United States? We used to think this was a result of American anti-government sentiment, which produced a government too small to redistribute income or to attend to the needs of the poor. But over the past three decades scholars have discovered that our government wasn’t as small as we thought. Historians, sociologists and political scientists have all uncovered evidence that points to a surprisingly large governmental presence in the United States throughout the 20th century and even earlier, in some cases surpassing what we find in Western Europe.
 
For example, European banks did not have to contend with regulations separating commercial and investment banking, as American banks did under the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933. Until the 1980s taxes on capital income were higher in the United States than in most European countries, where taxes on labor were and still are higher. American bankruptcy law has been harder on creditors and easier on debtors than any of the countries of Europe, even after bankruptcy reform here in 2005. Or consider the famous case of the thalidomide babies in the late 1950s and early 1960s. Thalidomide was a drug given to pregnant women for nausea. It caused devastating birth defects, from stunted limbs to spina bifida, and many babies died. Thalidomide was widely available in Europe and produced thousands of cases of birth defects there. But the Food and Drug Administration kept thalidomide off the American market, successfully using aggressive governmental intervention to protect children from a pharmaceutical company with a dangerous product. They would be in their early 50s now, those babies saved by the F.D.A. I wonder sometimes how many of them are walking around today complaining about big government.

Accra, Ghana

 
I was traveling in Ghana to study their 2012 presidential and parliamentary elections, and I came to the University of Ghana because it was serving as a polling station. The campus illustrated a phenomenon I observed repeatedly during my eight days there: while the people were as bright, warm and expressive as the colors that surrounded them, they were, in their commerce, politics and infrastructure, unabashedly and perhaps necessarily utilitarian. I snapped this shot of the dorms as good as any example of that unique juxtaposition in their character. JOSHUA SUGARMAN, New York, Dec. 7, 2012

‘Hollywood’ Charms the Crowd“Hair! Makeup!” Brandi Chastain said in a mock-diva voice backstage on “Late Show With David Letterman.”It was three days before the start of the 1999 Women’s World Cup. Mia Hamm had begged off, so Chastain took her place. She was not averse to the spotlight. Her nickname was Hollywood. Teammate Julie Foudy referred to Chastain as her favorite actress.She was unfailingly pleasant and accommodating. After one World Cup match, Chastain tossed a pair of cleats to a fan who had chased the team bus. She always seemed agreeable and at ease, giving interviews, taking penalty kicks at clinics against high school players, throwing out the first pitch at a Yankees game and pretending to shake off the catcher’s sign.Few were calmer in pressured moments. The 1999 World Cup was then the largest sporting event ever held for women. The championship game against China distilled itself to a penalty-kick shootout. Ninety thousand fans crowded into the Rose Bowl. An estimated 40 million Americans watched some part of the match on television.Hamm did not want to take a penalty kick but was forced to. Chastain reveled in the moment, scored the decisive shot, and then removed her jersey, her chiseled physique presenting an iconic image of female strength and celebration.“You have to be willing to stand in front of the crowd and say, ‘I’m the one to take on the responsibility,’ ” Chastain said. JERÉ LONGMAN

Andrew Mason, founder of the daily deals site Groupon, is a big goof. He was booted last week as chief executive, but didn’t let it cramp his style. Mr. Mason’s resignation letter, which he tweeted under the entirely reasonable notion that it would leak anyway, said he was leaving to spend more time with his family, the age-old alibi of dismissed chiefs everywhere. Then he came clean: “Just kidding — I was fired today.”
 
Mr. Mason added a dose of humor to what many can only hope will be a new kind of corporate goodbye: the honest one. Carol Bartz, a former Yahoo chief, was a pioneer of this approach. “I’ve just been fired,” she told her staff in 2011, a comment that won her more respect than anything else in her brief tenure.

TAMPA, Fla. — Boone Logan had a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left elbow, which revealed no structural damage, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Saturday. But Logan, the Yankees left-handed relief pitcher, is still feeling pain in one spot in his elbow so he will be shut down until the pain is gone. Girardi described the elbow as tender.
 
Outfielder Slade Heathcott, one of the organization’s top prospects who , sprained his right thumb during an outfield collision with Ronnier Mustelier on Thursday, also had a clean M.R.I. Girardi said Heathcott would need a few days off.

GOLDWATER--Maria Udenburgh, age 79 of Manhattan, died on February 22, 2013, of a short illness after years of managing the advancement of Alzheimer's disease. Born in Brooklyn, she was one of six sisters raised in the Bronx, Maria began her career in 1951 as a legal secretary to Richard M. Goldwater, one of the senior partners at the law firm of Goldwater & Flynn. In 1965 she volunteered in the primary and regular election campaigns of Jonathan B. Bingham for the U.S. House of Representatives, and then joined his staff in Washington DC as his personal secretary. After her marriage in 1966 to Richard M. Goldwater, she returned to New York and continued to work for Congressman Bingham. She obtained her BA, cum laude, from Marymount Manhattan College in 1987, and worked for many years as a Personnel Administrator. She is survived by her sisters, Olympia Santiago, Evangelina Gonzalez and Carmen Nieves; brother-in-law Peter Nieves, 15 nieces and nephews; and three stepsons, David, Daniel and Harry. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th Street, 3 to 5pm, and 7 to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter.

HOLMES--Constance Tizard Lewis. April 24, 1964 to February 23, 2013. Constance Tizard Lewis-Holmes, daughter of the late Geoffrey A. Tizard and Grace (Waldt) Tizard of Towson, Maryland. Sister of Geoffrey A. and his wife, Patricia, and Steven W. and his wife, Tracey, died on February 23, 2013 at University of Pennsylvania Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania after a long illness. Constance was a graduate of Towson High School and attended Towson University and Marymount Manhattan College, where she majored in English. An avid reader, Constance also enjoyed playing classical piano. She excelled in swimming, was an accomplished equestrian, enjoyed water skiing and was a certified scuba diver. She spoke French and Italian and used both languages often in her travels. While working as a model in New York City during the 1980's, Constance met and married her first husband, the late Edward R. Lewis of Brenner & Lewis a New York City and International hotel broker and art collector. She spent her years in New York volunteering for many charities and enjoying the arts. A member of SAG, she had cameo appearances in "Law & Order," "Roseanne," and a small role in the movie "Aviator." In January 2000, Constance married her second husband, Gregory G. Holmes. Together, they settled in Charleston, SC to raise their two children, Olivia and Heath. A stay at home mother, Constance enjoyed nothing more than being with her children. She spent most summers at her villa in Round Hill Jamaica teaching them both to swim, water ski, and enjoy the Jamaican sunsets. Constance is survived by her two children, mother, brothers, nieces and nephews; Geoffrey III, Brendan, Catherine Ashley, Evan, Emma, and her Aunt, Ingrid W. Gillilland of Arlington, VA. Beloved Daughter, Sister, Mother and Friend.May You Finally Be at Peace. KENT--Lillian J. Lillian passed away peacefully in her sleep at her home in Manhattan's Upper East Side on February 11th. She was 96 years old. Lillian was born on May 27, 1916 in Brooklyn to Ellis Jaffe and Anna Blumberg. Extraordinarily bright, determined and ahead of her time, Lillian earned her Bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College in 1936 and her Master's Degree from the University of Michigan in 1937. She worked in advertising sales for many years before founding her own highly regarded advertising agency at a time when it was extremely unusual for a woman to do so. She went on to serve as the president of Advertising Women of New York. She married Jack Kent in 1951, who treasured her until his death in 1973. Along with the deep love of her family, Lillian earned the unwavering friendship, respect and admiration of a multitude of people. She enjoyed life to the fullest and loved to take in all that New York had to offer particularly the ballet, theatre, museums, and restaurants. While she traveled extensively, she believed that there is no better place in the world than New York City. Lillian was well known for her generosity, volunteerism and deep desire and sense of responsibility to help others in need. She feared nobody and was known to speak her mind with honesty and passion. She followed current events closely, reading The New York Times from cover-to-cover each day. She had a remarkable ability to relate to younger generations, and despite the difference in age, her nieces and nephews (and great-nieces and great- nephews) routinely looked to her for guidance and friendship in all aspects of life. She is preceded in death by her husband, her parents, her brothers Harold and Herman Jaffe, whom she adored and who adored her, her sister-in-law Trude Jaffe, and her aunt, Tilly Strysower, who was like a mother to her. She is survived by her youngest brother Daniel Jaffe and his wife Lori, her cousin Joan Levitt, niece Susan Jaffe, nephew David Jaffe and his wife Maureen, nephews Brian Jaffe and Edward Jaffe and Edward's wife Sandy, great nephews Andrew Jaffe and Michael Jaffe, and great nieces Hilary Jaffe and Sarah Jaffe. Her family will greatly miss their mentor and friend. She will forever be in their hearts. A celebration of Lillian's life will be held at a future date to be announced. Contributions in Lillian's memory may be sent to Save the Children Foundation, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, CT 06881.

McKEE--James W. James W. McKee Jr. passed away February 27, 2013 in Naples, FL, after a brief illness. The son of James W. and Isabel McKee, he was born in Pittsburgh, August 19, 1922. Business relocation took the family to Montreal in 1934, where Jim graduated with distinction, first from Lower Canada College, and then from McGill University. During World War II he was a pilot who served initially as an instructor, before being assigned as a command pilot to the 9th Air Force in England and in France. In 1946 Jim joined Corn Products Refining Company (name changed to CPC International in 1969), a diversified food manufacturer of well known trademarks including Mazola, Hellmann's (mayonnaise), Thomas's (English Muffins), Skippy (peanut butter), and Knorr (soups and sauces), as well as the world's leading corn wet milling company. He spent his first 17 years with CPC on international assignments, primarily in Italy, Brazil and Cuba. In 1969, five years after relocating back to the United States he was appointed company president, followed by the appointment to CEO in 1972, the youngest CEO in the company's history. During his tenure as president and CEO, and until he retired in 1984, the company's sales quadrupled to exceed $4.3 billion and earnings growth compounded at just under 9% per year. In addition to CPC International, Jim served on a number of corporate boards of directors, including Marine Midland Bank, Melville Corporation, CVS, and Singer. He was president of the Conference Board; a member of the Council on Foreign Affairs; head of the Grocery Manufacturer's Association; and head of the American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in the early 1960's. He served as a trustee for several organizations, including St. Vincents Hospital, The College of New Rochelle, and the Committee for Economic Development, among others. The government of Brazil honored him twice with the country's highest civilian award, the Cruzeiro Do Sul medals for his contributions to Brazil's economy and to Brazilian/American relations. He also received honorary citations from the Geographic Society of Brazil, and the Union Cultural, among others for outstanding contributions. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from St. John's University for his academic and professional contributions in the field of economics, in particular, operating in inflationary environments. In retirement, Jim researched the McKee family genealogy, and self published the results in 2002: The Descendents of William and Mary Wilson McKee. Among his hobbies were his golf game (three holes-in-one), his computer, visiting hardware stores, reading books and newspapers, and managing investments. Jim is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Jayne (Finnegan); daughter Bettina McKee of Naples, FL; son James W. McKee III (wife, Pamela) of Charlotte, NC; daughter Sheila McKee of Boston, MA; two grandsons and two great-granddaughters. He was preceded in death by his brother, Robert McKee. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Monday, March 4, 2013 at 10am at St. William Catholic Church, 750 Seagate Drive, Naples. Interment will be in St. Mary's Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. Donations in Jim's memory may be made to NCH Healthcare System, P.O. Box 413029, Naples, FL 34101; www.NCHmd.org. Online condolences may be made at www.fullernaples.com

An article last Sunday about Salt Lake City’s struggle with poor air quality misstated details of the atmospheric inversions during the winter months that lead to a thick fog of dirty air cloaking the region. It is intermittent warm high-pressure systems — not warm fronts — that trap the cold air and keep pollutants from escaping.

Sisters Annie and Therese Gibbons, creators of the blockbuster home fragrance brand Alora Ambiance , have channeled their past and present travels into a new collection of personal perfume oils named after their mother. “I fell in love with the ritual of applying oil to your skin, and fragrance oils are more concentrated and therefore last longer as well,” Annie says. Green, which contains notes of fig leaves and wet oakmoss, aims to capture their childhood memories of growing up on a southern Minnesota farm; Incense, a blend of peppery-sweet bergamot and burnt firewood, evokes the spicy-smoky aroma of the Romanesque cathedrals they would frequently pass while living in Lake Como, Italy; and Gardenia celebrates the exotic flora of Hawaii, where Annie resides. “I actually sent several gardenia flowers, tuberoses and pikake leis to our perfumers, and we ended up with an authentic gardenia scent that smells like my backyard,” she says. Thanks to the supersleek refillable perfume holder, you can securely stash the fragrance oil in your bag and always have it within reach, regardless of where life may take you.
 
Terveer perfume oil and vial holder set, $185; Barneys New York .

ARNOLD--Robert Morris, of Seattle, noted banking executive, venture capitalist, and philanthropist died at his home in Palm Springs, California on Wednesday, February 27, 2013. Bob, as he was known to his legion of friends, died peacefully after a brief illness. He was 84. A lifelong resident of Seattle, with homes in San Francisco and Palm Springs, Mr. Arnold was prominent in Seattle banking circles as a long time Vice President and Director of the Seattle First National Bank. Additionally, he was a highly regarded angel and venture investor who possessed an uncanny eye for the next great idea. He was also a very active philanthropist who supported amongst other things the Fred C. Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, the Seattle Art Museum, Swedish Medical Center and Yale University. Mr. Arnold graduated from the Lakeside School in Seattle, Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, New Jersey and received his BA from Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut in 1951. Following Yale, Mr. Arnold enlisted in the US Navy where he received his Aviator Wings in 1952. He flew jet fighter aircraft missions from two aircraft carriers, the Yorktown and Essex during and after the Korean War and retired as a Lieutenant, J.G. after his years of active duty service and a stint in the Naval Reserve. After his time in the service, he embarked on a career in finance, steadily working his way up through SeaFirst Bank. After the bank was sold in the early 1980s, Mr. Arnold turned his attention to venture financing and it was here he achieved his greatest business success. A pioneer in the field years before it became fashionable, he was attracted to the entrepreneurial spirit and the dynamism that evolved from the hatching of new and creative ideas. While he possessed the commensurate analytical skills to dissect a new deal, it was his ability to measure up the individual behind the deal that gave him an advantage. "Bob was a true venture capitalist. His steady hand and perspective were second to none." says longtime associate Cole Younger. His track record as an extremely successful investor and willingness to meet just about anyone with a good idea made him a favorite in the venture community. His fingerprints are all over some of the Pacific Northwest's most successful companies. Throughout his life, Mr. Arnold believed in giving back to the things he loved. Longstanding family ties to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center and the Swedish Medical Center provided the catalyst for a lifetime of support. He loved the connection he had to these world class institutions but, more importantly, he loved what they were doing and how they were positively impacting lives. His support of the Seattle Art Museum was an extension of this philosophy. For decades he was a driving force behind this world class facility. Not only did he care deeply about the art, he wanted to ensure that his beloved Seattle had an art museum that could hold its own with any in the country. Finally, his connection to Yale was all encompassing. The years he spent there - the friends he made and the experiences he shared with them - provided the foundation from which he built his life. He made it a point to go to every reunion and stay in constant touch with his cadre of friends. In his spare time Mr. Arnold devoted himself to two passions - travel and friends. His itineraries were legendary in his never-ending quest to visit every country in the world. At the time of his death, he had traveled to 172 and had a new adventure on the books. His curiosity to experience different cultures and meet their people was unquenchable. However, it was his love of his friends, both old and new, that truly fueled him. To say he was a "people person" would be an understatement. Armed with a million stories and the style of a seasoned raconteur, he made countless friends throughout his life's journey. When he brought you into his orbit, there was no finer place to be. Not surprisingly Mr. Arnold was a longtime member of the Seattle Golf, Tennis and Yacht Clubs, the University Club and the Bohemian Club of San Francisco. He also enjoyed his role as a Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin (San Francisco chapter). Mr. Arnold is survived by his wife, Patricia Arnold, his two daughters, Grace Arnold of Rancho Sante Fe, California and Lauren Gorter of Lake Forest, Illinois, son-in-law David Gorter and two grandsons, Christopher and Taylor Gorter In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that contributions be given to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center the Seattle Art Museum or the Swedish Medical Center. A memorial service will be conducted at St. Mark's Cathedral at 1245 10th Avenue East, Seattle, Washington 98102 on Wednesday, March 13, 2013 at 3:00 o'clock.

BORCK--Charles Alan, passed away suddenly on March 1, 2013 at the age of 87, of Rye, New York and Boca Raton, Florida. Mourned by his loving wife of 62 years Virginia (Ginny) Herson Borck and children Leslie (David) Jameson, Jacquelyn Borck (Howard Brett Cutler), Douglas (Lynn) Borck and devoted grandchildren Jennifer (Connor), Jeffrey (Perri), Adam, Julia, Michael, Noel and Andrea. Alan graduated from RPI in 1946 with a degree in Electrical Engineering and has maintained a long relationship with the school ever since. He was a Founder and President of RLC Electronics, Inc. in Mount Kisco, NY where he continued to be a mentor until his death. "The Chief" lived by the motto "tough but fair." A caring man, Alan's greatest love was Ginny and, of course, their family. An avid sportsman, he had a love of golf, tennis, biking, rollerblading and could frequently be found at the gym. He was a long time member of Community Synagogue of Rye, Quaker Ridge Golf Club and Bocaire Country Club. His passion and generosity will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services to be held at Community Synagogue of Rye at 11:00 o'clock, Monday, March 4. A memorial service will be held in Florida at a later date. Donations in Alan's honor may be made to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180.

It has been four years since the ex-stage comedian Morgane Fleury opened her “cave-écologique” on Paris’ seedy Rue Saint-Denis to showcase the biodynamic bubbles that bear her family name. In the intervening years, the wonderfully chaotic Ma Cave Fleury has become a tightly held secret for a bohemian coterie of Parisian actors and musicians who revel in its unpretentious joie de vivre and affordable bottles (costing as little as €25). Its unassuming appearance and unlikely location amid X-rated stores in a gentrifying area belies the fact that it is the cellar door of the small respected Champagne house Fleury Père Et Fils.
 
Now in their fourth generation, the Fleurys are acknowledged as pioneers in winemaking. Morgane Fleury’s great grandfather Emile was the first to plant grafted pinot noir in the region after the invasion of phylloxera. Grandfather Robert took the unusual step of bottling his own grapes when they were refused by the “Grandes Marques” in 1929. And Morgane’s father, Jean-Pierre, was the first producer in the Champagne region to convert entirely to biodynamics in 1992.

Debating the Semantics of ‘Rape’

 
In last Sunday’s Big City column, Ginia Bellafante looked at legislative efforts to expand the definition of rape in New York State, where it is defined narrowly, including a proposal from Assemblywoman Aravella Simotas. A selection of reader responses from NYTimes.com is below.

“Torture is monotonous and sad,” muses Bruno (Michel Subor), the antihero hero of Godard’s “Petit Soldat.” When Bruno is tortured — doused, held under water, burned — it’s not at a black site, hidden from the world, but in a bright bathroom in Geneva, a cleanly anonymous modern space in the heart of Europe. In the next room a woman calmly reads Mao.
 
Made in 1960 but banned in France until 1963, “Le Petit Soldat” still feels daring and vital, both peculiarly timely and deeply Godardian, a meditation not just on politics and war — the Algerian conflict is the background — but also on morality and art. (Bruno has Godard’s famous line: “Cinema is truth at 24 frames a second.” More Bruno: “A gun is a beautiful object: black, mysterious, incorruptible.”) It’s also a love story. Bruno, part of a rightist French terrorist group, falls for Veronica (Anna Karina, in her debut), whose sympathies are with the Algerians. (At Film Forum in a new 35-millimeter print, Friday through March 14, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village; 212-727-8110, filmforum.com .)

Winter nights are long in Nordic lands. But their darkness can be brightened by the Northern Lights of modern dance. That will be demonstrated by “Ice Hot: A Nordic Dance Festival,” which opens Wednesday and presents companies from Finland, Denmark and Norway. The only one familiar in New York is the first attraction, the Tero Saarinen Company, from Finland, but it has not danced in the city since 2006, when Mr. Saarinen’s choreography generated considerable excitement.
 
It may do so again with a double bill of “Scheme of Things,” an emotionally charged group piece, and “Hunt,” a solo to Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.” In this work celebrating the centenary of this tumultuous score Mr. Saarinen becomes both hunter and prey. And that prey can be interpreted either as a beast in the forest outside him or as a monster deep in his mind or heart. It’s a craggy solo from a craggy country.

The Surfacing column on Feb. 17, about Rose Avenue, in the Los Angeles enclave of Venice, misstated the street on which the Frank Gehry-designed Binoculars Building, recently taken over by Google, is situated. It is at 340 Main Street, near Rose Avenue; it is not on Rose.

Miami’s James is having a season discussed only in superlatives, Bryant is playing well as his Lakers empire seems to be crumbling, and Duncan is quietly leading the Spurs to another No. 1 seed in the Western Conference.

RAVEN--James Wilson, of Weston, MA, formerly of Westwood, MA, died peacefully at home Tuesday morning, February 26, 2013. He was 77 years old. Rayen was born April 9, 1935 in Youngstown, Ohio. He was a graduate of Phillips Academy Andover, and received BA, BFA, and MFA degrees from Yale University. After receiving his MFA in 1961, he taught at Wellesley College, where he remained until his retirement in 2003. Rayen was the Elizabeth Christy Kopf Professor of Art, remembered as a devoted teacher and an extraordinary painter. He was strongly influenced by Philip and Maud Morgan at Phillips Academy, and by Josef Albers and Rico Lebrun at Yale. Rayen was a well-known landscape painter who continued to paint and exhibit during retirement. In the 1970s, Professor Rayen was instrumental in helping turn the College's studio art courses into a full major. He was preceded in death by his spouse of 48 years, Bruce Donaldson. They were married in 2007. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held at Wellesley College in April. Contributions in memory of Professor Rayen may be made to Phillips Academy, Andover, MA, or Wellesley College, Wellesley, MA.

Lee's intelligence and subtle wit and inclusive nature brought much joy to her loving family and friends. She will be sorely missed by her children and their spouses, David and Alice, Robert and Linda, Ellen and Bob, and Michael and Pat; her grandchildren and their spouses, Andrew and Deborah, Jonathan and Sheri, Becky and Eric, Amy and Chad, Emily, Jane, Anne, Karen and Rachel; and her great-grandchildren, Juliet, Oliver, Daschle, Theodore, Felix, Jacob, Ava, Samantha, Nathaniel, Jackson, Charlotte.

PARIS — As I said in a previous post, Alber Elbaz saw the problem of all these fashion shows, running like a hamster wheel, each format virtually the same, and in his own way did something about it. But now I’ve seen Raf Simons’s Dior show , and also Undercover (by the amazing Jun Takahashi), and they all express a similar attitude — which is freedom. It sounds silly to say that of talented and well-paid designers, but there’s a reason you leave their shows feeling good.
 
I’ve seen editors sitting in a trance at shows, often at Prada and Céline, where there is as much an interest in what’s new as in the heart-pounding thought, Can it be mine? But it has been a while since I saw anyone watch a show with a smile on her face, as Ikram Goldman, the Chicago retailer, had during the Undercover show.

‘Throw Up On Your Own Time’
 
In his endless quest to emasculate his players and prove to them that he was the man, Bill Parcells perfected the art of being mean. He meticulously studied each of his players to figure outhis weaknesses. Then he harped on those faults to see which players were tough enough to survive his mind games. Parcells called players clowns and brainless idiots. He used cruelty to control those under him, making even millionaire marquee players wish they had never been born. Once, when he saw a Jets player throwing up from exhaustion at practice, he said, “Throw up on your own time.” When a Cowboys running back had along overdue long run in one game, Parcells bellowed in a packed locker room,“Ooh, did you call your mama to tell her you got by four or five players all by yourself?” In Dallas, he refused to call the famously arrogant wide receiver Terrell Owens by his given name, instead referring to him as “the player” or “this player” when talking about him to reporters in his trademark gravelly growl. Even when talking about family, the ever-miserable Parcells barely mustered a smile. Upon the birth of his third grandchild, he grumbled to a reporter as he frowned, “It’s another girl,” as if frustrated that he, despite his omnipotence, could not will the birth of a grandson.When speaking with reporters, heoften prefaced his comments with, “I’m not trying to be a jerk.” But many players over the years didn’t think he was ever trying to be a jerk. They just thought it came naturally.

STATHAKOS--James F.,was born to Frank and Angelina Stathakos in Dallas, Texas on March 24, 1917. He attended University of Texas in Austin, Texas, where he received a law degree. An officer in World War II in the United States Army, he served in the Office of Special Services. As an American Greek, he was stationed in occupied Greece and was awarded the Bronze Star for his service behind enemy lines. In 1946 he married the love of his life Alkione Giovan in Chicago, Illinois. For the next 60 years they divided their time between their homes in New York City and Southampton, NY. For more than thirty years, he held a leadership position in the marine insurance division of Frank B. Hall. In 2004 he retired as a vice president of AoN Corporation. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Deepdale Golf Club, National Golf Links of America, and was well known on the links of the finest golf courses through out the world. His generosity of spirit, gracious manners and winning smile will be remembered by the many he encountered in his daily life. His wife, Alkione, predeceases him, as well as his parents, and sister Constance Condos. A sister Marcella Theodos, twelve nieces and nephews, 11 grand nieces and nephews and nine great- grand nieces and nephews, long time family friend KiKi Spyrou, as well as numerous devoted caregivers survive him. Friends may call Tuesday March 5, 4-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street. Service Wednesday, March 6, 10am at Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 East 74th St. NYC.

There are obviously many playwrights in New York, but how many of them are distinctly New York writers? Who do you associate with this city in the way that fans of other art forms do with Woody Allen or Jay-Z?
 
For me Richard Greenberg, one of the most underrated artists in the American theater, is at the top of the list. While plays like “The Dazzle,” which is about two Collyer-brothers-like figures, evoke Manhattan history, dramas like “Take Me Out” and “Three Days of Rain” are not only set in contemporary New York but also display a sensibility distinct to this city. That’s what makes him a natural choice to write the new stage adaptation of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” which was originally a 1958 novella by Truman Capote before being turned into a movie.

For those torn over which transparent shoes to pluck from both spring and fall runways this year, Reed Krakoff’s mesh and leather stiletto serves double duty for your wardrobe. Taking you not just from spring to fall but also day to night, the heel has a removable elastic strap, which comes in black and nude and slides right on for a little extra oomph.
 
Reed Krakoff mesh pointy pump with removable elastic, $675; reedkrakoff.com .

ATLAS--William, beloved brother, husband, father, uncle and grandfather, died peacefully in his sleep on February 27, at the venerable age of 98. An engineer since 1939, he opened his own firm in New York City in 1956, William Atlas Consulting Engineers. William worked full-time as owner and lead consulting engineer until 2009, when he sold the business at the age of 94. He retired to his home in Great Neck, NY to focus full time on his creative writing. Born in the Bronx on December 15, 1914, William graduated from the City College of New York in 1936, with a BS and MS in civil engineering. He married Ruth Kesselman in 1940, an early childhood educator who predeceased him in 1975. William Atlas Consulting Engineers, over the course of five decades, was responsible for the structural engineering of innumerable commercial, public, and religious projects, as well as private residences throughout the metropolitan area and nationwide. His life's work, as well as his quirky sense of humor and storytelling, will be fondly remembered by his sister Miriam; daughters and their spouses Susan (Jamie), Nancy (Bob), and Liz (Michael who predeceased him); and grandchildren Rachel (Matthew), Jonah and Hannah; as well as the many young engineers he trained over the years. A private family service will be held today in Riverdale, New York.

Daughters: Stephanie, Elizabeth and Jennifer. Brother William and five grandchildren. Burial will be private. A Memorial Service will be held at a time to be announced. For further information go to: www.thegreenfuneralhome .com

He was hugely admired, honored by a pope, emperor and king and poured out an immense quantity of inventive, expressive and ethereal music. Orlando di Lasso (1532-94) is the composer in question and the main subject of a concert this week at Carnegie’s Weill Recital Hall by the Studio de musique ancienne de Montréal, conducted by Christopher Jackson. The Studio, a group of about a dozen voices, was founded in 1974 and is a fixture on Montreal’s healthy early-music scene. 
 
Carnegie Hall called upon the ensemble to fill in for I fagiolini, another early-music group, which had to cancel its United States tour. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org ; $50.)

Often art exhibitions focus on a single artist, but sometimes a museum explores an idea. Starting Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will delve into the concept of walking and wandering through the work of a variety of artists. The show, “A Trip From Here to There,” uses as its starting point the meanderings of Mateo López, who from 2008 to 2010 drew his way through his native Colombia. Traveling from Bogotá to Cali to Medellín by Vespa, Mr. López produced detailed renderings of ordinary objects that crossed his path. Because the country was dominated by government forces and paramilitary rebels, this documentation became in itself an act of resistance. 
 
Mr. López offers a twist on the tradition of painters and draftsmen who have long been instrumental in plotting and investigating place as members of expeditions and surveys. In the second half of the 20th century the journey became both medium and subject. Other artists in the show include Richard Long, Marcel Broodthaers, Juan Downey and Mona Hatoum. (Through July 30, 212-708-9400, moma.org .)

Colgate University is mounting an exhibition of sound-art installations by Chinese artists whose work has never been displayed in the United States. 
 
Sound artists use noise, live performances by musicians, recorded ambient sounds, spoken words, audio-visual tapes and other aural elements to create art installations that either have no visual elements or forge a connection between images and sounds. It has become a popular genre in China in recent years, where a new generation of avant-garde artists are pushing its boundaries.

KOENIGSBERG--Beverly Feit, of San Diego, CA, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, East Windsor, NJ, Denver, CO, and Naples, FL, died on March 1, 2013. Born July 16, 1943, the daughter of Max and Rose Feit, Beverly is survived by her husband of 50 years, Alan, and children Lori (Jordan Steiker), Jason Koenigsberg (Ana) and four grandchildren- Blake, Aaron, Eliza and Max; her brother, Ira Feit (Lisa), sister-in-law Harriet (Gerard Rosenberg) and four nephews. She graduated from Brooklyn College (AB) and the University of Denver (MSW). She was a passionate addictions therapist who loved facilitating recovery in fellowship and practice. The world is much less interesting without her. Services will be held at Congregation Beth Chaim, Princeton Junction, NJ on Tuesday, March 5 at 1pm.

WOLLMAN--June, age 93, died on Sunday, March 3rd at her residence in Old Tappan, NJ. Born and raised in New York, and New Jersey, June lived in Woodcliff Lake for over 20 years before moving to Old Tappan 14 years ago. June's family was her life. Predeceased by her husband Jacob in 1992, she is survived by her two daughters Janet Wollman of New York, NY, Carol Wollman of Woodcliff Lake, NJ, a brother Allan Levey and his wife Barbara of New York, NY, a sister Jacqueline Kanofsky of DE, and two grandchildren Isabelle and Tyler. Funeral services will be held on Monday March 4th at 12:30pm, at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, 735 Forest Ave; Paramus, NJ 07652. Services are under the direction of Gutterman-Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors of Hackensack, NJ. Donations in Mrs. Wollman's name may be made to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital or Best Friends Animal Society.

GRANITO--Frank H.,Jr. St. John's School of Law mourns the passing of our alumnus, friend, and benefactor Frank H. Granito '62. Mr. Granito served his country as a Naval Aviator with the Pacific Fleet and with the Naval Reserve. He was an expert in aviation law, and spent the past 46 years with the firm of Speiser, Kraus, Nolan & Granito, practicing with his son Frank for the past 25 years. Mr. Granito was involved in nearly every major aviation case of the past 50 years. He successfully represented the families of Pan Am 103, which resulted in a historic settlement for the families and was the framework for renewed diplomatic relations between Libya and the United States. Mr. Granito shared his expertise in aviation, writing and lecturing at many local Law Schools including at his alma mater St. John's Law School. At St. John's School of Law, Mr. Granito's legacy lives on through "The Granito Scholar Program", which facilitates scholarly activities at St. John's Law School. Mr. Granito is survived by his wife of 56 years, Helen Elizabeth, and their four children - Catherine '82 (and her husband, Tim Langan '82); Frank Granito III '87 (and his wife, Monica); Nora '86 (and her husband, Dan Harris '82); and John Granito (and his wife, Luci); and fifteen grandchildren. The entire School of Law community extends it prayers and deepest sympathy to the Granito family. Michael A. Simons Dean and John V. Brennan Professor of Law and Ethics

KIRSHBAUM--Kenneth David, MD, died on February 23rd, at age 65. Beloved husband to Sandra. Devoted step-father to Joan (Freddie), and Laura (Chris). He was an alert, able and compassionate psychiatrist who loved his profession and always had great concern for his patients. He also leaves his four beloved rescued cats; Sally, Annie, Lila, and Bruce - a comfort to him on the bed when he was well and when he was sick. His loss is a great source of grief to his family.

LEWIS--Richard David, perhaps best known for his successful New York publicly traded consumer electronics chain, Newmark and Lewis, and their ubiquitous advertisements around the Northeast, passed away on March 2nd, 2013. He was the son of Edith and Moe Lewis and brother of Beth Hyman. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, Dick Lewis was generous yet staunch, gentle yet strong, thoughtful yet lionhearted, and unendingly charming, handsome, and dignified. Mentor and magnanimous confidant, avid tennis player and golfer, Dick spirited his gregarious clan around the world. He is survived by his wife Florence (with whom he had a 62 year love affair), five children, Peter Lewis, Sandy Shorey-Gorovets, Sasha Gorovets, Michelle Kingsley, Todd Kingsley, and his seven grandchildren (who he was immensely proud of), Barri, Craig, Melanie, Sammy, Eric, Becca, and Jack, all of whom cherish him deeply. The service will be held at 10am at Temple Judea on Searingtown Road in Manhasset.

Target and Best Buy have made it pretty clear they are fighting back against the phenomenon of showrooming , in which customers browse for television sets and other products in stores and then buy them online from Amazon and other etailers for less. Both companies recently made their seasonal practices of matching prices at online retailers a year-round policy.
 
A new study of Amazon customers who research products in stores by Placed , a mobile analytics company, offers some insight into who else could be at the greatest risk of losing business to showrooming. The study relies on Placed’s panel of more than 14,000 mobile phone users who consent to have their locations tracked in exchange for store gift cards and other perks. Placed can tell when those people visit a particular retailer without them having to proactively report their store visits.

Ichiro Suzuki’s first spring training    in Florida continues to be    eventful. Last week, he had a    close encounter with an alligator    on a golf course, and on Saturday,    he was involved in a car accident.    In both instances, he came away    unscathed.    Suzuki’s sport utility vehicle    and another car collided at an intersection    near the Yankees’    spring training complex. Suzuki,    who was unhurt, said both cars    were totaled and the air bags in    his S.U.V. deployed.    “I guess you can say that    you’re going to have to do a lot    worse to have me get hurt,” he    said through his interpreter.    Suzuki worked out Sunday and    planned to see the team physician    for precautionary reasons, but he    said he felt nothing.    He said it was his first accident    as a driver, but he was hit by a car    when riding his bike while in high    school in Japan. He said that incident    had made him extra aware    of his surroundings when driving,    and also as a passenger.    “I’m probably the worst backseat    driver,” he said, “because I    see everything and I tell the driver,    ‘Be careful,’ a lot.”

Husband of Gay Kitay Mandon, father of the late Margaret Mandon Wilchins, and the late James Mandon. Survived by his wife, his granddaughter Julie Wilchins and husband David Schor, his grandson Daniel Wilchins and wife Rebecca Wilchins, and his great-grandsons Abraham and Ezra Wilchins. Service to be held at Gutterman Warheit Chapel in Boca Raton, Florida on Monday, March 4th at 9:15am. Contributions in Mr. Mandon's memory may be made to the Fair Lawn Jewish Center, the Jewish Federation of Northern New Jersey, the American Cancer Society, or the charity of your choice.

The revolving door of casting continues to spin at “Downton Abbey” as the popular PBS/”Masterpiece” period drama prepares for its fourth season. After a year in which the series lost the actors Dan Stevens, who played Matthew Crawley, and Jessica Brown Findlay, who played Lady Sybil (for reasons that the “Downton Abbey” creator Julian Fellowes explained here ), PBS announced over the weekend that some new faces would join the series and that a familiar one was returning. But another well-known co-star has also announced her exit.
 
 Shirley MacLaine , who appeared in Season 3 of “Downton Abbey” as Martha Levinson, the outspoken mother of Cora, Countess of Grantham (Elizabeth McGovern), and who served as a foil to the Dowager Countess (Maggie Smith), will return in Season 4, PBS said. Several new actors were announced for the series, including Tom Cullen, whose character, Lord Gillingham, is described as “an old family friend of the Crawleys who visits the family as a guest for a house party”; Harriet Walter who will play Lady Shackleton (“an old friend of the Dowager”); and Julian Ovenden as Charles Blake (an “aristocrat”). The soprano Kiri Te Kanawa will also appear on “Downton Abbey” as “a guest who sings in the house.”

Sylvia Smith — who dropped out of high school at 15, never married, lived most of her life in London rooming houses, never had a great adventure or suffered a great misfortune, and never read books by most accounts — began writing her memoirs in her late 40s, when illness and a government disability pension had allowed her to quit the last of a long series of secretarial jobs, most of them as a temp. 
 
It was an unlikely foundation for a literary career. Just as unlikely was the literary stir she created with her first book, “Misadventures,” published in 2001 when she was 55 after years of work and hundreds of rejection letters.

ELLIMAN--Donald M.,of Westhampton, NY passed away on February 26, four days short of his 101st. birthday. He was born in New York, attended the Choate School and Yale, class of 1934 where he rowed crew, the genesis of a life long passion. He rowed a single shell until he was 99 and introduced many others to the love of the sport. After four years service in the Pacific in WWII, he left the Navy as a Lt. Commander. Returning to banking he rose to be President of the Bank of NY and retired as an EVP at Marine Midland. His first wife Grace preceded him in death. His wife Yvonne of NYC and Westhampton, his sister Barbara of NYC, his daughter Dale Balfour of Owings Mills, MD, his son Donald Jr of Denver, CO, six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren survive him.
PARISH--Dr. Sydney. Born: November 29, 1922. Died: March 1, 2013. "Everybody's Uncle Syd". Will be dearly missed by his friends and family.

Dear Diary:
 
Another storm was approaching when he beckoned for me. Toting a wimpy broom, he stood on the top step of his brownstone – the 10 other steps covered by light coats of snow. His weight shifted onto a cane. He reminded me of the man in East Harlem I’d seen earlier that day. That man sat in his electric wheelchair, one of its motorized wheels caked in mud and spinning like mad, unable to gain traction.

MORRIS--Leonard C. A gentleman on and off the court. Cherished husband of Marilyn (Weiner). Loving and proud father of Elizabeth and Ronald Krinick and Scott Morris. Dearest grandfather of Noah, Alix (Steven) and Jenny. Forever in our hearts. "Goodnight sweet Prince".

NEU--John. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved John L. Neu. John was special. No other word can adequately express the totality of the husband, the entrepreneur, the friend, and the man. Never allowing adversity to write the direction of his life story, John created his own pathway. He did so acknowledging that his life, his mission and his worth were intricately bound to those with whom he shared this path. His generosity of spirit evoked a fierce loyalty in those who knew him best. John made us think, challenged our principles, beliefs and ways of being. He was a true friend who will be greatly missed. His legacy of hard work, frugality, and fairness however will forever live on in our hearts. Irma and Don Redwood

SELIG--Joseph B. New York, NY. October 16, 1926-March 2, 2013. Funeral service to be held on Sunday, March 3rd at 12pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

A small group of academics, business executives and journalists gathered at the M.I.T. Media Lab last Thursday, and the purpose was to toss out ideas and discuss the concept of “Data-Driven Societies.” A daunting topic, ambitious and vague at once, it seems. 
 
Up to now, the focus on the power and implications of Big Data technology has been involved social media, business decision-making and online privacy. Those are big subjects in their own right. So it’s not surprising that the notion of a data-driven society has not been much considered.

NEU--John L.,Our firm expresses its profound sorrow on the passing of our dear friend, John L. Neu. A highly successful businessman, John was an intellectual powerhouse, always eager to analyze and solve knotty problems. John would have had a brilliant legal career had he chosen to stay in practice instead of joining his father, who he loved and respected very much, in business. He grasped very complex legal issues with lightning speed and before you could turn around, John had figured out a creative solution to the issue or problem just presented. We enjoyed seeing the wry smile that came across his face at such moments or when he offered a bon mot. John always demonstrated sincere and kind appreciation for efforts made on his behalf. John, together with his adored wife Wendy, have lived their lives with integrity and a steadfast devotion to promoting the public good and to a multitude of charitable activities. Just as a most recent example, we shall never forget how eager John and Wendy were to help the victims of Superstorm Sandy -- to serve meals, give money for a variety of needed supplies, and enlist the aid of government representatives on their behalf. John's goodness was a blessing to his friends and family, but also to many he never knew. We express our deepest sympathies to Wendy, to all the members of the Neu and Kelman families and to the dedicated employees of Hugo Neu Corporation. Herrick, Feinstein LLP

Samsung Electronics had no new phone to show at Mobile World Congress this week. But it was ubiquitous in Barcelona nonetheless.

BORCK--Charles Alan, passed away suddenly on March 1, 2013 at the age of 87, of Rye, New York and Boca Raton, Florida. Mourned by his loving wife of 62 years Virginia (Ginny) Herson Borck and children Leslie (David) Jameson, Jacquelyn Borck (Howard Brett Cutler), Douglas (Lynn) Borck and devoted grandchildren Jennifer (Connor), Jeffrey (Perri), Adam, Julia, Michael, Noel and Andrea. Alan graduated from RPI in 1946 with a degree in Electrical Engineering and has maintained a long relationship with the school ever since. He was a Founder and President of RLC Electronics, Inc. in Mount Kisco, NY where he continued to be a mentor until his death. "The Chief" lived by the motto "tough but fair." A caring man, Alan's greatest love was Ginny and, of course, their family. An avid sportsman, he had a love of golf, tennis, biking, rollerblading and could frequently be found at the gym. He was a long time member of Community Synagogue of Rye, Quaker Ridge Golf Club and Bocaire Country Club. His passion and generosity will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services to be held at Community Synagogue of Rye at 11:00 o'clock, Monday, March 4. A memorial service will be held in Florida at a later date. Donations in Alan's honor may be made to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180.

Sure, the ratings for the second season of NBC’s “Smash” have been low. The most recent episode fell to 3.3 million total viewers and it barely cleared the 1 million threshold in viewers between the ages of 18 and 49, the demographic most important to advertisers. But DVR viewing was crucial to buoying “Smash” in its first season . Will that be a help this time around? Probably not.
 
The latest DVR numbers released by Nielsen, which include the live ratings plus the next seven days of viewership, revealed that the Season 2 premiere of “Smash,” on Feb. 5, gained only about 900,000 viewers in the 18-to-49 category. That total signifies an increase of 58 percent for the category, a respectable number, but the show did not rank among the Top 25 broadcast programs that increased their audience through DVR usage in either total viewers or adults 18 to 49.

Car sales increased 3.7 percent from February 2012 to last month, according to Autodata, a research firm. Popular vehicles included smaller cars like the Ford Fusion and the Dodge Dart, pickup trucks like G.M.’s Chevrolet Silverado, and S.U.V.’s like Toyota’s RAV4. 
 
A look at Edmunds.com shows what consumers are interested in, or intending to buy. While Honda saw sales drop 2 percent year-over-year in February, and Nissan’s sales fell 6.6 percent, people are reading about its cars: three Hondas, including the Civic, above, were high on the list, along with two Nissan models. SHELLY FREIERMAN

“Bull,” a drama about office politics by the British playwright Mike Bartlett (“The Cockfight Play”), will have its New York premiere in the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, the theater is to announce on Monday. The play, which is to begin performances on April 25, recently completed a run at the Crucible Studio in Sheffield, England, where it received good reviews . Mr. Bartlett’s “ Cockfight Play ” (the actual, monosyllabic title is unprintable here) ran Off Broadway in a well-received, extended run last year. (Ben Brantley of The New York Times included the production on his 2012 Top 10 list .) “Bull” was initially intended as a companion piece to “The Cockfight Play,” Mr. Bartlett said in an interview with The Sheffield Telegraph last month, and both plays were inspired by his experience watching a bullfight in Mexico. But while “Cockfight” is about a love triangle, “Bull” is about the often brutal and bullying world of office politics: Three workers know that one of them is about to be fired, and as they await the arrival of their boss, two gang up on the one who seems to be the weakest of the group. “Bull,” directed by Clare Lizzimore, joins the previously announced Brits festival lineup, which is to include “Good With People,” by David Harrower; “ Bullet Catch ” by Rob Drummond; a revival of J. B. Priestley’s “Cornelius,” starring Alan Cox; and several other productions. The festival runs from March 27 to June 30.

The nation’s biggest banks wrongfully foreclosed on more than 700 military members during the housing crisis and seized homes from roughly two dozen other borrowers who were current on their mortgage payments, findings that eclipse earlier estimates of the improper evictions.

ROBINSON--Robert R.,of Severance, NY and Margate, FL, passed away quietly on March 3, 2013 at the age of 101. Known to family and friends as a Renaissance man, raconteur, standard bearer, and life-long learner. Born in Toronto, Canada to Max and Rose (nee Cohen) in 1912, and raised in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan before moving to New York City as a teen. Graduated cum laude in 1933 from Brooklyn College's first graduating class and retired from the NYC school system in 1973 where he was a dedicated teacher, school principal and Special Assistant to the Superintendent of Schools. Owned and directed Camp Severance for Girls on Paradox Lake in the Adirondack Mountains. Affectionately known as Uncle Bob to hundreds of Severance and Bradley Brook campers and counselors. Enthusiast of travel, photography, nature, the arts and computers. Mourned by his loving and devoted wife of 76 years, Tess Luskin Robinson and cherished children Geraldine (David) Lowe, Stephanie (Charles) Heineman, Brad (Luella) Robinson; his sister Celia Winters and devoted grandchildren Brian (Jody) Lowe, Nina (Scott) Felix, Max (Amy) Heineman, Alex Heineman, Lindsey and Erika Robinson, Greg and Lawrence VanEgdon, and the late Gabriel Robinson, and great-granddaughters Kasey, Jordan, Chase, and Caroline. Funeral services will be held at the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, NY, 11746, Wednesday March 5 at 12 Noon. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Brooklyn College Fund or The Seagle Music Colony in Schroon Lake, NY.

FLOOD--Dr. Anne T.,S.C., On Sunday, March 3. Cherished sister of Jane Flood Clare and Margaret Flood Nolan. Beloved friend of Vincent Hovley, S.J. Devoted daughter of the late Professor Patrick F. and Mary Flood. Anne was predeceased by her brothers Kevin, Robert, Frank, John, Joseph, Michael and Vincent, and sisters Mary Flood Thiry, Sr. Winifred Flood, S.C. and Patricia Flood Breen. She was an honored member of the Sisters of Charity, Mt. St. Vincent, NY. Dr. Flood was an esteemed scholar of ecclesial theology. She is mourned deeply by her numerous nieces and nephews and their families, and by her dear friend, Sr. Philip Dolores, S.C., along with a multitude of friends worldwide. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Convent of Mt. St. Vincent, for the Sisters of Charity in Retirement - Attention: Jane Flood - 22 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, NY 10708. Funeral Mass Wednesday, at 10am at the Immaculate Conception Chapel at the College of Mt. St. Vincent, 6301 Riverdale Ave, Bronx, NY 10471. The family will be present Tuesday 3-8pm at the College. Services by F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc. (914)-375-1400 www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com

Pleasing scenery can punch up a routine run, and one recent Sunday I was treated to a majestic view of the Calvary-St. George’s Episcopal Church at Park Avenue and East 21st Street.
 
This 1848 brownstone beauty , situated just a block from Gramercy Park, is straight out of an Edith Wharton novel. No, really. She belonged to this church, and the Web site claims it was a setting for “The Age of Innocence.” The Roosevelt family worshiped there as well.

KOHN--Immanuel (Ike). The partners, associates and staff of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of Immanuel Kohn (fondly referred to as Ike), our esteemed former chairman, partner, and friend of 60 years. Ike was a strong and effective leader who served for 33 years as a member of Cahill's executive committee and as its chairman for 15 years. Ike was an accomplished lawyer who for many years was a trusted advisor to the Firm's clients and helped the Firm to define and distinguish its practice during an era of dramatic development in the financial and insurance markets. In addition to his law practice at Cahill, he was for many years a Trustee (and, later, Trustee Emeritus) at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, and served on the advisory board of the Princeton Symphony Orchestra. We are proud to have been his partners, friends and colleagues. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Vera, and their four children, Gail Kohn, Peter Kohn and wife Margaret, Sheila Kohn, Robert Kohn and wife Susan Hendrickson, and their six grandchildren, Megan, Emily, Michael, Jason, Sarah and Katherine.

KANNER--Alice H.,Born on August 23, 1931 in Harrison, New York. Devoted and lovely wife of Bernard Kanner, beloved mother of Donna Kanner, Craig Kanner, Pamela Kanner Henry (Edward), and Megan Kanner; doting grandmother to Leigh and Michael McGowan and Sarah, Nicholas, and Anna Henry. After a short illness, she passed away peacefully in Jupiter, Florida on March 2, 2013 surrounded by ones she laughed with, lived for and loved. Alice, a unique person was co-owner of Directions Unlimited, a travel agency in Mt. Kisco, NY before her retirement in 1990. She traveled the world by air and sea enjoying everything she saw. She loved golf and played at two clubs, Jonathan's Landing Golf Club in Jupiter, Florida and Chequessett Neck Golf and Country Club in Wellfleet, Massachusetts. Along with the deep love of her family, Alice had the respect and admiration of many friends. She lived life to the fullest and took in all the world had to offer. A wonderful cook, she enjoyed food, restaurants and experiencing new things. Her family will greatly miss her love and friendship. She will forever be in their hearts. Services will be private.

An article on Feb. 14 about the growing acceptance of public kissing in India referred incorrectly to kissing scenes in Indian films. While they were strongly discouraged by Indian film censors until the 1990s, they were never officially banned, and they did appear in some movies.

Just eight N.F.L. teams used their franchise tags by the Monday afternoon deadline, a steep drop from the 21 players who were tagged last season. The decline is likely an indication that even with a modest rise in the salary cap this year, most teams – many of which have gone on a wave of restructuring contracts in recent days to create cap space — found it too expensive to use the tag on any but the most critical players. This came a year after tag numbers that were reduced from the pre-lockout years were considered more palatable.
 
In the biggest moves, the Kansas City Chiefs, aggressively trying to reshape a 2-14 team into an instant contender, reached a long-term contract with receiver Dwayne Bowe, which allowed them to use the franchise tag on left tackle Branden Albert as the 4 p.m. EST deadline neared. That gives the Chiefs’ new quarterback Alex Smith – who will not be officially join the team until free agency opens next week and his trade goes through – his No. 1 receiver and his top bodyguard. The Chiefs’ decisions could also impact the top of the college draft. Before tagging Albert, the Chiefs were widely expected to use the first overall draft pick on Texas A&M tackle Luke Joeckel. With Albert in the fold, the Chiefs could still take Joeckel and move Albert inside to guard; take a player at another position, like cornerback Dee Milliner; or try to trade down in the draft.

A question-and-answer article on Tuesday about horse meat and the American food supply misstated, in some editions, the number of pounds of meatballs Ikea was withdrawing from sale in 14 European countries. It is 1,670 pounds, not 1.67 billion pounds. The article also misstated, in some editions, the last year that horses were slaughtered in the United States. It was 2007, not 2006.

The injuries that Karen Bartlett suffered after taking a mild pain pill are enough to make anyone squeamish. 
 
Ms. Bartlett, who lives in Plaistow, N.H., developed a rare but severe reaction to the anti-inflammatory drug sulindac after a doctor prescribed it to treat shoulder pain in 2004. Within weeks of taking the drug, her skin began to slough off until nearly two-thirds of it was gone.
