LEWIS--Richard D. Dear good friend, who fought with courage and passion, as was his life, we will miss you. Love you Flo. Honey and the Ellis Family

8:55 p.m. | Updated The Hess truck may be going in a yard sale.
 
Known for its white-and-green gas stations, the Hess Corporation announced on Monday a plan to sell off its retail and refining operations and focus primarily on oil production.

COSTIGAN--J. Peter, October 28, 1924 - March 2, 2013. Loving and beloved husband of Penny for 51 treasured years. Dear uncle of Peter and Mary Carol. Proud veteran of WWII, having enlisted in the Navy immediately after Pearl Harbor, at age 17. Died as he lived, valiantly and bravely. Cremation and interment private, but family and friends are invited to a memorial gathering at Landmarc Tribeca, 179 West Broadway, on Tuesday March 12, from 6 to 8pm. Anchors aweigh, my beautiful sailor boy.

While another collaboration between Stanley Kubrick and Steven Spielberg would seem to require a time machine, a Ouija board or some sort of interdimensional extraterrestrial monolith, plans are nonetheless underway for these two celebrated filmmakers to work together again.
 
 Speaking to Canal+ Television in France , Mr. Spielberg said that he intended to turn an unproduced screenplay by Mr. Kubrick about the life of Napoleon into a television miniseries.

Robert Koehler, who last fall was named the year-round director of programming at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, is resigning that position, the organization said Monday. Taking over for him will be the critic and journalist Dennis Lim. 
 
In a news release, the Film Society said that Mr. Koehler “will step down immediately and return to Los Angeles to focus on personal matters and requests that his family’s privacy be respected.”

Three Off Broadway theaters announced on Monday that their current productions would add performances because of audience demand after positive reviews from critics, while a fourth theater, the Flea, said that its recent and highly praised production of “The Vandal” would return for an encore run later this month.
 
The Flea’s move is relatively unusual. Most theaters simply extend the run of productions to keep going when they prove popular, but “The Vandal” closed on Sunday in order to accommodate the schedules of two of its stars: Deirdre O’Connell has a 10-day film shoot this month, and Noah Robbins has midterms at Columbia, where he is a junior. “The Vandal,” a drama written by the actor Hamish Linklater about three people who come together on a freezing night in upstate New York, will return to the Flea for 11 performances from March 22-31.

KIKIS--Peter T. The Board of Governors, Membership and staff of Deepdale Golf Club note with great sorrow the passing of our former Member of the Board of Governors, Mr. Peter T. Kikis. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

TIDMARSH--Karen M.,Beloved Dean of the College at Bryn Mawr College (1990-2010), died at home in Haverford, PA, March 2, 2013, of carcinoid syndrome. An only child born in Newton, MA, she was 63. After earning a BA from Bryn Mawr in 1971 and a PhD in English from the University of Virginia, she was a Bryn Mawr administrator from 1979 until her death, as well as an English faculty member. Contributions to the Karen Tidmarsh Scholarship can be sent to Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010.

WASHINGTON — In picking Sylvia Mathews Burwell to be his budget director, President Obama on Monday again enlisted a Clinton-era veteran for his economic team as it deals with fiscal and partisan challenges that make the earlier time seem like the good old days.
 
Mr. Obama announced Mrs. Burwell’s nomination, along with his cabinet-level choices for the Energy Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, before an East Room audience. He used the occasion to denounce the across-the-board cuts to military and domestic spending, known as sequestration, which took effect on Friday when he and Republicans in Congress failed to agree on an alternative deficit reduction package.

While a trader known as the “London whale” has come to represent a multibillion-dollar blowup at JPMorgan Chase , Congressional investigators have discovered that the problems involved more senior levels of the nation’s largest bank.
 
A report by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations highlights flaws in the bank’s public disclosures and takes aim at several executives, including Douglas Braunstein, who was chief financial officer at the time of the losses, according to people briefed on the inquiry. The report’s findings — scheduled to be released on March 15 — are expected to fault the executives for allowing JPMorgan to build the bets without fully warning regulators and investors, these people said.

LOS ANGELES — With the mayor’s office up for grabs for the first time in nearly a decade, voters here will go to the polls Tuesday in the first step to choose a successor to Antonio R. Villaraigosa. But the mayoral primary is drawing far less enthusiasm than the election eight years ago, when Mr. Villaraigosa rode a wave of enthusiasm and became the city’s first Latino mayor in more than a century.
 
None of the five candidates is expected to win a majority of votes, making a runoff at the end of May all but certain. Turnout is expected to be very low among the city’s 1.8 million voters.

Yale University announced on Monday the inaugural winners of the Windham Campbell Prizes , which are given to writers for outstanding achievement in fiction, nonfiction and drama. 
 
Nine prizes of $150,000 each are to be awarded to James Salter, Zoë Wicomb and Tom McCarthy in fiction; Jonny Steinberg, Adina Hoffman and Jeremy Scahill in nonfiction; and Naomi Wallace, Stephen Adly Guirgis and Tarell Alvin McCraney in drama.

MEXICO CITY — The giant Monterrey glass maker Vitro said Monday that it had reached an agreement with bondholders, ending a dispute among powerful financiers that had ricocheted between Mexican and American courts.
 
Under the agreement, Fintech, which is owned by the Monterrey-born investor David Martinez, will buy the bonds held by a group of hedge funds and pay additional cash to cover legal fees. In return, Fintech will receive a 13 percent stake in a Vitro subsidiary and a $235 million note issued by the subsidiary.

ELLIMAN--Donald M.,of Westhampton, NY passed away on February 26, four days short of his 101st. birthday. He was born in New York, attended the Choate School and Yale, class of 1934 where he rowed crew, the genesis of a life long passion. He rowed a single shell until he was 99 and introduced many others to the love of the sport. After four years service in the Pacific in WWII, he left the Navy as a Lt. Commander. Returning to banking he rose to be President of the Bank of NY and retired as an EVP at Marine Midland. His first wife Grace preceded him in death. His wife Yvonne of NYC and Westhampton, his sister Barbara of NYC, his daughter Dale Balfour of Owings Mills, MD, his son Donald Jr of Denver, CO, six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren survive him.

WASSERMAN--Richard E.,age 77, of Ossining, NY, died early Sunday morning, March 3rd, 2013. He suffered from frontotemporal dementia. Dick graduated from Duke in 1957. In his mid 50s, he bravely left his career as an advertising copywriter to pursue his love of psychology, earning an MSW at Yeshiva University. He was a practicing psychotherapist into his early 70s, when he was diagnosed with dementia. Richard was the loving husband of Barbara (Krohn), and father of Carrie Brooke, MD. His wit and good humor will be missed by his extended family and many friends. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

An obituary on Sunday about Dr. Jane C. Wright, a pioneering oncologist, misstated part of the name of an organization she helped start. It is the American Society of Clinical Oncology (not Oncologists). The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

KOENIGSBERG--Beverly Feit, of San Diego, CA, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, East Windsor, NJ, Denver, CO, and Naples, FL, died on March 1, 2013. Born July 16, 1943, the daughter of Max and Rose Feit, Beverly is survived by her husband of 50 years, Alan, and children Lori (Jordan Steiker), Jason Koenigsberg (Ana) and four grandchildren- Blake, Aaron, Eliza and Max; her brother, Ira Feit (Lisa), sister-in-law Harriet (Gerard Rosenberg) and four nephews. She graduated from Brooklyn College (AB) and the University of Denver (MSW). She was a passionate addictions therapist who loved facilitating recovery in fellowship and practice. The world is much less interesting without her. Services will be held at Congregation Beth Chaim, Princeton Junction, NJ on Tuesday, March 5 at 1pm.

SHAW--Dr. Samuel E.,69, died on March 3, 2013, of complications from advanced Parkinson's disease. For all who knew him, Sam created cherished memories filled with love and humor. He lived with honor and enriched the lives of those he knew and loved. Sam carried in his wallet is list that he created entitled "Goals for Life" which best exemplifies his exceptional nature. These are the goals by which he lived each day: 1. Live with honor 2. Raise decent children 3. Be proud of yourself 4. Help your fellow man 5. Enjoy sports, the outdoors, reading and music 6. Be loving towards your wife 7. Be loving towards your parents 8. Make an effort at work 9. Maximize your investment 10. Earn the respect of others 11. Allow yourself to be happy. Sam earned a PhD in Political Science in 1971 at the City University of New York and went on to become a successful and respected financial analyst at Standard & Poor's. He leaves behind a legacy of a life filled with beloved family and life-long friends. He is survived by his loving wife and best friend Carol, daughter Ruth, son Stephen, son-in-law Luis, daughter-in-law Tiffany and grandson Alexander. Sam is also survived by his cherished parents, Margorie and Leo and his beloved brother Spencer. He will be greatly missed by both the Shaw and Coopersmith families, whose lives he so deeply touched. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation or the National Parkinson's Disease Foundation. Funeral service will be held 11:30am on Wednesday March 6th, at the Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ 07601 www.guttermanand musicant.com.

An article on Friday about the dismissal of Groupon’s chief executive misstated the company’s valuation at its initial public offering in 2011. The company’s offering valued the company at $12.65 billion — not at $16.5 billion, which was its valuation after the first day of trading.

BRUSSELS — The British finance minister, George Osborne, is expected Tuesday to urge his European Union counterparts to water down proposed rules restricting the size of bankers’ bonuses.
 
The proposal is a sore point for Britain, which is home to Europe’s main financial hub, and where many in government and the financial industry worry that mandated limit to bonuses could make it harder for London to compete in international banking circles.

LEBER--Marion,Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst mourns the passing of our longtime member Marion Leber. We extend condolences to her husband Steven and to the entire Leber family. Rabbi Sholom Stern Richard Holland, President

Melanie M. Canon, a family doctor who lives and works in East Harlem, happened upon the scene last Thursday moments after a 6-year-old boy, Amar Diarrassouba, was struck by a turning truck and tried to save his life. She sent us this account. 
 
Last Thursday morning, after dropping my 8-year-old daughter at school in East Harlem, I got back on my bike and headed home. I am a daily bike commuter, as is my daughter, and have been doing the same loop for years. I know the streets and the crossing guards. I pass the same kids walking to school with their grandmothers year after year. I smile, ring my bell or wave, “Hi, Ma.” In this daily ritual we become community.

A picture caption on Monday with a television review of “The Staircase 2: Last Chance” on the Sundance Channel, about a murder case in North Carolina, misspelled the defendant’s surname. As the review correctly noted, he is Michael Peterson, not Petersen.

Hammond--Peter. Born July 19, 1941. Died at home March 4 after bravely fighting cancer for six and a half years. Predeceased by dad Harold (1974) & mom Miriam (2006). He lived life to the fullest. Great Neck native. NYU alumnus. US Army veteran. Pioneer of electronic retail. Also lived in London and Clearwater. Husband of Suzie; father of Jamie & Charlotte, David & Jennifer and Alex; grandfather of Max, Benji, Jacob, Aliza, Mica and Helena; and brother of Barbara & Leslie Dubs. Service 11am today, Curlew Hills, Palm Harbor, FL. Shiva: Belleair Bluffs, FL Tuesday, Wednesday; Armonk, NY Thursday, Friday. Memorial donations: Temple Ahavot Shalom in Palm Harbor or Suncoast Hospice.

REICHER--Molly Dorfman, 100, of Cedarhurst, New York, died peacefully, surrounded by her family, on March 2, 2013. Devoted wife of the late Morris J. Reicher, loving mother of Jacqueline (Barry) Montag and Georgene (Steve) Winick, adored grandmother of Alan, Jason, Avi, Jennifer, and Matthew, cherished great-grandmother of Amanda, Savannah, Michael, Cole, Nathan, and Cade. A true woman of valor, beloved by all whose lives she touched.

TAMPA, Fla. — Mark Teixeira injured his wrist while working out with the United States team Tuesday in Arizona ahead of the World Baseball Classic, leaving the Yankees worried about his status.

New features from Rachel Boynton, Laurie Collyer and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason are among the 46 works announced on Tuesday for the 2013 Tribeca Film Festival, which unveiled its selections for the competitive world narrative and documentary categories, as well as its noncompetitive Viewpoints series.
 
“Big Men,” written and directed by Ms. Boynton (“Our Brand Is Crisis”), will make its world premiere on April 18, the opening film of Tribeca’s world documentary feature lineup. In a news release, “Big Men” was described as an “industrial exposé” for which Ms. Boynton “gained unprecedented access to Africa’s oil companies” to produce “a gripping account of the costly personal tolls levied when American corporate interests pursue oil in places like Ghana and the Niger River Delta.”

It takes just two good recipes for a new cookbook to earn a place on my shelf. But which recipes to try first? In Recipe Lab, a new monthly online feature, I make the book’s author choose its essential recipes for us. I’ll select one for you, our readers, to make at home. As you cook — or even if you don’t — you’ll be able to post comments and questions for the author here on Diner’s Journal. The author will then join me, and three of you, in a live video chat that everyone can watch. 
 
First up: Nigella Lawson and her new book, “Nigellissima: Easy Italian-Inspired Recipes” (Clarkson Potter, $35). It is Ms. Lawson’s ninth book, and all of them are larded with recipes for pasta and tiramisù. But this one is wholly Italian, if not authentically so, as she quickly admits. “I don’t want to be the English person telling everyone what Italians eat,” she said.

Mark Bittman’s column on Thursday incorrectly described findings from a recent epidemiological study of the relationship of sugar consumption to diabetes. The study found that increased sugar in a population’s food supply was linked to higher rates of diabetes — independent of obesity rates — but stopped short of stating that sugar caused diabetes. It did not find that “obesity doesn’t cause diabetes: sugar does.” Obesity is, in fact, a major risk factor for Type 2 diabetes, as the study noted.

John Flores was the one who spotted the spot. “Somebody painted red on the blue door,” he said.
 
John, a 14-year-old ninth grader, had a paint brush and a mission: to bring a bright new color scheme to his school, the Bronx Design and Construction Academy on East 151st Street in the Melrose section of the South Bronx. And the color on his brush was “Rocky Mountain sky,” an arresting color that blended easily with a palette created by the renowned designer Massimo Vignelli.

Consistent fourth-place finishes by the Mets are not helping finances at Citi Field.
 
The ballpark’s latest financial statements show some of the effects of faltering attendance. Last season, the Mets averaged 28,035 a game, down nearly 7 percent from the 2011 season.

The actress Amanda Peet will get her first professional credit as a playwright next season when Manhattan Theater Club stages “The Commons of Pensacola,” her work about a family grappling with the fallout from the financial crisis.
 
Neither a date nor a theater for the premiere has been set, nor has the rest of the theater’s season. But Mandy Greenfield, the company’s artistic producer, described the work as “thrilling,” adding that Lynne Meadow, its artistic director, has been working closely with Ms. Peet on the script. Ms. Meadow will direct the production.

An obituary on Tuesday about the physicist Donald A. Glaser misidentified an organic compound that was the first liquid he used in the bubble chamber, the invention for which he won the Nobel Prize . It was diethyl ether, not diethyl ester. And because of an editing error, the obituary referred incorrectly to the college from which Dr. Glaser received his bachelor’s degree. It was the Case School of Applied Science, which later became part of Case Western Reserve University; he did not receive his degree from “what became the Case Western University.”

An article on Tuesday about efforts to allow consumers to unlock their cellphones, and thus be able to take the phones with them when they change carriers, misstated the year the Digital Millennium Copyright Act was passed. It was 1998, not 1988.

KOHN--Immanuel (Ike). The partners, associates and staff of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of Immanuel Kohn (fondly referred to as Ike), our esteemed former chairman, partner, and friend of 60 years. Ike was a strong and effective leader who served for 33 years as a member of Cahill's executive committee and as its chairman for 15 years. Ike was an accomplished lawyer who for many years was a trusted advisor to the Firm's clients and helped the Firm to define and distinguish its practice during an era of dramatic development in the financial and insurance markets. In addition to his law practice at Cahill, he was for many years a Trustee (and, later, Trustee Emeritus) at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, and served on the advisory board of the Princeton Symphony Orchestra. We are proud to have been his partners, friends and colleagues. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Vera, and their four children, Gail Kohn, Peter Kohn and wife Margaret, Sheila Kohn, Robert Kohn and wife Susan Hendrickson, and their six grandchildren, Megan, Emily, Michael, Jason, Sarah and Katherine.

LOEWENSTEIN--Ruth, died at home on March 4, 2013 at the age of 81. The only child of German refugees, Ruth arrived in the United States from El Salvador as a young girl. Always fiercely independent, she traveled the world and in retirement became an accomplished bridge player. She loved books, theater and good restaurants. A report in the Observatory column on Feb. 26 about the resignation of a social anthropologist from the National Academy of Sciences referred incorrectly to criticisms of Napoleon A. Chagnon’s research on an Amazon tribe. Some criticism of the research has in fact appeared in peer-reviewed journals; it is not the case, as Dr. Chagnon said, that no such journals published the criticism.

Any discussion of barbecue is likely to become an argument. Why should a discussion of what to drink with it be different? 
 
Beer is wonderful; I gravitate to Shiner Bock from my days in Austin, Tex., but any good porter or pilsner would do. I recall an argument (I mean discussion) with the restaurateur Danny Meyer, and we agreed in the end that Champagne was perfect with barbecue, as long as you steer clear of overly sweet sauce, which you should do anyway. For brisket (again, my Texas bias), I also suggest a red wine with firm acidity and a touch of smoke to echo the meat. I’d reach for a Chianti, one that emphasizes the dusty, smoky fruit of the sangiovese grape and has no oaky flavors.

A star-studded battle among hedge fund titans over the nutritional supplements company Herbalife became the talk of Wall Street when it erupted. But when the barbs eventually fall silent and the klieg lights dim, how will the Herbalife war end? And what truth will emerge?
 
The arrival of the hedge fund billionaires — William A. Ackman, Daniel S. Loeb and Carl C. Icahn — spawned a media circus. And at times, some investors acted as if they were the stars of a reality-TV show. Yet blustering and bluffing are what traders do, after all.

KELLEY--Brooks Mather, 83, a resident of Guilford, CT, for thirty-two years, died at Yale-New Haven Hospital on February 14, 2013. The cause was multi-system failure. He was born on August 18, 1929, in Lake Forest, Illinois, the son of Phelps and Mary Cotton Kelley. He attended Deerfield Academy and, afterward, served a year in the Army. He entered Yale College and graduated with a B.A. in 1953. While at Yale, he was a member of the secret society Book and Snake. Following a year with Price Waterhouse in Chicago, he enrolled at the University of Chicago, where he received his M.A. in 1956 and his Ph.D. in 1961. He was a Lecturer in History at Illinois Institute of Technology 1956-57. He was an Instructor at Yale 1961-64, Assistant Professor, 1964-67, Curator of Historical Manuscripts and University Archivist, 1964-66. He was, variously, Lecturer, Research Associate, and Research Affiliate at Yale from 1967 to 2007. He was the author of "Yale, A History," published by the Yale University Press in 1974 and reissued in paperback in 1998. Also in 1974 the New Haven Preservation Trust published his brief study, "New Haven Heritage: An Area of Historic Houses on Hillhouse Avenue and Trumbull Street." He was co-author with Daniel J. Boorstin of the much-lauded high school textbook, "A History of the United States," published first (1980) by Ginn and Company and subsequently by Pearson-Prentice Hall. It went through many editions, most recently in 2007 as part of a new series called Prentice Hall Classics. He was also editor, with Boorstin, of "Perspectives; Readings on American History in the 20th Century" (1992). He served as historical consultant to the television series "Freedom to Speak," based on the ideas and course of Yale history professor Rollin G. Osterweis, hosted by William F. Buckley, Jr., and produced by WQED/Pittsburgh in 1983. He was also a consultant in Modern European History for "The Random House Dictionary of the English Language," second edition, unabridged, 1987. In 1956, he married Jean Russell. That marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his sister, Cynthia K. McGrath, his wife of 32 years, Suzanne Gray, and by his sons John Hutchinson (Bonny) and Todd Russell, and by his stepchildren, John and Elizabeth Burbank, and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brother, Phelps Cotton, and his son Brooks Russell Kelley. He served on the boards and as an officer of a number of nonprofit organizations: The New Haven Colony Historical Society (now Museum), The New Haven Preservation Trust, ISIS, The Foote School, and Connecticut Fund for the Environment. He loved to travel and with Suzanne visited all the continents and a large number of countries. Among his favorite journeys was traveling from Vladivostok to Moscow by private train just after the collapse of the Soviet Union and voyaging, also by train, from Beijing to Moscow following the route of the old Silk Road much of the way. Two of their trips took them around the world. He also loved to sail and skied into his 80's, active as he liked to say in nine different decades. There will be a memorial reception for Brooks held at the Graduate Club at 155 Elm Street in New Haven on March 9 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Connecticut Fund for the Environment, 142 Temple Street, 3rd floor, New Haven, CT 06510 or to The Kelley Memorial Fund at the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven, 70 Audubon Street, New Haven, CT 06510.

NICHOLSON--Ronald A. Born February 9, 1928. Died at home February 26 from complications of liver cancer. Predeceased by his mother and father, Ethel (Alfond) and Max Nicholson. A consummate story-teller. Lived big with quiet reserve. Quintessential negotiator-dispassionate, analytical and fair. Zealot fan. Thoroughbred owner and breeder. City Journal chronicled poker-playing aficionado. Loved his family and his country. Loyal to a fault. Will be missed only when those who love him can consciously accept his absence. For now we all still hear his laughter. Survived in sadness by his significant other and wife of forty plus years, Pat (Emsworth-Rodgers) and son, Justin, as well as daughter and son Leslie and James by his first marriage to the former Susan Zeckendorf. Ron was an adoring grandfather to Madeleine, Eric, Alison and Scott Goldstein; Amanda, David and Michael Nicholson; a caring older brother to Alfred (Pete); a beloved uncle to his nieces and nephews and a trusted and respected extended family member, friend and colleague. Cremation and burial private. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Wednesday, March 13, 2013 at 3:30pm. Family will receive visitors immediately following the memorial service at the residence of Pat Nicholson, 1016 Fifth Avenue (entrance on 83rd Street), apartment 15A. In lieu of flowers, Ron would revel in knowing you sent your contribution in his name to Wounded Warrior Project, PO Box 758517, Topeka, KS 66675.

A municipal court in Prague on Tuesday acquitted the lead singer of the heavy metal band Lamb of God of causing a teenage fan’s death at a concert in the Czech Republic, The Associated Press reported. A court spokeswoman, Marketa Puci, said that the court had ruled that what Mr. Blythe did was not a crime and that the concert organizers were to blame for the incident.
 
The singer, Randy Blythe, 42, was charged in December with causing bodily harm to another person with lethal consequences. He stood accused of pushing a 19-year-old man from the stage during a 2010 concert at Prague’s Abaton club. The man later died of a head injury. Mr. Blythe pleaded not guilty, saying the fan’s death was an accident that had happened in a confused scuffle after several fans broke through barricades and rushed the stage. The singer had faced five years in prison if convicted; prosecutors said they would appeal the verdict.

An article on Saturday about differing views among residents of McComb, Miss., about a law that requires their state and eight others to obtain federal approval for voting changes referred incorrectly to the history of blacks who represented Mississippi in Congress. The state had three black congressmen during Reconstruction; it is not the case that the state “did not have a black representative in Congress until 1986.”

Gary Gensler , one of the top regulators of Wall Street, is assuring officials that he plans to remain in the Obama administration through at least December even as he weighs other options, according to three people briefed on the matter.
 
The White House approached Mr. Gensler in January about serving a second five-year term as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission , the people said. While Mr. Gensler has yet to commit to a second term, and has no deadline to respond, he is considering staying.

With the Mariinsky Ballet’s “Swan Lake,” Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” and a weeklong hip-hop festival, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington is offering a mix of classics and contemporary pop culture in its 2013-2014 season. 
 
Programming for the capital’s art center includes more than 2,000 performances of dance, theater and music, Michael M. Kaiser, the center’s president, announced. Some highlights include a revival of Henry Krieger and Bill Russell’s “Side Show” ; an international theater festival with productions of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” from the Old Vic in Britain and “The Suit” from France’s Théâtre des Bouffes du Nord , directed by Peter Brook and Marie-Hélène Estienne; the National Symphony Orchestra’s birthday salutes to Richard Strauss; and a concert version of “Der Rosenkavalier” featuring Renée Fleming.

To Read: Vegetables the French Way

 
The Michelin three-star chef Alain Passard made his mark by offering vegetable tasting menus at Arpège, his restaurant in Paris. Now, with “The Art of Cooking with Vegetables” (Frances Lincoln, $29.95), he offers 100 vegetable-centric recipes, many of them original and inventive, and all illustrated with his own collages. Consider eggplant with a suave onion curry purée, a pumpkin soup green with herbs, and ratatouille with cooked and raw vegetables, illustrated at right. A number of dishes are monochromatic, like purple carrots with purple basil or beets with red onions. A dessert soufflé is made with avocado and chocolate. The recipes are clear and mostly easy to follow, though some ingredients, like white tomatoes, might require a trip to Rungis, not Union Square.

BRUSSELS — Europe’s antitrust regulators are preparing to deliver a strong message: a deal is a deal, and if a company fails to live up to a settlement agreement, there will be consequences.
 
On Wednesday, the European Union is expected to impose a large fine on Microsoft for failing to give users of the company’s Windows software a choice of Internet browsers. It would be the first time that European regulators had punished a company for neglecting to comply with the terms of an antitrust settlement, and it could signal a tougher approach to enforcing deals in other antitrust cases, including one involving Google .

Justin Bieber, who usually enjoys an adulation bordering on worship among his fans, was forced to apologize on Tuesday to concertgoers and their angry parents after he took the stage almost two hours late for a show at the 02 Arena in London, The Associated Press reported .
 
In a message on Twitter, the singer said he was only 40 minutes late in starting the show and vaguely blamed “technical issues” for the delay. “There is no excuse for that and I apologize for anyone we upset,” he said.

A music review on Tuesday about the George London Competition for singers, at the Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan, misstated the surname of the bass who sang “Aleko’s Cavatina” by Rachmaninoff. He is Ben Wager, not Wagner.

An article on Tuesday about an agreement between the Mexican glass maker Vitro and its bondholders referred incorrectly to a debt agreement involving another Mexican company, Cemex. Cemex promised debtholders that “it would not grant subsidiaries or related-party creditors the same rights as bondholders.” It did not make that promise to debtors.

The third annual marathon run in Gaza, set for April 10, was canceled after its Islamic leaders barred women from participating, the organizer said.

Is there a restaurant dish that haunts you? Something that makes your mouth water and your stomach growl whenever you start to describe its manifold charms? A dish you’d love to have the recipe for if it were readily available?
 
This week we’re introducing Restaurant Takeaway, a new feature devoted to restaurant food you can make at home that will appear regularly here on Diner’s Journal. I’ll offer recipes, tweaked and tested with home cooks in mind, for dishes that transcend the sum of their parts and leave you wondering how exactly the chef managed to make something as simple as bread, broccoli, cheese and garlic taste so sublime.

Marie Howe, the state poet for New York and the author of such books as “What the Living Do,” specializes in vibrant, bracing, haunting work that stops you in your tracks. Ms. Howe, 62, lives in Manhattan; she spoke about the lyrical and occasionally comic role food has played in her life.
 
What she consumes between visits from the muse “I just eat almond butter and apples. All day. You slice apples really thin, like paper, and you just smear the almond butter on. I don’t eat when I write. I take breaks, and I go have my apple and almond butter.”
Michael Arad, designer of the National September 11 Memorial, looks for simple colorful blocks.

Preservation groups say some of the buildings, which are for sale or being considered for sale, are architecturally significant and that their design elements and historic features should be protected.
“The Silence” begins with the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl; 23 years later, it happens again in an eerily precise duplicate.
The education department responds to a discrimination complaint filed with the D.C. Office for Civil Rights.
“Electrick Children,” written and directed by Rebecca Thomas, is a coming-of-age fable about two teenagers from a fundamentalist Mormon family in southern Utah.
Based on a Gothic thriller, “The Monk” traces the downfall of a sternly pious monk.
In “Dead Man Down,” a thug with a secret past squares off with a disfigured woman seeking revenge for an attack.

Sonos is no longer ignoring the TV. The company’s new Playbar begins shipping Tuesday, allowing customers to improve the sound of their televisions while also connecting them to Sonos speakers throughout the house.
 
The 35-inch-long speaker will be familiar to those who know Sonos’s other products. It is sleek and easy to set up, and the sound is loud and clear. Like other Sonos products, it is best controlled through the company’s smartphone and tablet apps, but the volume can also be controlled through the television’s own remote. The speaker costs $700 and also requires a bridge that connects to a wireless router.

KELLEY--Brooks Mather, 83, a resident of Guilford, CT, for thirty-two years, died at Yale-New Haven Hospital on February 14, 2013. The cause was multi-system failure. He was born on August 18, 1929, in Lake Forest, Illinois, the son of Phelps and Mary Cotton Kelley. He attended Deerfield Academy and, afterward, served a year in the Army. He entered Yale College and graduated with a B.A. in 1953. While at Yale, he was a member of the secret society Book and Snake. Following a year with Price Waterhouse in Chicago, he enrolled at the University of Chicago, where he received his M.A. in 1956 and his Ph.D. in 1961. He was a Lecturer in History at Illinois Institute of Technology 1956-57. He was an Instructor at Yale 1961-64, Assistant Professor, 1964-67, Curator of Historical Manuscripts and University Archivist, 1964-66. He was, variously, Lecturer, Research Associate, and Research Affiliate at Yale from 1967 to 2007. He was the author of "Yale, A History," published by the Yale University Press in 1974 and reissued in paperback in 1998. Also in 1974 the New Haven Preservation Trust published his brief study, "New Haven Heritage: An Area of Historic Houses on Hillhouse Avenue and Trumbull Street." He was co-author with Daniel J. Boorstin of the much-lauded high school textbook, "A History of the United States," published first (1980) by Ginn and Company and subsequently by Pearson-Prentice Hall. It went through many editions, most recently in 2007 as part of a new series called Prentice Hall Classics. He was also editor, with Boorstin, of "Perspectives; Readings on American History in the 20th Century" (1992). He served as historical consultant to the television series "Freedom to Speak," based on the ideas and course of Yale history professor Rollin G. Osterweis, hosted by William F. Buckley, Jr., and produced by WQED/Pittsburgh in 1983. He was also a consultant in Modern European History for "The Random House Dictionary of the English Language," second edition, unabridged, 1987. In 1956, he married Jean Russell. That marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his sister, Cynthia K. McGrath, his wife of 32 years, Suzanne Gray, and by his sons John Hutchinson (Bonny) and Todd Russell, and by his stepchildren, John and Elizabeth Burbank, and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brother, Phelps Cotton, and his son Brooks Russell Kelley. He served on the boards and as an officer of a number of nonprofit organizations: The New Haven Colony Historical Society (now Museum), The New Haven Preservation Trust, ISIS, The Foote School, and Connecticut Fund for the Environment. He loved to travel and with Suzanne visited all the continents and a large number of countries. Among his favorite journeys was traveling from Vladivostok to Moscow by private train just after the collapse of the Soviet Union and voyaging, also by train, from Beijing to Moscow following the route of the old Silk Road much of the way. Two of their trips took them around the world. He also loved to sail and skied into his 80's, active as he liked to say in nine different decades. There will be a memorial reception for Brooks held at the Graduate Club at 155 Elm Street in New Haven on March 9 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Connecticut Fund for the Environment, 142 Temple Street, 3rd floor, New Haven, CT 06510 or to The Kelley Memorial Fund at the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven, 70 Audubon Street, New Haven, CT 06510.

SCHAUER--Andrew Mark, of Denver, Colorado died at his home in Hermosa Beach, California Wednesday, February 27, 2013. Born July 12, 1966, to Irving and Francine Schauer, he received a degree in philosophy from Colgate University in 1989. He went on to receive his JD from New York University in 1992 and started his career at Debevoise & Plimpton before co-founding Jin, Schauer & Saad, LLC in Denver, Colorado. He is survived by his wife, Susan, and his daughter, Soren. Funeral services were held on Sunday, March 3. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be made to the OneLegacy Foundation.

An article last Thursday about sexual fetishes that are being discussed more openly as a result of the “Fifty Shades of Grey” novels misstated the name of a Harvard student social group focusing on such practices. It is the Harvard College Munch, not the Harvard Munch Club.
An article on Feb. 21 about the Tucson Gem, Mineral and Fossil Showcase referred incorrectly to a mineral deposit found in England. It is fluorite — not fluoride, which is a compound.

“Adventures of Superman,” a digital anthology from DC Comics, is scheduled to begin on April 29. But it will not feature the work of Chris Sprouse, an artist who has decided to drop out of the project because of a controversy surrounding the opposition to gay marriage by the novelist Orson Scott Card, one of the writers.
 
Mr. Sprouse’s resignation, which came on Tuesday, followed weeks of growing consternation by some fans and retailers after the announcement from DC in early February that included Mr. Card among the creative teams. In a statement provided by DC Comics, Mr. Sprouse said: “It took a lot of thought to come to this conclusion, but I’ve decided to step back as the artist on this story. The media surrounding this story reached the point where it took away from the actual work, and that’s something I wasn’t comfortable with.”

Ghostly vestiges of the gothic Herald Tribune logo still survive on the eastern facade of 230 West 41st Street in Midtown Manhattan, camouflaged by a faded Group Health Insurance emblem, and, more recently, dwarfed by the towering headquarters of The New York Times next door.
 
This fall, when The International Herald Tribune is rebranded as The International New York Times, that pallid logo atop The Trib’s former home may become the most visible remaining legacy of one of the great names of American journalism.

New movies from Richard Linklater, Neil Jordan, David Gordon Green, Mira Nair, Neil LaBute and Clark Gregg; and documentaries about Elaine Stritch, Richard Pryor, Gore Vidal and –  from Whoopi Goldberg — Moms Mabley  were among the latest announced for the Tribeca Film Festival by its organizers on Wednesday.
 
The 33 features that will be presented in the festival’s Spotlight series include: “Before Midnight,” the latest entry in Mr. Linklater’s romantic series starring Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke; “Byzantium,” a new film about creatures of the night from Mr. Jordan (“Interview With the Vampire”) and starring Gemma Arterton and Saoirse Ronan; Mr. Green’s “Prince Avalanche,” a road comedy set in the summer of 1988, starring Paul Rudd and Emile Hirsch; Ms. Nair’s adaptation of “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” based on the Mohsin Hamid novel; “Some Velvet Morning,” a new drama by Mr. LaBute starring Stanley Tucci and Alice Eve; and “Trust Me,” a Hollywood satire directed by and starring Mr. Gregg (“Choke,” “The Avengers”) as a bumbling talent agent.

An article in some editions on Saturday about the racecar driver Kyle Larson, whose Asian heritage could help Nascar develop a new following, misidentified the ethnicity of his mother, Janet. She is Japanese-American, not Japanese.

Software updates often bring changes like new menus, commands and keyboard shortcuts to Microsoft Office programs — and these new elements can temporarily slow down even the most experienced users of Word, Excel and PowerPoint. To help get its customers up to speed with the latest release, Microsoft has colorful “quick start” guides for all the programs in the Office suite at bit.ly/T9cQIu .
 
Along with information for Word 2013, Excel 2013, PowerPoint 2013 and Outlook 2013, the page also includes 2013 quick-start guides for less common programs in the Office suite like Access, OneNote, Project, Publisher and Visio. Available in the PDF format and free to download and print, each guide is about five to nine pages depending on the program and covers the changes made to the software from the previous edition. Tips for using the program are included, as is compatibility advice for working with people who do not have Office 2013.

FRIEDMAN--E. Judith, On February 28, 2012 at the age of 87. Born on March 21, 1925 in Frankfurt, Germany, the daughter of Siegfried and Helene Salomon. Devoted wife of Emanuel Friedman, MD, loving mother to the late Lynn Friedman and her husband John Crothers, Meryl Ruth and her husband Alfred Wolff, and Lee Friedman and his wife Leslie. Cherished grandmother of six and great grandmother of three. Judith ("Judy" to all who knew her) was a graduate of Brooklyn College and held Master's degrees in Statistics and Library Science. She worked for many years as a Research Librarian in Boston and New York City. Judy loved opera, literature, and travel, and she was active in many charities. The Friedmans wish to express their gratitude to the staff at NYU Medical Center and NY-Presbyterian Hospital for their care and support. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street in Manhattan, March 10, 2013, at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Judy's name to your favorite charity.
LEARY--Thomas. In loving memory of our son, brother, soon-to-be uncle and friend. You are always in our hearts.

The Dyson AM05 bladeless fan and heater is much cooler than its predecessor. Its new motor spins 33 percent faster, moving more air, hence: cooler.
 
The company said it has redesigned the impeller of the combination fan and space heater so that it now moves air more quietly and in greater quantities.

An article on Feb. 8 about the 45th anniversary of the Orangeburg Massacre, a tragic episode in the history of political activism by black athletes, described incorrectly the three black students shot and killed by state troopers while protesting the segregationist policy of a bowling alley. Two were South Carolina State students and one was a high school student; the three were not all from the college.

An article on Tuesday about European proposals on banking rules misspelled the given name of the finance minister of Cyprus, who cautioned against taking too aggressive a regulatory stance, and a correction in this space on Wednesday also misspelled the name in some copies. He is Michalis Sarris — not Michaelis or Machalis.

KAPLAN--Claudette S, Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., is deeply saddened by the passing of our Guardian of the Dream donor, beloved mother of Alan Josef Kaplan, Laurie Kaplan Steen and David Michael Kaplan and cherished grandmother. Claudia was devoted to her family, and carried this passion to her work on behalf of Hadassah. Mrs. Kaplan was truly a woman of valor that inspired all of us. May her memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marcie Natan, National President
A dual review of what’s new.

As Western Digital expands its effort to link your devices and the content stored on them, it has set its sights on the gadget that dominates the living room: the TV.
 
With its WD TV Play streaming media player , Western Digital is going head to head with some big competitors. Its media player offers about 30 apps, including popular ones like Netflix and YouTube, but this is hardly enough to compete with powerhouses like Roku, which offers hundreds of apps, and Apple TV, which has fewer than a dozen but provides content via iTunes.

An article on Tuesday about a Supreme Court case that weighs the liability of generic drug makers described incorrectly the Food and Drug Administration’s efforts in 2005 to strengthen warning labels on nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (Nsaids). It recommended that manufacturers specifically list the risk of skin reactions; it did not require manufacturers to list that risk, as it had no authority to do so.

BUCHMAN--Sidney, of Plainview, Long Island, died on Monday night, March 4th, 2013. Beloved husband for 59 years of Marilyn Buchman, father of Elissa Buchman Broad, Ronnie Buchman Schonzeit, and Sharon Buchman. Beloved brother of Nat. Zayde of Ilana, Sarah and Benjamin Broad, Gabriel, Miriam, Jeremy, Yael, and Jacob Schonzeit. Sidney was a founding member of Temple Beth Torah in Westbury, Long Island. Sidney was a career pharmacist. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Union Mutual Foundation. He was a veteran of the 101st Airborne Signal Company of the Army Air Corps, defending our country in Germany from 1944-1946. He enjoyed first and foremost his family and friends, photography, Yiddish culture, theater, music, reading, and a hot cup of mushroom barley soup. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth Torah, 243 Cantiague Rock Road, Westbury NY, at 10:30am on Thursday, March 7th.

In 1952, when Gaby Aghion, a wealthy Parisian by way of Egypt, founded Chloé, her breezily feminine designs, freer and less formal than was common in postwar fashion, quickly became a favorite of the boho-chic. For spring, the company is continuing its 60th-anniversary celebration by reissuing 16 styles that express the whimsical essence of the line. Included is a soft silk crepe blouse designed by Ms. Aghion in 1960; the very rock ’n’ roll black-and-gold cutout dress with a violin motif designed by Karl Lagerfeld in 1983; Stella McCartney’s pineapple T-shirt from 2001; and the kind-of-daffy high-waist jeans (2004), Paddington “it” bag (2005) and chunky wedge sandals (2006) from Phoebe Philo’s reign as designer at the house. They are at Barneys New York and Net-a-Porter this week and at Chloé boutiques on Monday. Prices range from $300 to $34,275 (that would be a croc Paddington).

The City Room column in some editions on Saturday about the growth of St. Pat’s for All, a parade started in Queens in 2000 to include gay groups excluded from other St. Patrick’s Day parades, misstated the surname of the husband of a founder, Brendan Fay. He is Tom Moulton, not Moulter. And because of an editing error, the article misidentified the neighborhood where the parade route begins. It is Sunnyside, not neighboring Woodside.

GLADSTONE--William. The Board of Governors & Members of Falls Golf & Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member William Gladstone. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Roslyn and their family. Leonard Sloan, President

Q.

 
Do I have to use the Apple Bluetooth keyboard with an Apple TV, or can I get a cheaper one instead?

A theater review on Wednesday about “Talley’s Folly,” at the Laura Pels Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the set designer. As the listing of credits correctly noted, he is Jeff Cowie — not David C. Woolard, who designed the costumes.

COGEN--Edward N. Died suddenly on March 4, 2013. Beloved husband of Lois, father of Andrew, Mitchell and Douglas, brother of Larry, Sherry and Barbara. Proud grandfather of Alexandra, Sam, Jack, Tess, Brianna and Jordan. Adored uncle and cousin. Veteran of World War II. Devoted graduate of Penn State. Avid sportsman and sport fan. Successful manufacturer. A great friend to so many. An unforgettable individual. Funeral Service 11:30am on Thursday, March 7 at Boulevard-Riverside-Hewlett Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

LOEWENSTEIN--Ruth. Who can I call for the few missing letters in the Sunday Times crossword puzzle? Who can I call to brag about knowing Final Jeopardy when none of the contestants did? Who can I call to tell me which restaurant to eat in and exactly what should I eat? Should I bother seeing a particular play that got mixed reviews? You will be very missed- 60 years of friendship will remain with me always. Love, Doris

BEIL--Sheldon. It is now 5 years that you are gone. You are thought of often by so many of your family and friends and they still talk about your pickled herring. I miss you dearly and hear you say "Did I tell you today that I love you". Your loving wife, Ruthie

The Deal Professor column on Wednesday, about a hedge fund investors’ feud over the nutritional supplements maker Herbalife, referred incorrectly in some copies to the time frame during which Daniel S. Loeb, the owner of one of the hedge funds, Third Point, disclosed its stake in Herbalife. It was Jan. 9, a day before Herbalife gave a presentation to investors and analysts to counter accusations that the company was a fraud; it was not a day after the presentation.

With any luck, the next James Bond movie will have a better title than “Skyfall” — yes, “Skyfall” — the 23rd official entry in that long running spy-thriller franchise, which featured an Academy Award-winning title song performed by Adele , the detachable jaw of Javier Bardem and Albert Finney in a supporting role that seemed almost surely designed for Sean Connery.
 
But whatever the next entry in the Bond series may be and whatever it is titled, it will not be directed by Sam Mendes, the stage director and filmmaker (“American Beauty,” “Revolutionary Road”) who oversaw “Skyfall.”

Bank of America has been underestimating its legal risks for years, and brazenly so, according to its critics. Is that strategy about to pay off with the Federal Reserve ?
 
On Thursday, the Fed will release figures on how much capital the nation’s biggest banks must have to cover a “stress” situation. The following week, investors find out whether those banks will be able to return more of their capital to shareholders by paying dividends or buying back stock.

A Reuters article on Tuesday about Justice Barbara R. Kapnick’s dismissal of a lawsuit filed against the bond insurer MBIA by Bank of America and Société Générale described incorrectly the activity over which she presided in New York Supreme Court. It was a nonjury proceeding, consisting of oral arguments without the testimony of witnesses; it was not a “nonjury trial.”

Mary Jo White, set to become a top Wall Street regulator, is seeking to allay skepticism about her spins through the revolving door between government service and private practice.
 
Yet even as she confronts concerns about her work for JPMorgan Chase in financial crisis cases and Morgan Stanley ’s board in vetting a chief executive, she is turning to a colleague who has trod a similar path.

The Roger Ailes book wars have begun. 
 
On Wednesday Vanity Fair’s Web site published an excerpt from the first of two — or maybe three — books about Mr. Ailes and the network he runs, the Fox News Channel.

FAGAN--Jeffrey, A.,December 18, 1951 March 3, 2013, recently of Tenafly, NJ. Devoted husband of Judy Davis-Fagan, loving father of James and Ali, beloved brother and brother-in-law of Bill Fagan (Sha), Kay (Dennis Smith), Gerry (Debbie) and Ted (Susan) Davis, son of late Olive Mae Fagan, son-in-law of Mariam Davis, nieces and nephews. 32-year government bond sales and trading career at DCNY and JPMorgan. Memorial service Friday, March 8th, 4pm, Clinton Inn, Tenafly, NJ.

PINES--Allan A.,on March 4, 2013. Husband of Paula. Father of Sara and Lisa. Grandfather of Henry, Graham and Isabelle. Son of the late Olga and Joe. NYU Law School graduate, former NYC Assistant District Attorney, in private practice for many years. Services Thursday 1pm at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Brian Trunzo and Matt Breen were law school roommates who came to share a disdain for their corporate attorney jobs and a growing taste for men’s fashion. This week they officially break free with a new venture, an expansive men’s wear boutique in SoHo. Carson Street Clothiers, named for the street where they lived at Villanova, is a loft-style space with exposed brick arches, industrial accents and plenty of places to sit. There is something for every man (disposable income will help) to start or build a wardrobe. Messrs. Trunzo and Breen have amassed a nice mix of elevated street brands like Patrik Ervell and the Swedish luxe streetwear label Our Legacy (there are some knit tanks that a certain man could pull off) and weekend and travel gear, like Rivieras Leisure mesh shoes and Orlebar Brown swimwear. There is cool sportswear from Ovadia & Sons and Wings + Horns and many manly accessories. Made to measure by the haberdasher Alfonso Felipe — suits start at $1,999 — will be available by appointment.
 
Carson Street Clothiers opens March 9 at 63 Crosby Street; carsonstreetclothiers.com .

A German museum has returned a 15th-century Renaissance painting to the estate of a Jewish art dealer who was forced to sell it under duress in 1935.
 
The painting, “Virgin and Child,” attributed to the Master of Flémalle, is the 10th work of art to be returned to the estate of Max Stern, since the dealer’s beneficiaries – Hebrew University in Jerusalem, and Concordia and McGill Universities in Montreal – started a restitution project in his name in 2002.

The Economic Scene column on Wednesday, about the benefits of encouraging workers to delay retirement misidentified a science organization that receives an annual appropriation from Congress. It is the National Science Foundation, not the National Academy of Sciences.

Q.

 
What does it mean when a Web site says its security certificate isn’t trusted? I get this message from Google Chrome sometimes — is my computer in danger?

APPELBERGH--John W. died on March 5 2013. He was 86 years old. Born in New York City, he was a life long resident of Yonkers, NY. He worked for Pan American Airways for 44 years. He is survived by his wife, Donna, of Yonkers, a son, Jon (Kathy) of Mahopac, a daughter, Jill Blythe (Steve), of Canadensis, PA, four grandchildren, Amy (Paul), Lori (Dan), Kristen and Brian and two great-grandchildren, Daniel and Gavin. Family will be present Friday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Funeral service Saturday 1:30pm at F. Ruggiero and Sons, FH. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla. www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com

KEAN--John, Jr.,88, of Lloyd Harbor, on March 6, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Mary. Loving father of John III (Susan) Kean and Kandace (Gerald) Kane. Cherished grandfather of Christopher, Colby, Alden and John IV. Visitation M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station, Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass St. Patrick's Church, Huntington Saturday 9:15am. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial donations made in memory of John Kean, Jr. to Huntington Hospital. www.maconnellfuneralhome.com

RESNICK--Mildred. A wise, patient and loving woman and respected sociologist and volunteer, passed away at home on Friday, March 1, 2013 at 89 years of age. Beloved wife of 67 years, Robert Resnick, mother of Abby (Roger Day), Pittsburgh, PA, Regina, NYC, and the late Trudy; grandmother of Benjamin Resnick-Day, Brooklyn, NY, Nathan and Eva Resnick-Day, Pittsburgh, PA. She was a counselor for NY State agencies, President, League of Woman Voters of Rensselaer County, NY, on the board of Planned Parenthood in upstate NY, a literacy volunteer at the YWCA of Troy, NY, and taught English as a Second Language (ESL) for Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute international students

ZORAWICK--Michael, age 39 on March 5. Beloved son of the Rev. Joseph and Lois Zorawick. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, March 9 at 11am at the Church of the Epiphany 1393 York Avenue at 74 street New York, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Michaels name to your favorite charity.

Frank Fraver was 19 when he heard about an outbreak of violence between patrons of the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar on Christopher Street in the West Village, and New York City police over the course of several June and July nights in 1969.
 
“It was a big deal,” he said. “I don’t remember a whole lot, just the news coverage, and seeing drag queens and police vans.”

Never doubt the selling power of a deep, well-publicized sale.
 
After being a steady presence among Billboard’s Top 10 albums for three months, Bruno Mars’s “Unorthodox Jukebox” (Atlantic) has finally reached No. 1, largely — but perhaps not entirely — because of a steep discount at Amazon’s MP3 store .

11:17 p.m. | Updated The shareholder opposition to the $24.4 billion buyout of Dell is growing louder.
 
 Carl C. Icahn , the longtime activist investor, is planning to unveil a major stake in the troubled computer maker, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday. As with other investors, he is expected to express dissatisfaction with the price, the person said.

An article on Tuesday about the Los Angeles mayoral primary misstated the number of official candidates. There are eight, not five. (The omitted candidates are Yehuda Draiman, Norton Sandler and Addie M. Miller.) The error was repeated in the headline, and an accompanying picture showed only the top five candidates.

ANDERSON--Barbara, nee Sapkowitz. Born October 10, 1931 to Hyman and Jessie Sapkowitz and sister to Bernice and Marvin, died March 4, 2013. Petite - larger than life. Catskills to New York City. Blood Bank volunteer. Fashionista extraordinaire. Now reunited with husband, Arnie. Gave birth to David Jay and Randi Lee but mother to all! Services: Sunday, March 10, 2013 at 11:45am at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The latest collection from 194t, a line of casual wear from Los Angeles, serves up a modern way to leave the house in sweats. The label uses high-quality Japanese terry for styles like these quilted shorts with a mesh inset, a sweatshirt with a V-shape panel in front, and a hoodie with black piping that would look as good with tuxedo pants as with leggings. As modeled by Chloe Norgaard, she of the fiery rainbow hair on the runway, comfort is always the key to looking good. 
 
Below, from top: 194t hoodie with ribbed side panels, $222; shorts with ribbed inset, $189; and a crew-neck pullover with V-shape inset, $178; at Curve, 83 Mercer Street, (212) 966-3626.

The wind beneath the wings of the musical adaptation of the film “Beaches” has landed the show a home. This week the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., announced that it would produce the show as part of its 2013-14 season. Eric Schaeffer, Signature’s artistic director, will direct the production, which has been talked about for a Broadway run . Casting is still to be announced.
 
In an interview Mr. Schaeffer said the musical is based on Iris Rainer Dart’s 1985 novel, itself the inspiration for the 1988 film, which was directed by Garry Marshall and starred Barbara Hershey and Bette Midler as lifelong friends whose relationship is tested by single parenthood, strained romances and a fatal illness. (It’s turning out to be a rich year for fans of Ms. Midler, who will appear on Broadway this spring in “I’ll Eat You Last,” a play about the Hollywood superagent Sue Mengers.)

WISOFF--Hugh Solomon, Family patriarch, neurosurgeon, teacher, scholar, and friend, passed away March 6th, 2013, at age 85. A child of Brooklyn, son of the late Esther and Percy Wisoff, WWII Navy veteran, graduate of Union College, and Albany Medical College, Dr. Wisoff received neurosurgical training under the renowned Dr. Leo Davidoff at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. A passionate teacher who instilled high standards while training a new generation of neurosurgeons. He treated thousands of patients during a distinguished career, served as Chairman, Dept of Neurosurgery, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center retiring as Clinical Associate Professor Emeritus. Affectionately known as "Sonny" and "Snippy", Hugh was intensely curious and maintained a wide variety of interests and hobbies. A voracious reader, great problem solver, avid gardener and dependable handyman. He loved tennis, photography, and travel. He enjoyed long-lasting friendships with neighbors and colleagues. His greatest joy was family, who gathered frequently at their country home, regaling in his wisdom, sage advice, humor, and generosity. Survived by his wife, Irene Lutzky Wisoff, constant companion of 62 years, with whom he traveled the continents, photographed thousands of artistic & architectural wonders, hosted countless family gatherings. Also survived by his four children and their families: Dr. Jeffrey Wisoff, wife Deborah, daughters Jessica and Alyssa; Marshall Wisoff, wife Therese, sons Benjamin and Jeremy; Andrew Wisoff, children Joshua and Sophie; Janice Solomon, children Daniel, wife Kim ,great-grandson Miles, Aaron, Margot, and Ruth. He is survived by his brother Dr. B. George Wisoff, his wife Rebecca, and sister in law Marian Lutzky. Funeral service at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers at 10am Fri March 8.
Skip and Karen Finley attribute their 41 years of marriage to always ending conversations with, “I love you.”
The death of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela prompted a mass outpouring of grief at his funeral, which also attracted dignitaries from around the world.
International donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on aid for Syrians, but the money has brought anger and resentment in some areas.
Performers from Questlove to Elvis Costello celebrated the music of Prince.

A ranter with jokes onstage, Eddie Pepitone shows a mellower side at home in “The Bitter Buddha.”

At least 10 people were injured, three of them critically, in an explosion on Thursday at a steel castings plant in southwestern Illinois, officials said.
The headquarters of the North American Aerospace Defense Command in Colorado were evacuated for about four and a half hours on Thursday after employees found five suspicious packages.
In “Greedy Lying Bastards,” Craig Scott Rosebraugh sets out to kick global-warming-denying corporate keisters.

For the peripatetic Madison Cox, home is a simple Moorish refuge in a city that has captivated like-minded wanderers for centuries: beloved books and plants share his view of the deep blue Strait of Gibraltar.
Lightweight summer suits — traditionally in pale neutrals — get a sophisticated remake in deep navy and charcoal hues. The rising actor Max Irons steps into the picture.
The life of Evgeny Lebedev, a London Russian who owns the Evening Standard and The Independent, is Balzac-meets-Bulgakov.
Preservationists are fighting what they consider shortsighted decisions to sell architecturally distinctive post office buildings.
The Hanford nuclear cleanup project in Richland, Wash., has been hit by leaking waste, layoffs and delays; now more trouble is ahead.
New York Road Runners will have to limit the number of new entrants to accommodate runners who had the right to compete after they missed last year’s canceled race.
The Los Angeles County Museum of Art has proposed combining with the Museum of Contemporary Art, which has struggled with precarious finances.
Hilton Botha, the former lead detective in the investigation into the death of the girlfriend of the Olympic athlete Oscar Pistorius, has resigned, the police said Thursday.
With Carmelo Anthony sitting out, J. R. Smith had 36 points to keep the Knicks competitive. He came up short, though, and the Thunder won.

An investigation into whether the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill routinely botched sexual assault and harassment complaints is the latest in a series of such allegations against other schools.
Two Frenchmen suspected of plotting terrorist attacks were detained amid heightened concern about threats to France over its campaign against fighters in Mali linked to Al Qaeda.

In 23 seasons, Pedro Valdes, 39, has played for 18 teams, in 13 leagues and in five countries. Now with Puerto Rico, Valdes plans to retire after the World Baseball Classic.
The Assembly’s Democratic majority will propose restoring the full $120 million that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is seeking to cut; the State Senate’s majority coalition is also objecting to the reduction.

Generous, loyal friend and trusted colleague, urbane, gregarious and cultured, an unforgettable presence to those who knew him. He will be greatly missed by his children, Vivian. M. Chambers, Jose A. Barral Jr, Alberto M. Barral, and his grandchild, Isabella Flora Chambers, all of New York and his brother, Angel Barral of Havana, Cuba. In lieu of flowers, all donations should be sent to Mary Manning Walsh Nursing and Rehab. Memorial info at www.frankecampbell.com

BERNSTEIN--Murray, born July 23, 1910, died March 6, 2013. He will be missed by his children Stephen and Jeffrey and their wives Lois and Dorrie; grandchildren Jonathan and Katie, Nina and Matthew and Colleen and his four great-grandchildren. He was an honest and noble man.

MARGOLIN--Harvey, on March 6th, 2013 at the age of 79. Devoted family man and friend to all who knew him. Beloved husband to Helen for just shy of 50 years. Cherished father to three children and their spouses: Neil and Beth, Sharon and Richard and Jeff and Gillian. Adoring grandfather to Joshua, Rachel, Laci, Emma, David and Olivia. SCHREIBER--Irving Jonathan. Irving Jonathan Schreiber, aged 91, died on March 3rd at home surrounded by his loving family. Under the circumstances, it was the best possible sendoff we could have given him and we, his family, are grateful that we were there to say goodbye. He would have been 92 in July and would have been married 65 years this June. His family was everything to him and despite his many professional achievements he always said that his legacy to the world were his children and grandchildren. Irving was born in 1921, a first-generation American born to immigrant parents from the Ukraine. He grew up in Brooklyn speaking Yiddish as his first language. Irving became a member of what came to be known as "The Greatest Generation". He graduated from the City University of New York as a certified public accountant and then served in the Army Air Force during World War II. As a navigator on a B-17 plane, he flew 34 missions over Germany with the 839th Squadron. Upon returning to the United States, he graduated from Columbia Law School on the G.I. Bill. He married Dorothy Benjamin in 1948. He worked for J.K. Lasser and William Casey and then started his own company, Panel Publishers, producing books and journals that addressed developments in both tax and pension laws. He was also a professor of business at C.W. Post University. An ardent baseball fan, he cheered for the Brooklyn Dodgers and then the Mets, but never for the Yankees. A voracious reader, short story writer, avid crossword and Scrabble player, dabbling artist and loving father and grandfather, he will be very much missed by his wife, Dorothy, his children, Jay, Susan and Fran; his son-in-law and daughter-in-law, John and Linda, and his six grandchildren, Aaron, Martin, Rose, Will, Alana and Julie.

CUTLER--Bernard, M.D. Beloved, devoted husband of Shirley for 60 years. Cherished Dad to Jonathan, Diane, R.J., Debbie, Dan, Jane. Treasured "Bernie" to Arin Jill, Mollie and Brian. Dear Brother-in-Law to Dr. Abraham Lurie. Pre-deceased by sister Selma. Loving uncle and friend. Gifted physician in private practice, Professor of Family Practice at SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Director of the Family Practice Center and Director of the Arthritis Clinic at Downstate. Active member of Temple Beth-El of Great Neck and participant in various Great Neck community organizations. Lived by the credo of doing his best, which he achieved monumentally. Services 11am Sunday, March 10 at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck.

DALE--Bruce. The Community Preservation Corporation (CPC) mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Bruce Dale, SVP. Bruce's hard work during his 27-year career at CPC contributed to the financing of nearly $1B and 30,000 quality affordable housing units in Manhattan and the Bronx. Bruce was a committed social justice activist, who believed that good quality affordable housing is a basic human right. His tireless commitment to affordable housing improved thousands of lives by helping to transform formerly distressed neighborhoods. New York City is forever better because of Bruce Dale. All of us at CPC send our deepest condolences to his family. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador (CISPES) 1525 Newton St. NW, Washington, DC 20010, or to Calvary Hospice Fund, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

FRUCHTER--Daniel S.,of Eastchester, NY, passed away March 7, 2013. He was born August 10, 1918 in New York City to the late Dora and Philip Fruchter. Survived by his loving wife Marilyn (Anker) of 54 years; sons Philip and Gary, daughter-in-law Mareanne; loving and proud grandfather of Jake and Alex. A Veteran of WWII, survivor of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. A graduate of New York University and Syracuse University, he had a 45 year career in hospital administration, 24 years as CEO of Union Hospital of the Bronx until retirement in 1989. Burial at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

Church, 72 River Road, Montague, NJ 07827. Burial will be at Rural Valley Cemetery, Cuddebackville, NY. Memorial contributions may be made in memory of Thomas to the ALS Association, Robert Wood Johnson, 10 Plum St., Suite 910, New Brunswick, NJ 08901. Funeral services are being handled by the Gray-Parker Funeral Home, 100 E. Main St., Port Jervis. For additional information, directions or to send a condolence note to the family please visit grayparkerfuneralhome.com.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about Microsoft’s new Office software suite, used an outdated name for a company that offers free equivalents of some Microsoft Office programs. It is Apache OpenOffice; it is no longer OpenOffice.org , though that remains its Web site.

CEPPOS--Robert P.,died on Tuesday, March 5, 2013 at the age of 87, after a two month battle with the MRSA virus. Bob had an incredible zest for life. A business associate spoke for all of us: "If the whole world behaved with the good will, happiness, fun and laughter of Bobby, we all would be better off." He worked every day until he became ill; retirement was never an option. He leaves behind his loving children, Gail, Alan and Richard. He was the proud grandfather of Chelsea. His devoted fiancee Gloria Jerro, and loving brother Ken will sorely miss him. The Funeral Services will be held at 9:30am on Friday, March 8th, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. WISOFF--Hugh Solomon, Family patriarch, neurosurgeon, teacher, scholar, and friend, passed away March 6th, 2013, at age 85. A child of Brooklyn, son of the late Esther and Percy Wisoff, WWII Navy veteran, graduate of Union College, and Albany Medical College, Dr. Wisoff received neurosurgical training under the renowned Dr. Leo Davidoff at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. A passionate teacher who instilled high standards while training a new generation of neurosurgeons. He treated thousands of patients during a distinguished career, served as Chairman, Dept of Neurosurgery, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center retiring as Clinical Associate Professor Emeritus. Affectionately known as "Sonny" and "Snippy", Hugh was intensely curious and maintained a wide variety of interests and hobbies. A voracious reader, great problem solver, avid gardener and dependable handyman. He loved tennis, photography, and travel. He enjoyed long-lasting friendships with neighbors and colleagues. His greatest joy was family, who gathered frequently at their country home, regaling in his wisdom, sage advice, humor, and generosity. Survived by his wife, Irene Lutzky Wisoff, constant companion of 62 years, with whom he traveled the continents, photographed thousands of artistic & architectural wonders, hosted countless family gatherings. Also survived by his four children and their families: Dr. Jeffrey Wisoff, wife Deborah, daughters Jessica and Alyssa; Marshall Wisoff, wife Therese, sons Benjamin and Jeremy; Andrew Wisoff, children Joshua and Sophie; Janice Solomon, children Daniel, wife Kim ,great-grandson Miles, Aaron, Margot, and Ruth. He is survived by his brother Dr. B. George Wisoff, his wife Rebecca, and sister in law Marian Lutzky. Funeral service at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers at 10am Fri March 8.

It was between 2011 and 2012, not between 2011 and 2014.
