Four years after the financial crisis, federal regulators said that many of the nation’s largest banks were better prepared to sustain future market shocks, paving the way for the healthiest institutions to increase their dividends and buy back shares.

An article on Tuesday about the next challenge for physicists after the discovery of a Higgs-like particle last July by two teams of researchers at CERN referred incorrectly to Joe Incandela’s position with one of the teams, known as CMS. He is the leader of CMS, not a spokesman for the leader of the team. (The position of spokesman or spokeswoman is the leader of the team.)

LARDI--Dr. Elizabeth ("Betty) Coryllos Dr. Elizabeth ("Betty") Coryllos Lardi, died on March 6th, 2013 at her home in Old Brookville, NY at the age of 83, surrounded by her family and beloved dog, Niko. This extraordinary woman lived an anything but ordinary life. Born in New York City in 1929, as the only child of renowned thoracic surgeon, Dr. Polivius Coryllos and Lois Ralli Coryllos, she often said she considered being a veterinarian but, when advised that a woman could only work on small animals, decided to become a surgeon. To her, the words doctor and surgeon were synonymous; her father had always told her that to be a surgeon was to be a doctor with an added tool. After graduation from the Spence School in New York, Elizabeth studied pre-med at Barnard College where she graduated cum laude in 1949. She was a runner in the Greek Games, a college auctioneer, active in Physical Education and President of the combined Barnard-Columbia Pre-Med club. In 1953, she was one of two females to graduate from Cornell Medical School. The next step was an internship in Medicine and Pathology at the Cornell division at Bellevue, then a five year surgical residency, including one year as a New York Heart fellow, for which she earned her masters degree in Surgery and, as Senior Resident in General Surgery, helped set up the first heart-lung machine at NYU. In 1959, Elizabeth set off to Toronto where, as not only an American but the only female, she completed her Pediatric Surgery fellowship at the Hospital for Sick Children where she felt blessed to find wonderful people who rapidly made her feel welcomed. Upon returning to "her island", Manhattan, she began practicing pediatric surgery. She helped start the New York Society for Pediatric Surgery and her new home became New York Medical School-Metropolitan Medical Center where her first of many projects was to set up the new Department of Pediatric Surgery while holding the rank of Assistant Professor and Junior Attending on the Thoracic-Cardiovascular service, teaching 3rd and 4th year med students and surgery residents, and serving a term as President of the Hellenic Medical Society. In 1963, Elizabeth married attorney Paul F. Lardi. They began their life together in a one bedroom apartment over a garage on a Great Neck estate with their two adopted police horses and ultimately two babies. After moving to their current home in 1965, they had two more children and many more animals. It was during this time that Elizabeth went into private practice on Long Island and joined North Shore, Mercy and Meadowbrook hospitals where she was chief of Pediatric Surgery for many years. In 1965, she joined the staffs of Glen Cove and Nassau Hospitals, now Winthrop University Hospital. She later became Chief of Pediatric Surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffolk and was made Chairman of the New York State Injury Prevention Committee. Amongst the many accomplishments Elizabeth achieved professionally were her involvement in Pediatric Sports Medicine since its beginnings in the 1960's; the separation of Siamese twins in 1978, being named "Man of the Year" by the Lion's club in Glen Head, becoming active in the Advanced Trauma Life Support program as a State Faculty Member. She helped introduce the use of hypnosis combined with local anesthesia as an alternative for patients needing surgery who are medically contraindicated for general anesthesia. More recently, her work concentrated in the Breast Feeding program at Winthrop through which she became internationally known as one of the leading sources for lactation therapy. Elizabeth constantly sought to increase awareness of and treatment for children with osteogenesis Imperfecta. In 2001 she received the Lifetime Achievement Award and the Teaching Attending Award for Pediatrics from Winthrop University hospital. In 2002 she was honored with the Distinguished Service Award by the Nassau Surgical Society and in 2003 the State of New York honored her for her "50 Years in Practice". The list of Elizabeth's diplomas, certificates, awards, associations and memberships goes on. She was a uniquely gifted surgeon who sought to heal not only the child that was her patient, but also their families. She was a strong and confident 5 foot 3 inch tall woman who carried a gift from God in both her hands and her heart; her mission in life was to share those gifts with as many people as she could. As a mother, Elizabeth treated every child in the way she would hope another doctor would treat her own. Elizabeth lived her personal life as passionately as her professional life. She and her family indulged their love of farming and outdoors with a small Angus farm. She will always be remembered for her desire to save everything from a human life to a shriveled up plant; her love of gardening and adventure, and her will to make a difference. She was a daughter, wife, mother, grandmother, cousin, friend, role model, a reason to believe that nothing is impossible, a symbol of hope and encouragement, and so much more. She lived her life to help others and have a great time in the process. Whenever cautioned that a planned new challenge would overtax her capacities, Elizabeth would quote her idol, Joan of Arc, and say, "I'm not afraid, I was born to do this". Elizabeth is survived by her husband, Paul, and all four children and seven grandchildren; Lisa (Sergio Echeverria), Paul (Laiz; Nina, Chloe), Janice (Steve Ross; Will, Cole, Luke), and Gordon (Shana; Jaden, Ava). Visitation will take place at the Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave, Glen Head, NY 11545, on Sunday, March 10, from 2pm through 9pm. www.whitting.com. Funeral services will be held on Monday, March 11at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Holy Resurrection, 1400 Cedar Swamp Road, Brookville, NY. at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution to The Osteogenesis Imperfecta Foundation. OIF.org

A picture caption on Thursday with a music review of “Well-Strung: The Singing String Quartet,” at the Marjorie S. Deane Little Theater in the West Side Y in Manhattan, reversed the identities of two musicians in some editions. The cellist, Daniel Shevlin, was at the right and the violist, Trevor Wadleigh, was second from the right.

On Monday, Jan. 2, 1911, at half past 7 in the evening, Wassily Kandinsky attended a concert at a hotel ballroom in Munich. The next day he painted it.
 
The work that resulted, “Impression III (Concert),” is one of the first on view in the exhibition “Inventing Abstraction: 1910-1925,” which continues at the Museum of Modern Art through April 15.
Maureen Dowd’s column on Wednesday misspelled the given name of former Vice President Dick Cheney’s wife. She is Lynne Cheney, not Lynn.

ALBANY – The New York State comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, declared victory on Thursday over a relatively little-known scourge: environmentally destructive doughnuts.
 
 Mr. DiNapoli announced that the owner of Dunkin’ Donuts had agreed to set a timetable for obtaining 100 percent of its palm oil, which it uses to make its doughnuts, from sustainable sources.

An article on Feb. 19 about the debate over a $2.6 billion effort to build two bridges linking Kentucky and southern Indiana contained a number of errors. 
 
Of the two bridges, it is the one known as the Downtown bridge, in Louisville — not the so-called East End bridge — that would potentially affect historic homes in Jeffersonville, Ind.

As a battle builds over the $24.4 billion buyout of the computer maker Dell Inc. , an important date is drawing near.
 
That date is March 22, when Dell’s directors can begin pushing back against growing shareholder opposition to the deal. That group’s ranks were recently joined by the billionaire Carl C. Icahn .

Of the art fairs large and small that have set up shop in Manhattan this week the Independent must be the most fun to work. It sure is the most fun to visit. The size is right; the atmosphere is light and bright, especially now that the show is back in its original digs in Chelsea, with some 40 galleries spread over three floors of the former Dia building.
 
If the arrangement of occupants doesn’t have quite the mi-casa-tu-casa informality that distinguished the fair when it was new nine years ago, transparency is still pretty much the rule. There are walls, but no booths, no nooks, no shadows. Everyone shares the same light. If you had a secret deal to do, you’d have to lock yourself in the loo with a phone.

NAIROBI, Kenya — He has been charged with heinous crimes, accused of using a vast fortune to bankroll death squads that slaughtered women and children. His running mate also faces charges of crimes against humanity, and as Kenya’s election drew closer, the Obama administration’s top official for Africa issued a thinly veiled warning during a conference call about the vote, saying that Kenyans are, of course, free to pick their own leaders but that “choices have consequences.” 
 
But when the ballot counting began this week, Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenya’s first president, surged ahead in the race for president and stayed out front as the margin narrowed early on Friday. Soon, the Obama administration and its allies could face a tough choice, made even more complicated by the appearance of taking sides against a candidate who may very well win.

The Spanish writer Federico García Lorca , who lived in New York in 1929 and 1930, and wrote about the experience in a book of verse, “Poet in New York,” will be the subject of a citywide festival anchored by an exhibition this spring.
 
 “Lorca in NY: A Celebration,” running from April 5 through July 21, will feature work by and inspired by García Lorca, a playwright and poet, including a puppet play, poems by creative writing students, scholarly panels and a concert by Patti Smith.

It was probably only a matter of time before the high-tech side of dating – Google background checks and fake emergency cellphone calls – would find its way onto the Broadway stage. The technological aspects of romance will be part of the fabric of “First Date,” a new musical that will open at the Longacre Theater on Aug. 4, with previews starting on July 9.
 
The musical follows a mismatched couple – an investment banker and a fledgling artist – on a blind date, and was first staged in Seattle last year . Its book is by Austin Winsberg, who is best known as a producer and writer for television. His credits include “Gossip Girl,” “Jake in Progress” and “Glory Days,” but he has also directed productions at the Blank Theater Company’s Young Playwrights Festival in Los Angeles.

In oral arguments before the Supreme Court last week , Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. introduced a statistical claim that he took to imply that an important provision of the Voting Rights Act has become outmoded.
 
Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act, which is being challenged by Shelby County, Ala., in the case before the court, requires that certain states, counties and townships with a history of racial discrimination get approval (or “pre-clearance”) from the Department of Justice before making changes to their voting laws. But Chief Justice Roberts said that Mississippi, which is covered by Section 5, has the best ratio of African-American to white turnout, while Massachusetts, which is not covered, has the worst, he said.

After more than two years of long train rides and selling off more than $120 billion in assets, the chief investment officer of the Treasury Department’s bailout program is stepping down.
 
The official, Matt Pendo, will serve his last day on Friday. He will be succeeded by Charmian Uy, who joined the department last summer from Sunoco , where she was treasurer.

An article on Thursday about the prospects of a free-trade pact between the United States and the European Union misstated the potential benefit of such an accord to BMW’s revenue. It could add hundreds of millions of euros annually, not hundreds of billions.

FAGAN--Jeffrey, A.,December 18, 1951 March 3, 2013, recently of Tenafly, NJ. Devoted husband of Judy Davis-Fagan, loving father of James and Ali, beloved brother and brother-in-law of Bill Fagan (Sha), Kay (Dennis Smith), Gerry (Debbie) and Ted (Susan) Davis, son of late Olive Mae Fagan, son-in-law of Mariam Davis, nieces and nephews. 32-year government bond sales and trading career at DCNY and JPMorgan. Memorial service Friday, March 8th, 4pm, Clinton Inn, Tenafly, NJ.

When the rest of America springs forward Sunday morning, there might be some New Yorkers under the impression that they can doze for an extra hour and presumably still legally comply with court deadlines or other official proceedings.
 
Those New Yorkers would most likely be familiar – for reasons that would be a mystery to most – with Section 2-106 of Volume 2 of the New York City Administrative Code (there are 21 volumes in total).

ROSMARIN--Richard, on March 5, peacefully in Boca Raton, FL. He was a talented artist and a retired New York City teacher. He spent many summers and most of his retirement in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. He will be missed by family and friends. For information: www.shermanschapel.com

WISOFF--Hugh S. The Members of The Leo M. Davidoff Department of Neurological Surgery of The Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center note the passing of our former Chairman, Hugh S. Wisoff M.D. We wish to extend our sincere condolences to his family and our colleague Dr. Jeffrey Wisoff.

The twins Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen have found success after transitioning from TV sitcom tots on “Full House” to major design darlings with their own fashion house. Now it’s time for their sister Elizabeth Olsen to make a high-profile career switcheroo: the Classic Stage Company announced on Thursday that the actress will star in a production of “Romeo and Juliet” that will open the company’s 2013-14 season this fall. Additional casting, a creative team and run dates are to be announced.
 
The production will be Ms. Olsen’s first time originating a stage role. Her theater background includes two stints as an understudy: in the 2009 Broadway production of the play “Impressionism” and in the 2008 Off Broadway play “Dust.”

Columbia University on Thursday issued what a spokesman called “a tongue-in-cheek university statement” about the cost of Nutella that students have been eating in — or stealing from — campus dining halls.
 
“Nutella-gate Exposed,” the statement said. “It’s a Smear!”

NEUMANN--Norbert, 93, on March 6, New York. Born September 13, 1919 in Grossostheim, Germany. Son of Max and Rosa. Brother of Herta and Margot. Beloved husband of Suzanne (Buch). Emigrated in 1938. Proudly served in the 8th Armored Div. Bartender extraordinaire at Longchamps. Loved the Catskills and being with his family. His memory will be cherished by his children Michelle (Ron Finkelstein) and Peter (Sabine), extended families and friends.

Will Ferrell, Adam McKay, Ben Stiller and Bob Odenkirk aren’t just the stars and producers of comedy films and television series that will live in perpetuity on DVD players, DVRs and cable-TV programming lineups. They’re also among the creative talent responsible for two new comedy series that IFC said Thursday it had picked up.
 
Mr. Stiller and Mr. Odenkirk, who collaborated on the short-lived but influential 1990s-era sketch series “The Ben Stiller Show,” are the executive producers of the new IFC series “The Birthday Boys,” which will feature the comedy troupe of the same name . IFC, which is ordering 10 episodes of “The Birthday Boys,” described the show in a news release as being in “the classic vein of absurd/silly/smart/funny variety shows” like “Monty Python’s Flying Circus” and said that an early episode would address “such issues as eggs, toilet paper and computers.” Mr. Stiller said in a statement that he was looking forward to working with Mr. Odenkirk again, adding, “We try to do something every 20 years or so.”

RETAIL ACQUISITION The clothing retailer Hot Topic, a mainstay of teenage mall shoppers, agreed on Thursday to sell itself for about $600 million to Sycamore Partners, the owner of Talbots.
 
The deal is the latest for Sycamore, whose takeover of Talbots last year gave it ownership of the troubled women’s wear chain. Hot Topic, whose wares tend toward the more casual end of the style spectrum, gives the buyout firm a younger target consumer.

MIELE--Armand. December 14, 1928 - March 5, 2013. Visitation Sunday, March 10, 2-4 and 7-9pm Scarr Funeral Home, 160 Orange Ave., Suffern, NY Mass of Remembrance Monday, March 11, 11am Church of the Presentation, 271 W. Saddle River Rd, Upper Saddle River, NJ. For more information, visit: www.bornminus.com/ armandmiele
RUBIN--Benjamin A. 9/27/17-3 / 8/ 2010. Always with me. Mae

Last Updated, 11:59 p.m. The State Department dropped an Egyptian activist from a list of women to be honored in Washington on Friday after comments celebrating attacks on Israelis in Bulgaria and the American Embassy in Cairo were discovered in her Twitter feed, along with an anti-Semitic quotation from Adolf Hitler. 
 
The activist, Samira Ibrahim, shattered taboos in Egypt by speaking out about sexual abuse she suffered in March 2011, when she and other female protesters detained in Cairo’s Tahrir Square were subjected to so-called virginity tests by Egyptian soldiers. Encouraged by her father, a religious conservative, Ms. Ibrahim filed suit against the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, known as Scaf, which ruled Egypt at the time.

An article on Tuesday about the search for the Higgs boson misidentified, at one point, the group for which a physicist, Vivek Sharma, works. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, Dr. Sharma works for CMS, not for Atlas.

MYERS--Joel Roth, Manhattan, died Wednesday, March 6, 2012. A prominent insurance executive he served on numerous boards of businesses, civic and religious organizations. He was a loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather to Gail (nee) Liebman, Scott and wife Trudy Myers, Charles French, and Noah, Faith and Jonah Myers. Funeral services will be held Sunday in Dunmore, Pa. (Near Scranton). In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Joshua Morgan Myers Memorial Fund, C/O Margaret Fala, Jefferson Foundation, 925 Chestnut St, Phila., PA, 19107. For additional information, please visit: DunmoreFuneralHome.com

The chairman and chief executive of Pandora Media , the company behind the popular Internet radio service, announced on Thursday that he would be leaving the company after nine years, on a day when Pandora reported growth and better-than-expected earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter and full year.
 
Joseph J. Kennedy, the company’s chief since 2004, said he would remain in place until a successor was found. He informed the board at its meeting on Tuesday, and in the earnings call on Thursday gave no reason for his decision other than hinting at the toll of running a technology company for nearly a decade.

ANDERSON--Barbara, nee Sapkowitz. Born October 10, 1931 to Hyman and Jessie Sapkowitz and sister to Bernice and Marvin, died March 4, 2013. Petite - larger than life. Catskills to New York City. Blood Bank volunteer. Fashionista extraordinaire. Now reunited with husband, Arnie. Gave birth to David Jay and Randi Lee but mother to all! Services: Sunday, March 10, 2013 at 11:45am at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

SOCHER--Jerome. Born July 3, 1936 to Lillian and Meyer. Graduated City College. Tax accountant, most recently at Brown Harris Stevens. Former Treasurer/CFO of Realty Equities. Passion for the ponies. Beloved brother, uncle, great uncle and friend. Funeral service Sunday, 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 108 West 76 St. Interment at Mt Hebron Cemetery.
The city’s top and perhaps only Hasidic hardcore band, Moshiach Oi!, plays to a group at a Brooklyn community center.
Claudia Astor and her mother, Norma Astor, were on opposite sides of Venezuela’s political divide as they watched Hugo Chávez’s funeral on their television in Caracas.
Cultural expectations and practices of birth vary around the world.
The veteran receiver Brian Hartline signed a five-year deal for nearly $31 million to remain with the Miami Dolphins, his agent said.
Maria Sharapova began her pursuit of a second BNP Paribas Open title with an easy victory over Francesca Schiavone.
R. A. Dickey was hit hard over four innings against Mexico, dooming the United States to a loss and an uncomfortable urgency in the World Baseball Classic.
Television highlights.
The best start in N.H.L. history is over. The Blackhawks were stunned, 6-2, by the struggling Colorado Avalanche on Friday night.
The military had planned to hand over control of the prison on Saturday, but remarks President Hamid Karzai made about releases may have caused a reversal.
When Sean Anderson heard Marguerite Daniels was a good cook, he invited himself over for Singaporean chili crab. He got more than he bargained for when her cat was sick on their very first date.
Five police officers were injured on Friday night in the worst rioting for weeks in Belfast in a dispute over the flying of Irish flags near a predominantly pro-British area, officials said.
Russian police temporarily detained six activists protesting  against the incarceration of members of the punk rock band Pussy Riot.
Danica Patrick said she was fine after being hit in the head by a rock while attending a race in Las Vegas on Thursday night.
Harvard would secure the conference title outright with a win against Cornell on Saturday and a loss by Princeton in either of its final two games.
Brad Keselowski will start on the pole after heavy rain forced Nascar to cancel qualifying for Sunday’s race at the Las Vegas Motor Speedway.
The Anaheim Ducks re-signed their captain, Ryan Getzlaf, to an eight-year, $66 million contract, tying him to his only N.H.L. team through the 2020-21 season.
The United States Olympic Committee has received a letter from the city, officially putting it in the running to host the 2024 Games.
The Colorado Senate began a marathon session on a range of new firearms restrictions in a state haunted by two mass shootings.
A.C. Milan warmed up for its second-leg match at Barcelona with a 2-0 win at Genoa but lost two key players to injury four days before the Champions League match in Spain.
Dillon Gee said he felt he was near optimal form for the start of the season after having surgery last summer to remove a blood clot from his arm.
Security forces fired on stone-throwing Sunni demonstrators in the northern city of Mosul on Friday, killing one and wounding five, according to Iraqi officials.
The unidentified remains of two of the 16 men who went down with the ship on Dec. 31, 1862, during the Civil War were interred in Arlington National Cemetery on Mar. 8.
The dead were two unidentified sailors from the ironclad warship Monitor, buried with full military honors 150 years after their ship sank during a storm off the coast of Cape Hatteras, N.C.
Four former public officials pleaded guilty Friday to illegally selling information to the Rupert Murdoch-owned tabloid, The Sun.
While their Yankee teammates were on the other side of Florida, the aging stars Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera and Andy Pettitte moved closer to playing together again.
A manager who turned around Germany’s national railway and second largest airline took over the company behind the construction of Berlin’s new international airport on Friday.
The French defense minister, Jean-Yves Le Drian, said that French forces in Mali had found tons of weapons stockpiled by fighters linked to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.
Deron Williams hit 11 of 16 3-point attempts, including an N.B.A.-record nine in the first half, as the Nets cruised past the Wizards.
An appeals court in Argentina convicted former President Carlos Saúl Menem on Friday of smuggling contraband weapons in the 1990s.
Republicans in the Senate have so far blocked President Obama from filling vacant judgeships in the District of Columbia Circuit of the Unites States Court of Appeals.
Officials in cities like Philadelphia, Chicago and Washington are being met with anger and criticism as they close schools citing budgets.
The Rangers’ Brad Richards returned from a two-game absence, but the Senators’ Jacob Silfverberg broke a 2-2 tie, helping end the Rangers’ four-game winning streak.
Saigon Grill was known for tasty spring rolls and soups, but its owners still owed $1 million for labor violations.
The death of President Hugo Chávez seems to have had surprisingly little impact so far on global oil markets.
The Devils have struggled without the injured 40-year-old goalie Martin Brodeur, whom an analyst described as their “life source.”
Fourteen years after his death, there’s a possibility for something that Arthur Pinajian never enjoyed in life: serious money for his paintings.

Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, head of the United States’ most prominent Catholic diocese, is juggling his leadership roles, Vatican tasks and numerous interviews on Italian television.

LeBron James and Dwyane Wade combined for 47 points to lift the Heat over the 76ers for their 17th straight victory, and the Bulls escaped the Jazz.
Representative Gregory W. Meeks, who had a little-known but significant relationship with Hugo Chávez, was part of a small United States delegation to Venezuela.
Rory McIlroy, the world’s No. 1 player, kept pace with Tiger Woods on the back nine in the second round of the Cadillac Championship, but Woods had built too big a lead for anyone to catch him.
Jurors in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap and eat women, ended their first full day of deliberation without reaching a verdict.
Leslie Dach, who is credited with polishing the company’s image through energy conservation, environmentally friendly packaging and philanthropy, is resigning after almost seven years.
Many students can’t earn their way out of this trap.
One way to appreciate the conceptual oddness of daylight saving time is to imagine it as a new idea.
A plan to combine the two biggest museums in Los Angeles has both wide support and a powerful potential foe: a philanthropist who bailed one of them out five years ago.
Because of recent incidents with the jet’s battery, an advanced feature allowing for new flight paths may not receive approval for months, which could dilute the jet’s appeal.
Research suggests that sports fans, even zealous ones, are less prone to depression and alienation than nonfans.
Turning roadkill into dinner is common in parts of rural America, and state lawmakers are starting to take notice.
Lawmakers need to work with President Obama on a diplomatic solution to the nuclear dispute in Iran.
United States wholesalers increased stockpiles in January by the largest amount in 13 months, even though sales dropped sharply.
The February jobs report may have seemed to be welcome good news for the economy, but there is much to be worried about.
Republican senators have so far kept President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most important appeals court, reviving talk of a change in Senate rules.
Leadership vacuums in government and the Vatican have further shaken Italians troubled by recession, political instability and church scandals.
At the Texas State Capitol, legally armed lawmakers and constituents can enter freely through their own entrance.
Françoise Larribe, who was taken captive in Niger by members of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, clings to hope that her husband, Daniel, is still alive, safe and unharmed.
The Big Brother imagery conjured up by Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky during a filibuster this week has animated a diverse swath of political interests.
The 3-year-old colt Verrazano, a Kentucky Derby contender, has shown early brilliance in two wins for the small Let’s Go Stable.
My eccentric, boisterous relatives told me everything — almost.
Every day officers in New York City confront all manner of hazardous material and dangerous items, but a robbery in Brooklyn was something else.
The Night of the Stars tournament was held on Feb. 28 at the Richmond Bridge Club in London.
This week ABC Family broadcast an entire episode of a show, “Switched at Birth,” in American Sign Language.
Strict limits on pitching and major league teams’ interests weigh heavily on the team managers who take to the mound often in the World Baseball Classic.
The attorney general’s statement about drone strikes on American soil should not reassure anyone concerned about human rights and the limits of executive power.
“The Music of Prince” brought a wide range of performers, including Elvis Costello, Bilal and the Blind Boys of Alabama, to Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.
Ballet Flamenco de Andalusia opened a short season at City Center on Wednesday night.
The F.B.I. is investigating racist and antigay messages left around Oberlin College in the past month and the possible sighting of someone wearing a Ku Klux Klan-type outfit.
One of a dozen Florida A&M University students now charged with manslaughter in the hazing death of a drum major plans to plead guilty in the hope of receiving a more lenient sentence.
A northwestern Montana man shot and killed the host of “A Rifleman’s Journal” on the Sportsman Channel while the TV personality was visiting the man’s wife, police officials said Friday.

The Dow Jones industrial average topped its nominal record high, Martha Stewart took the stand in a trial over sales of her products, and employment data for February suggested the recovery was gaining speed.
First Focus, a bipartisan advocacy group for children and families, responds to an Op-Ed article.
A professor at Columbia says America must continue its global leadership.
A law professor is doubtful that Congress will approve a federal law to deter usury.
An immigration researcher says spending more money to deter unauthorized migrants is futile.
Readers discuss the environmental issues raised by the proposed Keystone XL pipeline.
The rapper YG performed at the Knitting Factory on Thursday, backed by DJ Mustard, the force behind ratchet music.
The members of the Bronx High School of Science track team, accused of holding another boy down and striking his genitals, sat quietly as the judge addressed them.
Richard Breitman and Allan J. Lichtman say their new book is a neutral assessment of Franklin D. Roosevelt’s record on Jewish issues.
The ruling Islamist Renaissance Party said that it had yielded control of the ministries of justice, interior and foreign affairs, bowing to a central demand of several opposition parties.

The Big East announced an agreement to sell its name to the seven Catholic universities that are breaking away this summer to form a basketball-only conference.
An Ensemble Matheus concert at Zankel Hall on Wednesday was full of joy in a program of Handel, Vivaldi and Porpora.
Whole Foods, the first retailer in the country to require such labeling, said all foods sold in its stores would need to be labeled within five years.
Poor play by the Wildcats could keep the team from making the N.C.A.A. tournament, a year after they won it all. Kentucky Coach John Calipari blamed himself.
Having a baby is a wonderfully happy time and also a stressful one, so it pays to get your financial house in order for the sake of you, your partner and your new child.
Divorce filings spiked in big cities across China after rumors that one way to avoid a 20 percent tax on profits from housing sales was to separate from a spouse, at least on paper.
The Oratorio Society of New York performed Paul Moravec’s “Blizzard Voices,” set to texts by the poet laureate Ted Kooser.
The doctrine of Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the head of the Eurogroup, could mean that bondholders end up absorbing steep losses if euro zone members are called upon to prop up failing banks.
The agency cut its rating on Italy's credit by a notch, saying political gridlock could deepen the slump in a pivotal euro zone economy.
A jury ordered $8.3 million in damages in the first of some 10,000 lawsuits tied to a now-recalled implant.
Electronic Arts’s new SimCity requires an online connection, even for the private single-player mode, and so far this week its servers haven’t been up to the task.
A marketing deal between J. C. Penney and Martha Stewart, the subject of a court battle this week, offers a window into the management skills of the company’s chief executive, Ron Johnson.

After track and field’s international federation retested samples from the 2005 world championships, six athletes were found to have doped and now face discipline.

The officers died while carrying out an eradication campaign in a corner of the country where the government has struggled to stem cultivation.
Uhuru Kenyatta appeared to have secured enough votes to win the race for Kenya’s presidency by a narrow margin, but his opponent’s rejection of the result raised fears of chaos.
The princes of the Roman Catholic Church chose March 12 to begin secret voting for a successor to Benedict XVI, who set the transition in motion by resigning the papacy.
Syrian rebels holding a group of peacekeepers from the Philippines in the Golan Heights region were pressing for a redeployment of Syrian government forces nearby, the Filipino authorities said.
North Korea responded angrily to a decision to impose tightened sanctions, saying it was nullifying all nonaggression agreements with South Korea.
Marilyn Maye performed anthems by Jerry Herman and standards by Cole Porter with gusto in her show at 54 Below.

Workers are paying a greater share of their health care costs, and that trend is likely to continue over the next several years, a new report on employer-based health plans finds.
 
Employers still bear most of the cost of workplace health plans. But employees contribute 42 percent more for heath plan coverage than they did five years ago, as against a 32 percent increase for employers, according to the study from the benefits consultant Towers Watson and the National Business Group on Health , a nonprofit industry group whose members are large employers concerned rising about health care costs. (This change is shown in the graphic above.)

An article on Page 66 this weekend about five young men who won the Ruth Lilly Poetry Fellowship describes the group incorrectly. Though no women are included, it is not the case that the X chromosome is not “represented in this year’s crop of winners.” All five men, of course, have an X chromosome paired with a Y. (The women have neither a Y nor a fellowship — just X X.)

Joy Behar, an original member of the 16-year-old ABC talk show “The View,” says that she has decided to leave the show at the end of its current season. 
 
“There are other things on my plate I want to do,” she told Deadline.com on Thursday, citing a play she has been writing and her stand-up comedy. She also said she would like to host another talk show of her own; she previously had stints on HLN and Current TV.

NICHOLSON--Ronald A. The current Trustees of Teachers College, Columbia University, and the former Trustee colleagues of Ronald A. Nicholson mourn the passing of Ron, who rendered staunch service as a Trustee of the College and supporter of our students and of education at all levels. Successful in law and business, and a proud military veteran who worked to ensure better lives for those who were wounded in service to their country, Ron, a man of wide-ranging interests, had well-informed opinions on education issues ranging from the deployment of learning technology to expanding school choice. Above all, through the generous scholarship program they established, Ron and his wife, Patricia -- a Teachers College graduate -- sought to provide opportunities to learn for all who wished to do so. Our condolences to Pat; to Ron's beloved children, Leslie, James and Justin; and to the many grandchildren, extended family, friends and colleagues who join us in mourning his loss.
A film review on Friday about “Dead Man Down” misidentified the nationality of the director, Niels Arden Oplev. He is Danish, not Swedish.

Jenrry Mejia returned to the Mets’ facility in Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Friday morning ready to resume what has been a troublesome spring training camp for him thus far.
 
Mejia, a 23-year-old right-hander, flew to New York this week to undergo further testing for a thyroid gland issue first detected during his preseason physical. Mejia has since been cleared to resume all baseball activities.

WEAVER--Samuel Davis, 73, May 31, 1939 to March 5, 2013. Resident of Jupiter, FL, died peacefully at home in Greenwich, CT after a courageous year and a half long battle against an aggressive brain tumor. He is survived by his beloved wife, E. Galey Clarke, his children Marian Weaver Ide of Natick, MA, S. Davis Weaver of Cape Cod, MA, Timothy Weaver of Bolton, MA, Jen Weaver Trisk of Greenwich, CT, his brother William Bigler Weaver III of Colts Neck, NJ, his sister Alita Weaver Reed of Hobe Sound, FL and eight grandchildren. Samuel D. Weaver was the second child of William Bigler Weaver Jr. of Charlestown, WV and Alita Davis Weaver of St. Louis, MO. He was predeceased by his younger brother E. Whitaker Weaver of Greenwich, CT. Sam was an alumnus of Greenwich Country Day School, Middlesex School in Concord, MA and Williams College, Class 1961. He maintained many loyal friendships with classmates throughout his life. He was a fierce competitor and will be remembered for his athletic achievements in basketball and baseball at both Middlesex and Williams. Following a successful career in banking at the Wall Street firm of Morgan Guarantee, he became a private investor. He was the "go to" person for friends, family and associates with questions about finance. Among the many committees that Sam served on over the years, the one closest to his heart was the Grindstone Association of Winter Harbor, ME. He served as Chairman of the Golf Committee for twenty years and was instrumental in improving one of the oldest golf courses in the United States. Sam was caring and reliable; a man without pretense. Whether at the Round Hill Club, the Winter Harbor Yacht Club, or Admiral's Cove, you could count on Sam for a good story. He was always ready to laugh, tease or pull a prank, but try as he might, he couldn't prevent the twinkle in his eye or the twitching at the end of his nose from giving away his joking. Sam will be buried alongside his mother, father and brother at the Putnam Cemetery. Services are private.

This week’s Your Money column tells the tale of Andrea and Stephen Kondaks, a couple whose Brooklyn home took in nearly eight feet of water during Hurricane Sandy. Dealing with the trauma and physical clean-up after the storm was hard enough. But Mrs. Kondaks has spent the last four months trying to convince the couple’s flood insurer that its estimate for the cost of repair was woefully inadequate.
 
In November, Ron Lieber wrote a Your Money column about some of the issues and problems that claimants should be prepared for. Many of them have played out in the Kondakses’ case.
At least four people were killed and eight injured in what appeared to be a knife fight in the city of Korla, in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, regional officials said Friday.

An article on Wednesday about a milestone high reached by the Dow Jones industrial average on Tuesday misstated the recent increase in investments in domestic exchange-traded and equity funds as measured by TrimTabs Investment Research. The net inflow into equity funds was $32 billion in January; it was not $77 billion in January, as stated in some copies, nor was it $55.1 billion in January and February, as stated in other editions.

An entry in the Spare Times listings in some editions on Friday about the American Museum of National History’s “Ocean Eats” event scheduled for Sunday, which includes a screening of the film “Shellshocked: Saving Oysters to Save Ourselves,” misstated the connection a teacher at the New York Harbor School has to the film. The teacher, Peter Malinowski, is interviewed in the film; he did not make it with Emily Driscoll, who wrote, directed and produced it.

Goalkeeper Tim Howard has two broken bones in his back, his English club, Everton, announced Friday , an injury that will almost certainly rule him out of two important World Cup qualifiers for the United States national team later this month.
 
Everton revealed no timetable for his recovery, saying only that the injury, sustained in an F.A. Cup game Feb. 26, was not expected to end his season.

LONDON — One thing, at least, is certain in both the fascinating new versions of Harold Pinter’s “Old Times” that are keeping audiences in a rapt state of perplexity here: The man loses.
 
Admittedly, he loses in two very different ways, even though he is played by the same actor, a marvelous Rufus Sewell. But there’s no doubt that by the end of the matinee and evening performances I saw on Saturday, he was a thoroughly defeated soul.
Daylight saving time resumes at 2 a.m. on Sunday.

DEL GUERCIO--Dr. Louis R.M. of Larchmont died on Friday, March 8 due to complications from a brain tumor. He was 84. A renowned thoracic surgeon and pioneer in his field, he was also an artist, inventor, public servant, mentor and entrepreneur. He was an individual who was committed to enhancing the lives of others. He was born on January 15, 1929 to Louis and Hortense (Ardengo) Del Guercio and grew up in Larchmont where he lived all of his life. Dr. Del Guercio graduated from Fordham College in 1948 with a B.S. degree, cum laude. He attended the Yale School of Medicine and received his post-graduate training in surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medial Center, Saint Vincent's Medical Center and Cleveland Metropolitan General Hospital. At the Albert Einstein College of Medicine from 1960- 1971 he progressed from Instructor of Surgery to Professor. He then served as Chief of Surgery at the Saint Barnabas Medical Center in New Jersey until 1976 when he was appointed Chairman of Surgery at New York Medical College and Chief of Surgery at Westchester Medical Center where he served for 26 years until his retirement. He was the author of three textbooks and 320 surgical articles. He was one of the founders and past presidents of the Society of Critical Care Medicine. He volunteered for the first Gulf War and was commissioned a full Colonel and put in charge of the 320th Evacuation Hospital. He was awarded the U.S. Army Commendation Medal in 1991. He most recently served on the board of the Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center, the Executive Committee of the Yale Medical Alumni Association and the Fordham Science Council. In his retirement he walked with his sons on a 500- mile pilgrimage to the tomb of St. James in Santiago de Compostella. He was also an avid fisherman, sailor, painter and tennis player. He loved nothing more than spending time at his waterfront home with his family and pets. He is survived by his beloved wife Paula of 56 years; his children Louis (Carolyn), Francesca (Robert) Monro, Paul (Marianne), Catherine (Luc) Gregoire, Maria (Greg) Stanton, Michelle (Mark) Ferri, Christopher (Berit) and Anthony (Magan); his 15 grandchildren; and his sister Eligia Dundee and her children. Donations can be made in his name to Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center. Visiting Sunday 1-6pm and Monday 4-8pm at Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10:00am at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne.

As payday loans come under more scrutiny, consumer advocates are also urging a closer look at a similar type of short-term loan often marketed to the poor: car title loans .
 
Car title loans are short-term loans — the typical term is 30 days — secured by the title to the borrower’s car. If consumers can’t repay the loan in full, they must extend the loan, incurring additional fees and interest, or risk losing their vehicle.

An article last Saturday about differing views among residents of McComb, Miss., about a law that requires their state and eight others to obtain federal approval for voting changes referred incorrectly to Percy Pittman, the Pike County coroner. He is one of two black countywide officials, not the only one. (The other, Gwendolyn J. Nunnery, is the Pike County tax collector.)

SARNO--Ronald A.,71, son of the late Anthony Sarno and the late Philomena Pilla of Jersey City, NJ; attended St. Aloysius Academy, Our Lady of Victories Grammar School and St. Peter's Prep. He received BA and MA degrees from Boston College and Union Theological Seminary. Initially an associate with Dennis J. Cummins, Jr., Esq. in Fair Lawn, NJ, Ronald went to NYC as an associate at Belair, Kline & Evans, then at Quirk & Bakalor, P.C. Finally, he established the Law Firm of Sarno & De Felice, in NYC and Sarno Law Firm in Ridgewood, NJ. His passion for the law initiated his volunteer role as a moot court judge at Yale College for the last four years. His diversity as an author produced eight books, among which was Prayers for Modern, Urban, Uptight Man, and his role as a writing consultant for the television program Mod Squad. In progress is an adult adaptation of an original EPILLAW TAXONOMY Learning to Think and Write, designed in assisting the learning process of the English language. A resident of Ridgewood, NJ for the last 25 years, Ron is survived by his beloved wife of 38 years, Una McGinley Sarno and his devoted daughter, Niamh. Mass will be celebrated at Mt. A capsule summary on Friday for a national article about the efforts by law schools to provide employment and training programs for their graduates misstated the number of Americans who are unable to afford a lawyer. As the article correctly noted, it is a “vast number” of Americans, not a “vast majority.”

Lillian Cahn, who founded the Coach Leatherware Company in a Manhattan loft in 1961 with her husband, Miles, and went on to help produce the “shopping bag” tote and other handbags that have become ubiquitous accessories in the wardrobes of well-heeled American women, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 89.
 
Mr. Cahn confirmed her death.

TREZISE--Maria Lucia Bezerra Dayton. Born on July 12, 1929 in the upstate Sao Paulo city of Barretos, Maria Lucia became known as "Puzas" (to the chagrin of her mother, Ilnah Lima Bezerra) from the nickname bestowed by her father, Dr. Francisco de Assis Bezerra. Puzas completed her post-graduate studies at the Faculdade de Psicologia Sedes Sapientiae in Sao Paulo where she worked with abandoned children. In 1960 she moved to Rio de Janeiro as an auditor with the Brazilian Ministry of Finance, returning to Sao Paulo in 1966 when she married Arthur Dayton Trezise of St. Albans, New York who had been transferred to Brazil by his employer, the American Can Company. The couple raised three children in Sao Paulo where they attended American schools. Upon her retirement, Puzas accompanied her husband in his second career as a United States Foreign Service officer in their assignments to Sao Paulo, Bogota and Paris. With her knowledge of Spanish and French, combined with her warm personality, Puzas counseled single mothers on a regular basis in a religious shelter in Bogota -- putting to good use her life-long dedication to children. She ably complemented her husband in his responsibilities as Commercial Counselor of the American Embassy in France. Since 1994 the couple resided in both Vermont and Sao Paulo. Puzas the 11th among 12 siblings -- leaves her sisters, Silvia Camara and Neusa Reiff, plus a beloved team of 36 nieces and nephews in Brazil, in addition to her husband Arthur and their children: Bridie Bezerra Musser (Steven) with grandsons Will and Ben of Minneapolis; Arthur A. B. Trezise (Heather) with grandchildren Clara, Macy and Wyatt of Gunnison; and Patrick Bezerra Trezise (Silvia) of Sant Cugat del Valles, Spain. There will be a Requium Mass at 11am on March 14 at St. Peter's Church in Gunnison for family and friends in the area, with similar funeral services to be announced at a later date in Sao Paulo and Vermont.
An art review on Friday about two installations by Anthony McCall at the Sean Kelly gallery in Manhattan misstated the title of one. It is “Circulation Figures,” not “Circulating Figures.”

MERIANS--Sidney, Former owner and CEO of Talon, Inc., the world's oldest manufacturer of zippers, died Wednesday, March 6, at the age of 86. Mr. Merians passed away peacefully at his home in Alpine, New Jersey. Mr. Merians first joined Talon as president of the company in 1981. At the time, a New York Times report quoted "the owner of another zipper company" who "applauded" the move, saying, "Talon needs a street fighter." He went on to acquire Talon in a leveraged buyout in 1984, an early example of such an acquisition. He ran the company until he retired. Mr. Merians had a long history as a high-level executive in the textile industry. Prior to Talon, Mr. Merians served as president of Everlon Fabrics, a division of Nabisco that manufactured curtains. He joined Everlon in 1963 after rising through the ranks as a sales executive and division manager at Garan, Inc, and before that at Uxbridge Worsted Co. Sidney Merians was born in Harlem, New York on December 11, 1926, the child of Russian Jewish immigrants. His father, a furrier, introduced Merians to the textile business, employing him in his small company, which was relocated several times during the Depression-first to Pennsylvania, and later to New Jersey, where Sidney Merians attended Paterson High School. Mr. Merians enlisted in the Army Air Corps at the age of 17 and served in the Pacific during World War II. Upon his return, he attended Clemson University on the G.I. Bill, and earned a B.S. in textile engineering. While at Clemson, he met Isabel Bern. The two eloped in 1952, and subsequently moved to New York before settling in Alpine, NJ where they lived for 42 years, and where Mr. Merians was elected to the town council, serving the town for over a decade. After his retirement from Talon, Mr. Merians served as a consultant to, and sat on the boards of, Ivy Asset Management, a financial management service, and Paxar Corp., a clothing label maker. In addition, Mr. Merians was an active supporter of several charities, including UJA, Jewish Family Services, and Englewood Hospital. He was also a director of the United Jewish Appeal, a member of American Arbitration Association, and was the president of the Alpine Country Club, where he also served on the board of directors. In addition to his wife, Isabel, Mr. Merians leaves behind three daughters, Lisa DiSalvo, Melanie Merians, and Valerie Merians, and two granddaughters, Madeleine and Rachel DiSalvo, a step-granddaughter, Sara DiSalvo and three sons-in-law Joseph DiSalvo, William Guston and Dennis Johnson. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, well-wishers make donations to Covenant House California. (www.CovenantHouse California.org).

News Corporation’s new publishing company will receive a $2.6 billion infusion of cash and have no debt when it separates from the company’s higher-growth cable channels and Hollywood studio this summer.
 
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, the company confirmed what analysts had expected: Rupert Murdoch will make sure his beloved trove of roughly 175 newspapers will have plenty of capital once they are split off on their own.

Stompin’ Tom Connors, a Canadian country-folk singer whose odes to the vast country he had roamed as a hitchhiking troubadour — not least his paean to its national obsession in “The Hockey Song” — earned him renown from the Maritime Provinces to British Columbia, died on Wednesday at his home in Halton Hills, Ontario. He was 77. 
 
His Web site announced the death, citing natural causes.

Over its nearly 109 years, the New York subway system has inspired many questions. Why do pigeons ride the A train in Queens? What becomes of a failed MetroCard swipe, curdling at the turnstiles?
 
Here is one nobody has ever had to tackle: How do you resurrect a subway station, left for dead beneath Lower Manhattan for nearly four years?

Awards season isn’t over quite yet. On Sunday the winners of the first annual Symmys awards , for outstanding palindrome achievement, will be announced in Portland, Ore. The name of the awards is a palindrome, of course, and so is the date on which they’re being handed out: March 10, or 3/10/2013.
 
The finalists in four categories are impressive, even if they don’t approach the elegance and coherence of arguably the most famous palindrome: “A man, a plan, a canal, Panama.” These embrace the more nonsensical side of the art form, as in these finalists in the short palindrome category: “But as God lived to bore us silly, did a mad idyll issue robot devil-dogs a tub?” And, “I made Rihanna hirsute, familiar, frail: I’m a fetus Rihanna hired, am I?”
INDIG--Jack, born 1928 in Sighet, Romania, died peacefully in Manhattan on February 26, 2013, devoted father of Paul Indig and Suzannah Warlick, and father-in-law of Cecilia Cuesy-Indig, M.D.

Klaus Biesenbach, the chief curator at large at the Museum of Modern Art , and the director of MoMA PS1 , the museum’s outpost in Long Island City, will devote the next six months to EXPO 1: New York, a sprawling exploration of the current state of the environment  and social and political change.
 
The festival’s centerpiece is “Dark Optimism,” a show by about 35 contemporary artists based on the notion, attributed by the museum to the editor of Triple Canopy magazine, that we are on the brink of both the apocalypse and a technological transformation that promises a brighter future. Adrián Villar Rojas, Meg Webster, Agnes Denes, Anna Betbeze and the Fluxus performance artist Joseph Beuys are among the artists whose works are included in the exhibition, which opens at MoMA PS1 on May 12 and runs through Sept. 2.

FIEDLER--Lawrence Elliot, "Nuclear Physics Quiz Kid," CPA, JD, LLM age 74 on March 8, 2013. Beloved husband of Paula. Loving father of Meridith Dennes (Mark). Devoted grandfather of Addison Ryder and Morgan Skyler. He graduated from Syracuse University and received a JD and LLM from NYU. Early in his career, he was active in politics, rising to the position of district campaign manager for Mayor John Lindsey. Later, he went on to run a successful real estate company and was a beloved adjunct full professor of real estate at NYU for over 20 years. Perhaps his greatest source of pride was that he was a teacher, mentor and friend to so many of his students. He was a mentor at Riverside Church and a patron at the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center. Family requests donations to be made in Lawrence's name to the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center, www.whpac.org.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Friday to buy Gardner Denver for $3.9 billion, ending a sales process of months for the maker of industrial equipment like blowers and compressors.
 
Under the terms of the deal, K.K.R. will pay $76 a share, a 3 percent premium to Gardner Denver’s closing price on Thursday. The offer is also 39 percent higher than the company’s stock price on Oct. 24, the day before the industrial equipment company said it was exploring a sale of itself.

The filmmaker who taught moviegoers to be terrified of the New York City subway system (and also made Georgetown seem like a pretty horrific place) will be getting a warm welcome from Brooklyn. William Friedkin , the Academy Award-winning director of “The French Connection” and “The Exorcist,” will be the subject of a six-film retrospective in May at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was announced on Friday.
 
The retrospective, presented by BAMcinématek and titled “Friedkin 70s,” will run from May 2 through 7. Its opening night film will be “Sorcerer,” Mr. Friedkin’s 1977 action thriller about a team of fugitives  transporting unstable explosives in South America. The screening of “Sorcerer” (which has recently been the focus of a lawsuit Mr. Friedkin filed against Universal and Paramount to determine his rights to show the film publicly) will be followed by a Q & A with the director, who will also be signing copies of his new memoir, “The Friedkin Connection.”

LONDON — British banks have been suffering amid dismal earnings, scandals and regulatory investigations, but three of the country’s largest financial firms handed out seven-figure pay packages to hundreds of employees last year.

After three weeks in upstate New York, Alex Barrios was excited about coming back to the city. The sight of the Empire State Building, its shiny spire peeking over the jagged suburban landscape, set his heart racing.

MINSKY--Arthur. Husband, father, grandfather, great- grandfather, father-in-law, brother-in-law, uncle, friend, optometrist, New Yorker, citizen-of-the-world, WW2 Veteran, spreader of charm and warmth, advisor, steady hand of support, man who seemed ceaseless, fell victim to a heart that ceased on Thursday 7 March. His sudden departure leaves his survivors Claire Joel Martin Robert Ellen Darcy Tracey Anna David Helen Laura Louis Rachel Sara Taviel Sidney, Roz and Bob, Arlene Skip and Judy, Arthur Jeff and Paul, Carolyn and Marge, in grief and in certainty that life can be long, rich, gracious, and beautiful.

New plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Bruce Norris ( “Clybourne Park” ) and Mona Mansour ( “Urge for Going” ) are among the productions in the 2013-14 season at Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theater, the company announced on Wednesday.
 
The season begins in September with Zinnie Harris’s play “The Wheel,” a supernatural drama set on a 19th century Spanish farm. Directed by Tina Landau, the show will star Joan Allen, who was last seen at Steppenwolf in the 1991 production of “Earthly Possessions.” “The Wheel” had its premiere in a National Theater of Scotland production at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2011.

An article on Friday about a proposal by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to merge with the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles misidentified the co-chairmen of the board of the county museum, who wrote a letter with its director, Michael Govan, proposing the merger. They are Terry Semel and Andrew Gordon — not Maria Arena Bell and David G. Johnson, who are the co-chairs of the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art. The article also included a quotation from Mr. Govan that referred incorrectly to some of the holdings of each museum. The Museum of Contemporary Art does in fact have works by Frank Stella, although it does not have one of his “Black Paintings.” And the Los Angeles County Museum of Art does in fact have works by Robert Rauschenberg, although Mr. Govan said in an e-mail on Friday that they are prints and minor works that are not on view.

With Carmelo Anthony injured, out of the lineup and unable to carry them through crunch time, the Knicks had an opportunity to explore a few alternatives on offense in the final minutes of their 1-point loss to the Oklahoma City Thunder on Thursday night.
 
Coach Mike Woodson called plays for all the would-be Anthony replacements, but Amar’e Stoudemire, J.R. Smith and Raymond Felton managed only 4 points on eight trips down the floor in the final four minutes of action. The Knicks scored just 13 points in the fourth quarter.

When a team is about to play its first game of the season, and the owner publicly states that anything less than a trip to the Eastern Conference finals would be a disappointment, pressure is created that is hard to live up to. For the Brooklyn Nets, who invested heavily in putting together a winning team in their first season since their move from New Jersey, the pressure created by the team’s owner Mikhail Prokhorov has seemingly distracted from what has otherwise been a successful move for both the Nets and Brooklyn.
 
In a sense, for anyone to talk about this season as a disappointment for the Nets is to ignore their recent history. Currently in line to be the No. 4 seed in the Eastern Conference, the Nets will almost assuredly make the playoffs for the first time since 2006-7, which was the last time the team finished with a .500 record. After years of being among the worst in the N.B.A. in home attendance, the Nets have filled 94.8 percent the Barclays Center’s seats on average for a total attendance of 583,228 through Friday.

It must feel a bit surreal to find yourself, in the tradition of once-unknown European actors like Javier Bardem and Jean Dujardin, suddenly an American sensation. Just ask Matthias Schoenaerts, who starred last fall in the French art-house hit “ Rust and Bone ,” in which he plays Ali, a single father and mixed-martial-arts fighter who falls into a careless romance with Stéphanie, played by a deglamorized Marion Cotillard, who has recently become a double amputee after being maimed by one of the whales she trained at a SeaWorld-type park on the Côte d’Azur. Schoenaerts’s performance, suffused with a clumsy gentleness that recalls Ryan Gosling’s career-changing role in “Half Nelson,” has earned him critical raves and media infatuation. One day he’s a working actor living in Belgium, finding time to go to the gym; the next he’s a Hollywood man of the moment, with a string of movies on the docket.
 
“It’s been exciting, but at some point it drives me nuts,” Schoenaerts says. Indeed, he feels that his quiet life in Antwerp — where he lives with his girlfriend, a law student and model — is slipping away. “I haven’t been here a lot this year,” he says. “Next year I want to do two projects and not more. Four or five a year starts feeling like a grab-the-money-and-run show.”

Each year, the Lilly fellowships offer five young poets prestige, publicity and — most elusive of all — money. The latest crop of winners represents how important, and how controversial, these awards have become.

A report in the F.Y.I. column in some editions last Sunday about the history of monorails in New York City referred incorrectly to the modern-day AirTrain to Kennedy Airport. It is not a monorail. (The city had a monorail for a short time beginning in 1910 and at the 1964-65 World’s Fair.) Another report in the column about Batman’s having been created in the Bronx misstated the given name of one creator. He was Bill Finger, not Joe. (He and Bob Kane thought up the series in 1939 during an hour spent in Poe Park.)

It’s pretty neat to be the first act with an album out on a brand-new record label, but even more momentous when that label — in this case, Cult Records — is run by Julian Casablancas, of the Strokes. While lead singer Donald Cumming isn’t shying away from whatever halo effect that may cast on the Virgins ‘ “Strike Gently,” which will be released March 12, mostly he’s excited to have the blessing of a fellow musician who understands both sides of the mixing board. “We all played the songs in the studio together,” Cumming said of the band. “You can really hear our instruments bleeding over each other.” The organic quality here lies in considerable contrast to the Virgins’ self-titled 2008 debut, whose rock ‘n’ roll was produced to within inches of bubble-gum pop on tracks like “Rich Girls” and “One Week of Danger.” Their new material is stripped down, a harmonic rumble of moonlight swagger and blue-rose tattoos. “I never aspired to hear someone sing my lyrics on ‘American Idol,’” Cumming explained. “I just wanted to make music that felt authentic to me.” Indeed, a lot has changed in the intervening five years: Cumming is the only original member left in the group; he’s married now, to the artist Aurel Schmidt; and he even taught himself to play the piano (think Schroeder from Peanuts, but with a Brechtian twist). “I don’t like to practice too much,” he admitted. “I like the discoveries I make to sound fresh.”
 
The Virgins tour North America this spring with label mates Har Mar Superstar and Color.

When I think of the six-overtime Big East tournament quarterfinal between Syracuse and Connecticut that began on March 12, 2009, and ended March 13, I think of Jonny Flynn.
 
Not his 34 points. I think of Flynn, the Syracuse guard, stumbling a few steps as if his backside were magnetized to the nearest elevated surface, and sitting on the press table to catch his breath. The horn had just ended the fifth overtime. He looked at several reporters, shook his head and said, “This is crazy.”

Armory Arts Week is winding down, but Asia Week, New York City’s annual festival of Asian-art-theme shows, auctions and lectures, is just getting started. Joining new museum exhibitions like “Edo Pop: The Graphic Impact of Japanese Prints” at the Japan Society ( japansociety.org ) and “The Artful Recluse: Painting, Poetry and Politics in 17th-Century China” at Asia Society ( asiasociety.org ) is a minifair at the Ukrainian Institute of America, “JADA 2013” ( jada-ny.org ), hosted by the Japanese Art Dealers Association and opening on Friday.
 
The fair will include a themed exhibition on art of the Momoyama Period (1573-1615), emphatically titled “Momoyama Style!” Momoyama art really had two styles; the opulence of castles belonging to the daimyo, or feudal lords, furnished with golden decorative objects and extravagant textiles, and the more rustic, wabi-sabi aesthetic seen in the tea ceremony.

In 2010, when the Issue Project Room, a presenter of new music, wanted to show off its new space in the former Education Department building at 110 Livingston Street in Downtown Brooklyn, it made a splash with a performance of Morton Feldman’s six-hour String Quartet No. 2 . Last August, though, Issue Project had to shutter the space because of structural problems. On Saturday it reopens there with another monumental work: “November” by Dennis Johnson, a California composer cited as a forerunner of Minimalism by that movement’s éminence grise, La Monte Young. Johnson fashioned “November” from a handful of achingly slow-moving melodic figures, producing a six-hour span of soft-spoken intensity. Lost for more than 50 years, “November” was recently reconstructed by the composer Kyle Gann, and recorded in a limpid five-hour interpretation by the pianist R. Andrew Lee, who will play the work next Saturday. (2 p.m., 718-330-0313, issueprojectroom.org .)

Over the last several decades, it has become accepted wisdom that consuming saturated fat, the type found in meat and butter, is bad for you. Starting in the 1960s, studies showed convincingly that saturated fat raises cholesterol levels and that these elevated levels, especially of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, or LDL (the so-called bad cholesterol), increase heart disease. Studies also showed that consuming polyunsaturated fats — safflower, corn and soybean oils — reduced people’s levels of overall cholesterol and LDL and should be encouraged.
 
But new studies may be upending those assumptions. Researchers with the National Institutes of Health and other organizations recently resurrected the results of a long-overlooked Australian study conducted from 1966 to 1973, in which one group of men with heart disease increased omega-6-rich polyunsaturated fat intake to 15 percent of calories, while reducing saturated fat intake to less than 10 percent. Another group of men with heart disease continued their normal diets.

The authorities said he was trying to enter “an unauthorized location” on the set of the NBC show “Smash”; Mr. Sands was not going into “a designated press tent.”

For Rangers fans, Stephane Matteau’s goal in double overtime in Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals against the Devils is a sweet memory. The Rangers went on to defeat the Vancouver Canucks for the Stanley Cup.
 
Matteau, 43, supports the Garden of Dreams Foundation , a nonprofit that works with the Madison Square Garden Company to help children facing obstacles like illness and homelessness.

Because of an editing error, a reporting credit last Sunday with an article about the impact of sequestration described incorrectly the location of a writer who contributed. Will Carless reported from San Diego — not from “San Ysidro, Calif.” (San Ysidro is a community in San Diego, not a city.)

FISCHMAN--Inge Margaret, (Margot) 93, passed away of natural causes on February 28, in Salt Lake City, UT. She and her husband, Seymour, were long-term residents of Hartsdale. Condolences to: www.garnerfuneral.com

FlightStats, a company that tracks air travel, released its annual On-time Performance Service awards for 2012. Alaska Airlines, AirTran Airways and US Airways were the top North American carriers last year; Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways and Scandinavian Airlines were the top three international ones. The rankings were based on the percentage of the carriers’ flights that arrived within 15 minutes of their scheduled time.

After a breakout performance in ‘Rust and Bone,’ Hollywood is waking up to the raw magnetism of this Belgian import.

An article on Page 66 this weekend about five young men who won the Ruth Lilly Poetry Fellowship describes the group incorrectly. Though no women are included, it is not the case that the X chromosome is not “represented in this year’s crop of winners.” All five men, of course, have an X chromosome paired with a Y.  (The women have neither a Y nor a fellowship — just X X.)
An article on Feb. 24 about the History channel’s new drama “Vikings” misstated the level of literacy in Viking culture. Though not a broadly literate culture, it was not illiterate.

FIEDLER--Lawrence Elliot, "Nuclear Physics Quiz Kid," CPA, JD, LLM age 74 on March 8, 2013. Beloved husband of Paula. Loving father of Meridith Dennes (Mark). Devoted grandfather of Addison Ryder and Morgan Skyler. He graduated from Syracuse University and received a JD and LLM from NYU. Early in his career, he was active in politics, rising to the position of district campaign manager for Mayor John Lindsay. Later, he went on to run a successful real estate company and was a beloved adjunct full professor of real estate at NYU for over 20 years. Perhaps his greatest source of pride was that he was a teacher, mentor and friend to so many of his students. He was a mentor at Riverside Church and a patron at the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center. Family requests donations to be made in Lawrence's name to the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center, www.whpac.org.

KOEPPEL--Marlene, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, March 6, in Hong Kong. Her husband, Dr. Jerome Koeppel predeceased her and left four beautiful children, Lisa, Gabrielle, Claudia and John, and nine grandchildren. In addition to her children and grandchildren, her twin sister Ilene and husband Jerry Cohen, and brothers-in-law Howard Koeppel and Mark Hsiao, will dearly miss her. Funeral services to be announced. Sol Levinson and Brothers Funeral Home, Baltimore, MD. 410-653-8900.

In its division of emphasis between formal, technical precision; and pedestrian, apparently casual movement Liz Gerring’s work is distinctive, and different from that of most of her choreographer peers. In the 2011 “She Dreams in Code,” which will have its last performance at the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival on Sunday, Ms. Gerring offers six dancers — three men, three women — in a seamless flow of solos, duets and ensemble work both dreamlike and physically forceful, its poetic drama amplified by Michael Schumacher’s score and Willy Le Maitre’s video. Reviewing the piece in 2011 Alastair Macaulay described it in The New York Times as “a stage world that keeps deepening as you watch, and then again further in recollection.” (3 p.m., 1395 Lexington Avenue, 212-415-5500, 92Y.org ; $20.)
 
There’s other intriguing dance to see this week. The Irish choreographer John Scott returns to La MaMa with “The White Piece,” which expands upon his earlier “Fall and Recover,” a haunting exploration of the consequences of torture. (Thursday through March 24, 74A East Fourth Street, East Village; 212-475-7710, lamama.org .)

Re “A Final and a Beginning,” March 3: It is with bittersweet nostalgia and mixed emotions that I read the recounting of the 1963 N.C.A.A. championship men’s basketball game in which Loyola and Cincinnati were each made up predominantly of black players.
