Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Sunday with an article about Joshua A. Miele, who was blinded at age 4 in an acid attack in 1973 in Brooklyn, misidentified the California city where he was shown sitting in a transit station. He was in Berkeley, not in San Francisco.

A picture caption on Feb. 24 with an article about non-Western dance companies coming to New York, misidentified one of two dancers from the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble and misidentified the dance they were performing. Bijayini Satpathy was shown dancing with Surupa Sen — not with Pavithra Reddy — and they were performing “Invoking Shiva,” not “Alap.”

The French national rail company SNCF is starting an economy high-speed rail service called Ouigo on April 2. It will operate between the Paris suburb Marne-la-Vallée (home to Disneyland Paris) to points south, including Lyon, Marseille and Montpellier. Fares for the single-class, no-frills service (with no food or drink) range from 10 to 85 euros (about $12.50 to $107).

FEFFER--Gerald Alan "Jerry". A preeminent trial lawyer who attained nationwide recognition as one of the leading criminal tax defense attorneys in America, died at his home in Washington, D.C. on February 13. He was 70. Jerry Feffer epitomized the term "Super Lawyer," according to James Bruton, a criminal defense lawyer who worked closely with Mr. Feffer throughout the last 30 years of his legal career, first at the U.S. Department of Justice and then at the Washington, D.C. power firms, Steptoe & Johnson and Williams & Connolly. "He had an uncanny rapport with juries. It is one thing to have a jury acquit your client, but quite another for jurors to wait around after they have been discharged to hug the defendant and wish him well. That's the kind of reaction jurors had to a Feffer defense." Jerry's uncanny rapport did not stop with the jury but extended even to his adversaries. As Brendon Sullivan, his partner and close colleague at Williams & Connolly put it, "Jerry was, simply put, the nicest man we knew. He was able to be a zealous advocate, yet remain a gentleman. He could try a hard-fought case and still be friends with the opposition." His friends and business associates unhesitatingly attribute his ability to get along with jurors and the prosecution as well as everyone else with whom he came in contact to his infectious smile, his boundless enthusiasm, and his genuine compassion for others. "Jerry was something rare in our profession," said Roger Zuckerman, a Washington, D.C. lawyer. "He remained a uniformly nice and kind person, gentle, with an easy and ever-present smile. He was the antithesis of what most people think about lawyers." Jerry was born in Washington, D.C. in 1942. As a boy he spent most of his time playing or watching sports of all kinds, which would become his life-long passion. He and his pals regularly would spend 25 cents to take a streetcar to Griffith Stadium after grade school, where they would sneak into the stadium to see his beloved Senators. At age 14 he moved to Europe when his father, a U.S. Diplomat, was assigned there. He attended school at Aiglon College (Chesieres, Switzerland) and Notre Dame International School (Rome), and then returned to the United States to enroll in college at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, where he graduated with honors in 1964. He studied law at the University of Virginia Law School, graduating in 1967. After law school Jerry joined the Wall Street law firm of Nixon, Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Mitchell. In 1971 he left to serve at the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, first as an Assistant U.S. Attorney and later as Assistant Chief of the Criminal Division. He reentered private practice in 1976 with New York City's most prestigious criminal defense law firm, Kostelanetz & Ritholz, where he practiced for three years before being appointed by President Jimmy Carter as Assistant Deputy Attorney General of the Tax Division of the Department of Justice in charge of criminal tax investigations. He left the Department of Justice in 1981 with the end of the Carter Administration. Preferring to remain in Washington, D.C., he then joined Steptoe & Johnson as a partner, leaving in 1976 to become a partner at the quintessential white-collar criminal law firm in America, Williams & Connolly. While there, Jerry worked exclusively with lawyers who shared his love for white-collar criminal law, including the legendary Edward Bennett Williams, the undisputed dean of the field. This move was the fulfillment of his professional dream, which he realized on his very first day when he got on the elevator with Mr. Williams and Mr. Williams introduced him to Joe DiMaggio, Jerry's favorite hero after Willie Mays. Jerry became one the country's most sought after white-collar criminal defense lawyers early on in his career. He and his clients counted his greatest successes by cases that were never made public rather than those that were. His goal in every instance was to persuade the government not to prosecute his client, if not during the investigation then at least once indicted. It was his rare case that progressed to actual trial. Nonetheless, Jerry also was the consummate trial lawyer, with legendary cross-examination skills. One of his more celebrated trials was his defense of hotelier Leona Helmsley against federal income tax evasion and extortion charges. His "silver tongued" arguments, as the prosecutor characterized them, won an acquittal on the most serious charge, to the surprise of legal experts around the country. After the trial the jury foreman was quoted as saying "Mrs. Helmsley had the best lawyer on the planet. He was a cross between Jimmy Stewart and Steve Martin." Jerry's compassion for others resulted in many years of community service, mostly involving education. In the early 1990s he was active in Mentors, Inc., a Washington, D.C. high school mentoring program, and he later served on the Boards of Directors of two local private schools, first at Beauvoir School (as Chairman) and then at The Field School (as Vice-Chair). In 2004 Jerry was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, an illness that in his case started slowly but eventually progressed rapidly, forcing him to retire from the practice of law in 2010. At that time he volunteered to serve on the Board of Directors of the Parkinson's Foundation for the National Capitol Area. "He made an incredible impact on our program," said Lou Nistler, Executive Director of the Foundation during Jerry's years of service. "His personal commitment was key in helping us grow to become the largest Parkinson's Chapter in the country. He was a true inspiration to all of us." Jerry Feffer led a fulfilling life full of love, family, friends and adventure. His wife, Monique Edwige Yingling; three sons, Andrew, John and Keith Carl "Casey"; two sisters, Emily and Myra; daughter-in-law Susan and grandchildren Jake and Rees; and beloved aunt, Rosalie Kane, survive him. A Memorial Celebration of Jerry's life will be held at The Field School in Washington, D.C. on April 27, 2013 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Jerry's name to the Parkinson's Foundation of the National Capitol Area, 7700 Leesburg Pike, Suite 208, Falls Church, VA 22043.

HARRINGTON--Norman Taylor. HARRINGTON--Norman Taylor, died February 28 of cancer in his Manhattan home surrounded by his family. He was 86. An emeritus professor of English literature, Norman taught at Brooklyn College from 1960 to 2009, his specialty Chaucer. Born in Denver, CO, on May 6, 1926, Norman served in the navy in WWII and was graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hobart College in 1948. He received his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1960. He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Delphi Nikopoulos Harrington, three children, Spencer, Alexander and Persephone, their spouses Susannah, Liza and Stephen, five grandchildren, and his sister, Romaine Wasserman. A memorial will be held at West End Collegiate Church in NYC on April 13 at 3pm. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Brooklyn College Foundation (memo: International Travel Fund), 2900 Bedford Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11210.

REYNOLDS--Dr. John J.,was born on June 25, 1924 in Redwood City, California to John and Margaret (O'Malley) Reynolds. He passed away on March 4, 2013 at his home in Scottsdale, Arizona. John was proud to have attended the University of California at Berkeley where he earned BA, MA and PhD degrees in Spanish. He taught at the University of Arizona during the 1950's. He then moved to New York City where he was a distinguished professor at St. John's University for thirty years until his retirement in 1991. He was the author of numerous scholarly articles and several books including "Juan Timoneda" for the Twayne World Authors Series, "Spanish Golden Age Drama" (with Szilvia Szmuk) and "Repase y Escriba" (with Maria Canteli Dominicis), a widely used advanced grammar and composition textbook. Upon retirement, John moved back to Arizona. John was generous, thoughtful, intelligent, and witty. He was incredibly well-read, and because his knowledge was so wide-ranging he was an excellent conversationalist. He was interested in art, history, politics and theology. He also had a special interest in genealogy and was proud of his Irish heritage. When living in New York he enjoyed the theater and was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera. He was a generous supporter of many charitable causes. He will be missed by all who knew him well, especially his family. He was predeceased by his sister Gerry Howe; he is survived by his nephews James, Paul, Jack, and Michael Howe and his niece Margaret Howe. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Harmony Hospice; 4300 N. Miller Road, Suite 110; Scottsdale, AZ 85251. A private burial will be held in Santa Cruz. Please visit: www.pacificgardenschapel.com to light a candle for John and share any condolences with his family.

THAUL--Elliot, 96, born May 20, 1916 in New York City to Hilda and Rabbi Samuel Joshua Rosenthal, died March 4, 2013 in Lantana, FL. Loving husband of Judith Feinsand Thaul (died 1991) and Harriet Wolaner Thaul; father of Susan Jo Thaul (husband Bob Lehrman) and Lawrence Jay Thaul (wife Nancy Thaul); grandfather of Eric and Michael Thaul Lehrman, and Aaron and Jesse Thaul. Corporate Secretary, Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company; Board member, Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn, L.I.; Deputy Mayor, East Hills, L.I.; lifelong poet, including book "My Poetry Well," and Poet Laureate of the Berkshire Writers Room. Elliot remained always keen and will be missed by so many including brother Perez and Harriet's grandchildren.

The Marble House, the eccentric and extravagant TriBeCa triplex that embodies one man’s ode to all of the design possibilities inherent in marble, especially the Carrara variant, sold for $9,466,099.64 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
 
The transaction also included a designated parking spot, No. 7, inside the historic 15-unit brick building at 60 Collister Street/157 Hudson Street, a former stable that dates to 1866 and is now known as the American Express Carriage House.

Garrett Leight, the son of the Oliver Peoples co-founder Larry Leight, dabbled as a journalist and D.J. before giving in to fate in 2010 and starting his own line of retro optics in Venice, Calif. “My dad of course is my mentor from a design standpoint,” Garrett, 28, says. But while the father takes his inspiration from glamorous 1930s film stars, the son’s frames channel bespectacled rebels like Hunter S. Thompson and Charles Bukowski. In an industry where brand names seem to matter more than ever, Leight’s glasses — logo-less and hand-finished — embody understated cool.

Designer fashion is no longer just for gay men and Europeans. Welcome to the age of sartorial enlightenment, in which the average male has shed schlumpiness for style.

 
The scene was a Williamsburg restaurant, packed with the usual array of hip beard-farmers. There was a cookie-cutter likeness about the men in the room, an aesthetic Brooklyn lockstep. Everyone seemed to have gotten the same style memo, the one that called for cardigans with granddad shawl collars, for select brands of pricey Japanese denim and for glasses that make you look like you’ve read too much Ayn Rand.

The questions start: “What’s your favorite virtue?” a man asks. “Integrity,” former Vice President Dick Cheney replies. 
 
What does he appreciate most in his friends? “Honesty.”

To the Sports Editor:
 
Re “Extreme Grief,” March 6: I am a musician. One February, I performed in Valdez, Alaska. There were young men at my hotel in sporting outfits that did not look like skiing attire, but they were definitely for some outdoorsy activity. I asked them what they were dressed for, and they told me they were at an ice climbing festival. They were in the Army and lived in Virginia but had flown all that way to climb frozen waterfalls.

HANSON--John. Brown Brothers Harriman mourns the loss of our friend and Partner, John C. Hanson. Mr. Hanson joined the Firm in 1948, became a Partner in 1972, and was a leader in our Investment Management business. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Gwenda, and his two children, Lee Hanson Scherer and John, Jr. Digger Donahue on behalf of the Partnership

RAFAJ--Susan M.,founder and Chief Executive Officer of Rafaj Associates passed away on Friday, March 1st. Born in Dickson City, PA to a Lutheran minister's family, Sue was one of six children. She received her R.N. at Moses Taylor Hospital in Scranton, PA, then moved to New York, where she started her nursing career at Nassau Hospital (now Winthrop) in the Premature Birth Unit and received advanced training at New York Hospital. In the 1960's Sue was recruited by Revlon for their marketing department to work on the launch of a line of baby care products under Charles Revson Sr. After many years at Revlon, Susan held several marketing positions at Helena Rubenstein, and then became Vice President of new product development at Shiseido Cosmetics. After several years, Susan moved from the corporate side to the agency side of the business at Merchandising Workshop overseeing the Revlon Professional hair care business. Susan started her own agency in 1977 as Blustain, Blum and Rafaj and successfully launched the Bon Jour jeans line in both print and TV. Shortly thereafter she started Rafaj Associates. Her determination, knowledge and expertise set her apart as a pioneer in creating a solely owned women's business. Concentrating on businesses across the cosmetic industry, Susan built Rafaj Associates into a company with over 17 employees and worked on such global businesses as Revlon, Lancome, Elizabeth Arden, L'Oreal, Borghese Inc., Laura Geller Beauty, Hanes, Champion and Ralph Lauren. She was a driving force in helping to establish the industry organizations ICMAD and The Foragers, and also an active member of The Fashion Group International, ABA (American Beauty Association), CEW (Cosmetic Executive Women), ISPA (International Spa Association), PBA (Professional Beauty Association), Women's Business Enterprise National Council (WBEC) and a 30 year member of The Advertising Association of America (4A's). Beloved daughter of Paul and Susan, Sue is survived by two sisters, Ruth Goodwin and Joan Olson and a sister-in-law, Mildred Rafaj. She was predeceased by her brother Paul, and sisters Ellen Vrudny and Grace Rafaj. She was a cherished aunt to Linda Powell, Peter and Scott Goodwin, Mark and Janet Vrudny, Susan McLesky, Ruth Khan, Eric and Susanne Olson. She is also survived by her many close friends and business associates. Susan will always be remembered as a pioneering woman in business and was responsible for helping countless people in the cosmetic and hair care industry find and succeed in their positions. She will be deeply missed by all. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, March 22nd at 1pm at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 122 East 88th Street (corner of Lexington Avenue), New York, NY with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Osteoporosis Foundation or The New York Public Library. A private burial will be held at Susan's family grave in Peckville, near Scranton, PA.

TORCZYNER--Jacques. Zionist Leader, passed away at home in Saratoga, CA. March 7. Survived by beloved wife of 74 years Berthe, son Robert (Janice), granddaughters Rebecca Rountree (Ryan) and Elizabeth Torczyner, great-grandchildren Gabrielle and Joshua Rountree. Pre-deceased by son Ernest. Services Monday, 11:15am at The Riverside: 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

WASSERMAN--Richard E.,age 77, of Ossining, NY, died early Sunday morning, March 3rd, 2013. He suffered from frontotemporal dementia. Dick graduated from Duke in 1957. In his mid 50s, he bravely left his career as an advertising copywriter to pursue his love of psychology, earning an MSW at Yeshiva University. He was a practicing psychotherapist into his early 70s, when he was diagnosed with dementia. Richard was the loving husband of Barbara (Krohn), and father of Carrie Brooke, MD. His wit and good humor will be missed by his extended family and many friends. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

The gentle jazz sage Charles Lloyd turns 75 on Friday, and he’ll celebrate in public, at the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The sober antiquity of the setting should suit Mr. Lloyd, a saxophonist and flutist who found fame in the psychedelic era and then retreated from it, eventually returning as an unhurried seeker, and one of the most lyrical improvisers of our time.
 
The concert, which will be streamed online , encompasses most of Mr. Lloyd’s recent history on the ECM label. He’ll play duets with the pianist Jason Moran, as on a beautiful new album called “Hagar’s Song.” He’ll lead his lithe working quartet, with Mr. Moran, the bassist Reuben Rogers and the drummer Eric Harland. (Mr. Moran’s wife, the operatic soprano Alicia Hall Moran, will join as a guest.)

A map on March 3 with the Frugal Traveler column, about Gangnam, a district in Seoul, located the Gangnam subway station incorrectly. It is just south of Kyobo Tower, not northwest of Bongeunsa Temple (that is Gangnam-Gu Cheong station). A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/frugaltraveler.

It is a particular pleasure, as a woman, to get to edit a men’s issue. In fact, it is the great pleasure of journalism — and by extension of being a reader — to be able to step outside one’s own world and dive into another as an interested outsider. This month we feature a wonderfully diverse array of men, all admirable in distinct and varied ways.
 
The cover shoot of the breakout star Matthias Schoenaerts was, for our seasoned team — the brilliant Bruce Weber, who has shot many a handsome, famous man, and also our entertainment director, Lauren Tabach-Bank, who has coddled many a star on a photo shoot — a charmed experience in which they were enthralled by the energy and realness of this actor, who having worked mostly in his native Belgium did not seem like so many of his slick, packaged and protected Hollywood peers. (Witness the picture of the crew cuddled in bed with Schoenaerts and see the video Weber made on the actor.)

For the peripatetic Madison Cox, home is a simple Moorish refuge in a city that has captivated like-minded wanderers for centuries: beloved books and plants share his view of the deep blue Strait of Gibraltar.

133

 
The South by Southwest Film Festival, which runs through next Saturday in Austin, Tex., is a rising buzz maker for indie filmmakers, jump starting movies like “Tiny Furniture” by Lena Dunham, now of “Girls” fame, and the gay romance “Weekend.” This year it is hosting 133 features (nearly 250 films including shorts), with 76 first-time directors. The festival opened on Friday with “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone,” featuring Steve Carell, and closes with “The East,” an eco-terrorism thriller starring Ellen Page.

The design store Karkula has returned to its Brooklyn roots: its new home in Williamsburg officially opens tomorrow, at 98 South 4th Street, with an exhibition of chandeliers by Michelle James and jewelry by Monica Castiglioni. The store’s owner, the designer John Erik Karkula, co-founded the Brooklyn design object shop Breukelen in 1996 before moving to Manhattan and opening Karkula, where he was an early supporter of emerging talent like Jim Zivic and Lindsey Adelman, first in the meatpacking district, and later in TriBeCa. The new shop, which was designed by Karkula and the Brooklyn-based architect Philipp Mohr, now represents European brands like e15, Bocci and Nanimarquina, as well as its owner’s designs. Karkula maintains that he has always kept a low profile on New York’s design scene. “I thought it was cool to be under the radar,” he said. But that might not be so easy now.
 
98 South 4th Street, Brooklyn, N.Y.; (212) 645-2216; karkula.com .

Each year, the Lilly fellowships offer five young poets prestige, publicity and — most elusive of all — money. The latest crop of winners represents how important, and how controversial, these awards have become.

 
There are a lot of things poets have to worry about these days, but selling out isn’t one of them. Poetry is so marginal (at least economically) that there’s probably more money in needlepoint, thanks to Etsy. A poet’s working life is one of scrapping and scraping to get by, while scavenging free moments in the day to inscribe a tiny number of words onto the page. Grants like the Ruth Lilly Poetry Fellowship — $15,000 handed out by the Poetry Foundation to five emerging talents every year — are among the prestigious ways that poets can be rewarded for their work, and encouraged to make more of it.
CORNWELL--Katharine Saremal, of Brooklyn, died at home on March 4 at 93 years. Memorial 16 March 2pm First Church 124 Henry St., Brooklyn. Visit BKCFILMS.COM

FRUCHTER--Daniel S.,of Eastchester, NY, passed away March 7, 2013. He was born August 10, 1918 in New York City to the late Dora and Philip Fruchter. Survived by his loving wife Marilyn (Anker) of 54 years; sons Philip and Gary, daughter-in-law Mareanne; loving and proud grandfather of Jake and Alex. A Veteran of WWII, survivor of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. A graduate of New York University and Syracuse University, he had a 45 year career in hospital administration, 24 years as CEO of Union Hospital of the Bronx until retirement in 1989. In retirement he was dedicated volunteer at the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum in NY. Funeral services at Sinai Free Synagogue, 550 N. Columbus Ave., Mt. Vernon, NY on Monday, March 11 at 10am. Burial at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

MARMER--Jeffrey, MD. Died unexpectedly on December 23. Funny, compassionate, generous, he lived a full and exciting life. Memorial service on Sunday, March 24 at 2pm at Plaza Jewish on Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street.

NEUMANN--Norbert, 93, on March 6, New York. Born September 13, 1919 in Grossostheim, Germany. Son of Max and Rosa. Brother of Herta and Margot. Beloved husband of Suzanne (Buch). Emigrated in 1938. Proudly served in the 8th Armored Div. Bartender extraordinaire at Longchamps. Loved the Catskills and being with his family. His memory will be cherished by his children Michelle (Ron Finkelstein) and Peter (Sabine), extended families and friends.

TREZISE--Maria Lucia Bezerra Dayton. Born on July 12, 1929 in the upstate Sao Paulo city of Barretos, Maria Lucia became known as "Puzas" (to the chagrin of her mother, Ilnah Lima Bezerra) from the nickname bestowed by her father, Dr. Francisco de Assis Bezerra. Puzas completed her post-graduate studies at the Faculdade de Psicologia Sedes Sapientiae in Sao Paulo where she worked with abandoned children. In 1960 she moved to Rio de Janeiro as an auditor with the Brazilian Ministry of Finance, returning to Sao Paulo in 1966 when she married Arthur Dayton Trezise of St. Albans, New York who had been transferred to Brazil by his employer, the American Can Company. The couple raised three children in Sao Paulo where they attended American schools. Upon her retirement, Puzas accompanied her husband in his second career as a United States Foreign Service officer in their assignments to Sao Paulo, Bogota and Paris. With her knowledge of Spanish and French, combined with her warm personality, Puzas counseled single mothers on a regular basis in a religious shelter in Bogota -- putting to good use her life-long dedication to children. She ably complemented her husband in his responsibilities as Commercial Counselor of the American Embassy in France. Since 1994 the couple resided in both Vermont and Sao Paulo. Puzas the 11th among 12 siblings -- leaves her sisters, Silvia Camara and Neusa Reiff, plus a beloved team of 36 nieces and nephews in Brazil, in addition to her husband Arthur and their children: Bridie Bezerra Musser (Steven) with grandsons Will and Ben of Minneapolis; Arthur A. B. Trezise (Heather) with grandchildren Clara, Macy and Wyatt of Gunnison; and Patrick Bezerra Trezise (Silvia) of Sant Cugat del Valles, Spain. There will be a Requium Mass at 11am on March 14 at St. Peter's Church in Gunnison for family and friends in the area, with similar funeral services to be announced at a later date in Sao Paulo and Vermont.

Serengeti National Park, Tanzania, Feb. 7, 2012 

 
Every view of wildlife on this trip filled me with excitement because I was sharing it with my wife, who grew up on a farm in Guangdong, China. She had seen animals in the zoo in Guangzhou, but I told her it would be amazing to see them free on the plains of Africa. We traveled to Tanzania as a prelude to a new adventure — having our first child, we hoped — on our return.  These zebras were taking a break from the great migration when I snapped this photo, which captured the essence of wild Africa for us. We hope to share this experience someday with our son, Victor, who was born Dec. 29, 2012. THOMAS ADOLPHSON, WILMETTE, ILL.

Insomnia is never far from my thoughts, especially when I am writing. A poor sleeper even as a girl, I spent many nights scribbling diary entries in a notebook on the bathroom floor after our household had gone to bed. As a mother with a full-time job, I often sought the desk in the wee hours by necessity. Those liminal hours between dark and dawn continue to haunt my praxis even now that my nest is empty. For me, there is nothing as attuned as nocturnal writing.
 
We who suffer from sleeplessness also have an arsenal of advice to offer one another. After I once confessed in an article to being a “mouth-breather and ferocious snorer,” concerned readers urged me to seek medical attention, certain that some sort of breathing issue was causing my inability to get a good night’s rest.

An article on Feb. 24 about high-end, high-design hostels contained several errors.
 
A picture of the spa at the Out NYC was taken by Magda Biernat, not Viernat.

Half a century ago a young student who grew up in Queens, began photographing a motorcycle gang in Chicago. The student, Danny Lyon , assembled the black-and-white images he took from 1963 to 1967 into a book, “The Bikeriders,” that became a touchstone of the 1960s. It helped inspire the vision of biker as outlaw hero in the 1969 film “Easy Rider.”
 
The book has gone through three editions, and now two galleries are planning exhibitions of his work. The Akron Art Museum’s “Danny Lyon: The Bikeriders,” runs through June 21. The Hofstra University Museum in Hempstead, N.Y., is celebrating its own 50th anniversary with an exhibition that includes photos from “The Bikeriders”; it owns a set of the prints that was given by George Stephanopoulos of ABC television. That show runs through May 19.

DEL GUERCIO--Dr. Louis R.M. of Larchmont died on Friday, March 8 due to complications from a brain tumor. He was 84. A renowned thoracic surgeon and pioneer in his field, he was also an artist, inventor, public servant, mentor and entrepreneur. He was an individual who was committed to enhancing the lives of others. He was born on January 15, 1929 to Louis and Hortense (Ardengo) Del Guercio and grew up in Larchmont where he lived all of his life. Dr. Del Guercio graduated from Fordham College in 1948 with a B.S. degree, cum laude. He attended the Yale School of Medicine and received his post-graduate training in surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medial Center, Saint Vincent's Medical Center and Cleveland Metropolitan General Hospital. At the Albert Einstein College of Medicine from 1960- 1971 he progressed from Instructor of Surgery to Professor. He then served as Chief of Surgery at the Saint Barnabas Medical Center in New Jersey until 1976 when he was appointed Chairman of Surgery at New York Medical College and Chief of Surgery at Westchester Medical Center where he served for 26 years until his retirement. He was the author of three textbooks and 320 surgical articles. He was one of the founders and past presidents of the Society of Critical Care Medicine. He volunteered for the first Gulf War and was commissioned a full Colonel and put in charge of the 320th Evacuation Hospital. He was awarded the U.S. Army Commendation Medal in 1991. He most recently served on the board of the Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center, the Executive Committee of the Yale Medical Alumni Association and the Fordham Science Council. In his retirement he walked with his sons on a 500- mile pilgrimage to the tomb of St. James in Santiago de Compostella. He was also an avid fisherman, sailor, painter and tennis player. He loved nothing more than spending time at his waterfront home with his family and pets. He is survived by his beloved wife Paula of 56 years; his children Louis (Carolyn), Francesca (Robert) Monro, Paul (Marianne), Catherine (Luc) Gregoire, Maria (Greg) Stanton, Michelle (Mark) Ferri, Christopher (Berit) and Anthony (Magan); his 15 grandchildren; and his sister Eligia Dundee and her children. Donations can be made in his name to Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center. Visiting Sunday 1-6pm and Monday 4-8pm at Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10:00am at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne.

KANNER--Alice H.,Born on August 23, 1931 in Harrison, New York. Devoted and lovely wife of Bernard Kanner, beloved mother of Donna Kanner, Craig Kanner, Pamela Kanner Henry (Edward), and Megan Kanner; doting grandmother to Leigh and Michael McGowan and Sarah, Nicholas, and Anna Henry. After a short illness, she passed away peacefully in Jupiter, Florida on March 2, 2013 surrounded by ones she laughed with, lived for and loved. Alice, a unique person was co-owner of Directions Unlimited, a travel agency in Mt. Kisco, NY before her retirement in 1990. She traveled the world by air and sea enjoying everything she saw. She loved golf and played at two clubs, Jonathan's Landing Golf Club in Jupiter, Florida and Chequessett Neck Golf and Country Club in Wellfleet, Massachusetts. Along with the deep love of her family, Alice had the respect and admiration of many friends. She lived life to the fullest and took in all the world had to offer. A wonderful cook, she enjoyed food, restaurants and experiencing new things. Her family will greatly miss her love and friendship. She will forever be in their hearts. Services will be private.

You will be very missed- 60 years of friendship will remain with me always. Love, Doris

Husband, father, grandfather, great- grandfather, father-in-law, brother-in-law, uncle, friend, optometrist, New Yorker, citizen-of-the-world, WW2 Veteran, spreader of charm and warmth, advisor, steady hand of support, man who seemed ceaseless, fell victim to a heart that ceased on Thursday 7 March. His sudden departure leaves his survivors Claire Joel Martin Robert Ellen Darcy Tracey Anna David Helen Laura Louis Rachel Sara Taviel Sidney, Roz and Bob, Arlene Skip and Judy, Arthur Jeff and Paul, Carolyn and Marge, in grief and in certainty that life can be long, rich, gracious, and beautiful.

Debates over the fairness of the tax code are as old as the federal income tax itself. A cornerstone of the tax — established a century ago, by the 16th Amendment — has been the principle that those who make more should pay more, while lower tax rates help the poor support their families and depend less on government benefits. 
 
That social compact shifted into high gear during the Nixon administration, which tried to incentivize work by rewarding low-income households with a tax break that became the nation’s most successful antipoverty tool ever: the earned-income tax credit. Politicians of both parties have embraced the credit, making it more progressive three times since it was enacted in 1975.

The State Department created a Web portal for LGBT travelers last month that includes advice and links for gay people traveling abroad. In addition to steering travelers to country-specific pages that outline which governments give gay travelers legal protections, and which criminalize same-sex relations, the portal also suggests precautions, like carrying documents verifying custody of any children.

In her brief tenure on earth, 28-year-old Lauren Bush Lauren has already occupied many roles in the public sphere: presidential niece, model, wife of David Lauren, fashion designer, social entrepreneur, philanthropist — and now, photographer. Her latest venture with FEED Projects — her six-year-old company that sells utilitarian-chic, grain-sack-inspired bags and donates school meals to the world’s hungry children with each sale — is the FEED function bag, available now on the company’s Web site. It’s a messenger-like iteration of FEED’s familiar burlap theme, with a detachable shoulder strap, a faux suede bottom and an interior outfitted with pockets for today’s many gadgets. To promote it, Bush Lauren, who minored in photography in college, has shot portraits of a smattering of her many creative (and busy) friends, among them the photographer Henry Hargreaves (above), the Town and Country editor Amanda Hearst and Lehmann Maupin ’s Carla Camacho, all pictured carrying the bag. “We wanted to show real people that I am inspired by, and how they function,” Bush Lauren says of the project, which can be viewed on FEED’s Web site. “Instead of hiring a photographer, I thought: I would love to do this.”
 
So will photographer be a permanent addition to her already overstuffed résumé? The portrait project is over for now, but Bush Lauren is enthusiastic about contributing her snaps to FEED’s lifestyle blog, and about doing similar projects in the future. “It’s fun to flex that photography muscle again,” she says. “It’s something I haven’t used nearly as much as I would have liked.”

The 1970s have always been a nebulous time for style, particularly interior design. An era — or was it a moment between two eras? — full of brazen promise at the beginning, but to which the harsh light of passing years has not always been kind. Especially when it comes to modernism. Picture conversation pits, exposed reel-to-reel stereo equipment or George Hamilton in a leather vest, shirtless. Of course, there are also the highlights, like Babe Paley in a caftan, or the town house rebuilt for Halston on 63rd Street by Paul Rudolph, snapshots of a moment whose fabulousness is undimmed.
 
Another highlight of 1970s design, though not so well remembered today, is the work of the designer Ward Bennett, who died in 2003 at the age of 85. Ask for the book on Bennett and you will find none. Ask one of his clients about him, however, and you will hear raves, assertions of loyalty and of his importance as a designer. There’s a real sense of affection for the man who started out as a shipping clerk in Manhattan’s garment district and ended up creating objects, jewelry, furniture and houses that are of their time, but also have a quiet elegance that evades classification. In a world in which “important” design is increasingly taken to mean Mies chairs and Noguchi lamps, Bennett was and is one of the in-between guys who has not been reduced to Design Within Reach catalog status. “He was one of the first people to look at industrialized modernism as a source of sensual design,” the architecture critic Paul Goldberger says. Indeed, Bennett makes the ’70s look good.

Born in Vietnam and raised in Denmark, the conceptualist Danh Vo’s rapid rise in the art world can be attributed to his incisive and enigmatic style. His most famous work to date involved “building” a to-scale model of the Statue of Liberty: the hundreds of discrete chunks were never actually assembled into a whole; instead they were scattered around the globe to represent the reach of democracy and American imperialism. Last year, Vo won the Guggenheim’s prestigious Hugo Boss Prize , a biennial award that comes with a solo show at the museum. Continuing his exploration of identity and heritage, Vo has filled his show, which opens on March 15, with artwork, kitschy Americana (above right) and Oriental knickknacks that belonged to the late painter Martin Wong . “I consider it a kind of collaboration,” he says. “And I don’t have any problems collaborating with dead people.”
 
Another of Vo’s exhibitions, which opens on March 20 at Marian Goodman Gallery , cleverly assembles the personal effects of Robert McNamara , the former secretary of defense. Largely remembered for escalating the American involvement in the Vietnam War, McNamara is a fraught figure for the artist, whose family fled their homeland in a boat when he was 4 years old. But McNamara is also an ideal subject for Vo, who is once again deconstructing a complex symbol of American power.

Young and Working Round-the-Clock

 
To the Editor:

For the peripatetic Madison Cox, home is a simple Moorish refuge in a city that has captivated like-minded wanderers for centuries: beloved books and plants share his view of the deep blue Strait of Gibraltar. 

 
Sunny, stormy and fog-drenched Tangier has long been a magnet for diplomats, painters, traders, writers, dreamers, stoners, smugglers and spies. In the last century, the city has been full- and part-time home to an eccentric assortment of creative residents and travelers including Eugène Delacroix, Henri Matisse, Edith Wharton, Tennessee Williams, Paul Bowles, Barbara Hutton, Cecil Beaton, William S. Burroughs, Patricia Highsmith and Yves Saint Laurent. All of them basked in the warm — sometimes dangerous and decadent — romantic allure of Morocco’s most northern outpost. The city’s complicated, contentious history matches its diverse vistas and uneven topography: it has been an ancient Berber settlement, a Roman and Phoenician outpost, and a trophy port for a half dozen occupying foreign powers before it gained independence in 1956.

PARIS — Showing confidence in the power of e-commerce and the importance of the Internet, the publishing group Condé Nast announced on Monday a $20 million investment in Farfetch , the Web site that has united individual luxury retailers with online shoppers. 
 
Jonathan Newhouse, chairman and chief executive of Condé Nast International, said this initiative was a recognition of the fast-changing digital world.

An article last Sunday about universities that have begun selling meat and other foods to increase revenue referred incorrectly to the Washington State University department that sells Cougar Gold, a white Cheddar cheese named for the university mascot. It is the Creamery at the School of Food Science, not “the dairy department.” (There is no such department.) The article also misidentified, in some editions, a university in California that has started or expanded student-run farms to supply dining halls. It is California State University, Chico — not a University of California campus in Chico. (There is no UC campus in Chico; there is a student-run farm at UC Davis.)

Gloria loved animals and endowed a scholarship at the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine. FRANKEL--Irving Elliot, 87, passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City, on January 14, 2013 after having bravely undergone brain surgery for a meningioma. He died from complications from the surgery. He was born in Philadelphia on June 22, 1925 and attended Boy's High School in Brooklyn. As a forward observer for the 91st Chemical Mortar Battalion in Patton's Third Army, he earned three battle stars, including one for the Battle of the Bulge. After WW II he finished his college career at City College and Stanford. He started his professional career in the Macy's executive training program, and held executive positions in the clothing industry until jumping careers to serve as Vice-President of Excelsior Imports and President of Allstate Medical Supply, a pharmaceutical company. In his later years, Irv engaged in a number of ventures involving his passionate interest in fine wines. He owned a wine shop in Kent, CT and in his 80's continued to serve as a wine consultant dispensing his charm and considerable knowledge. He was married for 57 years to the love of his life, Harriet Frankel, who passed away last October. Together, they enjoyed their grandsons, theater, travel, food, New York, and each other to the fullest. He is survived by his daughter Dana Kraus; three grandsons, Nicholas Kraus, Nathaniel Kraus and Preston Frankel, and a son Jim Frankel and Jims wife Cindy. He is dearly missed.

KAHN--Dr. Elayne J.,died on Friday, March 8, 2013 at the age of 73. Elayne had an incredible zest for life. She was a dynamic individual- truly one of a kind - and was an inspiration to all who knew her. She was a renowned psychologist, author, world traveler and free spirit whose positive energy and sense of humor was infectious. Beloved daughter, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, cousin and friend- she will be missed and remembered with love and laughter. The funeral services will be held at 11:15am on Sunday, March 10th at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Burial will follow immediately at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.

MERIANS--Sidney, Former owner and CEO of Talon, Inc., the world's oldest manufacturer of zippers, died Wednesday, March 6, at the age of 86. Mr. Merians passed away peacefully at his home in Alpine, New Jersey. Mr. Merians first joined Talon as president of the company in 1981. At the time, a New York Times report quoted "the owner of another zipper company" who "applauded" the move, saying, "Talon needs a street fighter." He went on to acquire Talon in a leveraged buyout in 1984, an early example of such an acquisition. He ran the company until he retired. Mr. Merians had a long history as a high-level executive in the textile industry. Prior to Talon, Mr. Merians served as president of Everlon Fabrics, a division of Nabisco that manufactured curtains. He joined Everlon in 1963 after rising through the ranks as a sales executive and division manager at Garan, Inc, and before that at Uxbridge Worsted Co. Sidney Merians was born in Harlem, New York on December 11, 1926, the child of Russian Jewish immigrants. His father, a furrier, introduced Merians to the textile business, employing him in his small company, which was relocated several times during the Depression-first to Pennsylvania, and later to New Jersey, where Sidney Merians attended Paterson High School. Mr. Merians enlisted in the Army Air Corps at the age of 17 and served in the Pacific during World War II. Upon his return, he attended Clemson University on the G.I. Bill, and earned a B.S. in textile engineering. While at Clemson, he met Isabel Bern. The two eloped in 1952, and subsequently moved to New York before settling in Alpine, NJ where they lived for 42 years, and where Mr. Merians was elected to the town council, serving the town for over a decade. After his retirement from Talon, Mr. Merians served as a consultant to, and sat on the boards of, Ivy Asset Management, a financial management service, and Paxar Corp., a clothing label maker. In addition, Mr. Merians was an active supporter of several charities, including UJA, Jewish Family Services, and Englewood Hospital. He was also a director of the United Jewish Appeal, a member of American Arbitration Association, and was the president of the Alpine Country Club, where he also served on the board of directors. In addition to his wife, Isabel, Mr. Merians leaves behind three daughters, Lisa DiSalvo, Melanie Merians, and Valerie Merians, and two granddaughters, Madeleine and Rachel DiSalvo, a step-granddaughter, Sara DiSalvo and three sons-in-law Joseph DiSalvo, William Guston and Dennis Johnson. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers, well-wishers make donations to Covenant House California. (www.CovenantHouse California.org).

WARREN--Fran, died on her 87th Birthday March 4, 2013. Fran's career spanned over 50 years as a Big Band Singer and Actress, performing with Orchestra leaders - Eckstine, Barnet, Thornhill, James and trumpeter Joe Cabot. Receiving a Gold Record for her signature tune "A Sunday Kind Of Love" (written for her). She appeared on TV variety shows and had title roles on Broadway "Pajama Game" "Guys and Dolls" and "Mame". Fran enjoyed involvement in the Friars Club, Society of Singers and the Copa-Girls. Fran is pre-deceased by her husband Woody Witt, daughter Jody Steinman-Ellentuck and is survived by her beloved daughter Athena (Tina) Witt, son-in-law Larry Grunfeld and two nieces, Audrey, Debbie.

WOOD--Sharon, age 64, of Southampton, NY, died peacefully after a brave battle with cancer on March 2, 2013. She was surrounded by her four children at her bedside. A beloved daughter and overly proud mother, she will be greatly missed. Sharon is survived by her mother Mrs. Helen Polak; daughters Tanya Hausner Ormond, Melody Wood and Charlotte Wood and son Nicholas Wood. She is also survived by her nephew Christopher James, niece Jennifer James, four grandchildren (Katie, Jack, Robbie), son-in-law Benjamin Ormand, and stepchildren Sean Wood, Ian Wood, and Jenny Wood. Her family will hold a private Catholic Memorial Service before scattering her cremated remains in her two favorite places.

A review last Sunday about “Shouting Won’t Help: Why I — and 50 Million Other Americans — Can’t Hear You,” by Katherine Bouton, misstated the cost of cochlear implants for children, and their expected longevity. An implant costs approximately $60,000, including the surgery, adjustments and necessary training, not normally “up to hundreds of thousands of dollars.” And the devices are intended to be permanent; they are not “quickly outgrown.”

Forrest Bess (1911-77) spent most of his adult life in a fishing camp outside Bay City, Tex., where he sold bait and fished. But this visionary artist also read, wrote and painted obsessively. Of his paintings, Roberta Smith wrote in The New York Times last March: “The best of them, made from 1946 to 1970, are initially unimposing yet can rivet the eye with their roiled surfaces, saturated colors and combinations of odd symbols or distilled evocations of the natural world.” People can see for themselves, starting April 19, at the Menil Collection in Houston with “Forrest Bess: Seeing Things Invisible,” featuring about 40 paintings, including, right, “Drawings” (1957), an oil on canvas ( menil.org ).

Because of an editing error, the Foraging column last Sunday, about the upscale High Street Phoenix shopping complex in Mumbai , misstated part of the price range of a jewelry shop there, H. Ajoomal. Prices range from 50,000 to 1,000,000 rupees, not to 100,000 rupees (about $950 to $19,070).
A credit last Sunday with The One-Page Magazine misspelled the surname of an artist who created some of the illustrations. He is Cody Haltom, not Halton.

COGAN--Steven (Skip), MD.,died at his home in Rockville Centre, NY, on March 7, 2013, after a battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife Louise, children Daniel and Sarah, grandsons Max and Asher.

I was born and grew up in the late ’80s in a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side. In New York, apartments can be appealing for three reasons: size, location and cost. You hope to score in one of these categories. Sometimes you’re lucky enough to find a place with two. Three is unimaginable. 
 
We got location and cost. Our place was a hot pretzel’s throw from Central Park and close enough to the American Museum of Natural History that I often detoured there after school to do my homework beneath their giant blue whale. Also, it was cheap: my mother had moved there in the 1970s, and rent-control had kept it affordable. But it wasn’t big. My parents slept on the living room futon, and my bed was all about storage: under, over and inside (layering fitted sheets, one on top of the other, saved room in the closet).

MERIANS--Sidney. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board, Members and Staff deeply mourn the passing of their esteemed former Board Member and Past President. We offer our deepest sympathy to his wife, Isabel and the entire Merians Family. Alpine Country Club John Margaritis, President

SHEEHY--Eugene Paul. Born October 10, 1922 at Wendell, MN. Received a BA from St. John's University, MN (1950), Library of Science degree from University of Minnesota (1952). Served in the U.S. Marine Corps December 1942-June 1946; discharged with the rank of Sergeant. Worked at Georgetown University Library 1952-53. Joined the Columbia University Libraries Reference Department in 1953, retiring as Head of the department in 1987. Edited the 9th and 10th editions of the Guide to Reference Books (1965-86). Passed away, February 26, 2013 at the age of 90 years. Survived by one sister, Ruth Beckman of Fergus Falls, MN and numerous nieces and nephews.

Misogyny has never gone away in politics or business. Women were simply warned that talking about it or identifying it would result in career-ending failure. Who in the real world had to wait for the case of a police officer obsessed with snuff porn to understand that misogyny never went underground or to the Internet. If not misogyny, what do you call the idea that a women can be forced to allow a vaginal ultrasound to be performed on her? The sad truth is misogyny never went away. It has been so successful that it is now viewed as an acceptable policy choice. Just because we cannot speak its name does not mean it does not exist.
 
Justice Holmes, Charleston, S.C.

An article last Sunday about the popularity in England of a diet plan involving fasting misstated part of the name of Britain’s national health-care provider. It is the National Health Service, not National Health System. The article also referred incompletely to a recipe ingredient with 209 calories in a quarter-cup. It is balsamic vinegar dressing, not balsamic vinegar.

In the days before Google, librarians at the New York Public Library hand clipped hundreds of thousands of photos and illustrations from magazines and books to create over 12,000 different files for its Picture Collection. Visitors could search for images of, say, rat catching or handshaking. It was here that Diego Rivera sought inspiration for his monumental murals and Andy Warhol borrowed advertising images, occasionally not returning them, for his art. The photographer Taryn Simon, whose work focuses on cataloging (contraband items seized by airport customs officials, bloodlines of Bosnian genocide victims), has been archiving the collection as part of a series now on view at the John Berggruen Gallery in San Francisco and at the Gagosian Gallery in London. The contents of the folder “Beards & Mustaches,” shown here, is one of her favorites.

In last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, Wendell Jamieson revisited the story of Joshua A. Miele, who was blinded in an acid attack as a small boy in Brooklyn in 1973. Readers responded to the tragedy and its remarkable coda: Mr. Miele’s adult success as a scientist and advocate for the blind. Readers also commented on Ginia Bellafante’s Big City column about the dark corners of the Web exposed in the trial of Gilberto Valle, accused of plotting to kidnap, cook and eat female victims. 
 
I remember Josh. I grew up on Carroll Street and was 6 when the tragedy happened. Like Wendell Jamieson, I thought about him often. The event reverberated through the neighborhood and left an indelible impression on me. Everyone in the community felt terrible for the Miele family. I was shocked to see this story and realize he was the same Josh from Park Slope. I am so impressed with how strong, capable and accomplished he is. What a remarkable example of greatness he provides for the world.

BAYERSDORFER--Alice Klauber, 93. Alice Bayersdorfer (nee Klauber) died peacefully and of natural causes on March 3, 2013. Alice Helen Klauber was born October 8, 1919 in New York City. She graduated from Ethical Culture and Fieldston schools going on to Mt Holyoke where she graduated with an A.B. degree in medical sciences. After graduation she joined the Navy and did bacteriological warfare research in the area of tularemia as a Lieutenant JG. After her marriage to Martin ("Mike") Bayersdorfer, Jr. she moved to Steubenviile, Ohio where she taught biology at the College of Steubenville. In 1968 they moved to The Philadelphian in Philadelphia, PA where she remained and maintained a very active life in a wide range of areas including acting (movies and television) and lyric writing. She was also very supportive of several charitable and civic groups. Alice's activities were somewhat curtailed when her husband Mike developed polio in 1950 and she spent tireless years unselfishly devoted to helping him. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Richard and Mary Beth, and their son, Martin III ("Mike"), and daughter, Sarah. and by her younger brother Alfred ("Bud"), 90, and his son and daughter-in-law, Rick and Ryn, and their son Jason. A family service was held at Joseph Levine & Sons Memorial Chapels in Philadelphia followed by burial next to her husband at Mount Sinai Cemetery in Philadelphia. Memorial donations may be made to Planned Parenthood.

ROTHENBERG--Janet, of Fort Lee, and formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ and Philadelphia, died on March 7, 2013, at the age of 81. The first child of Manuel Fives and the former Freda Portnoy, who fled the pogroms, Jan was a mother in her 20s; a market research pro in her 30s; a college grad and high school teacher in her 40s; and an NYU Master's graduate, arts educator, and theatre producer in her 60s. She loved Jacques Brel's songs, Eugene O'Neill's plays, and Il Cantinori's food. But most of all, she loved her family and myriad friends. Jan leaves her beloved husband Marv, her best friend for 64 years; her children and their spouses, Debra (Philip Carvalho), Stuart (Talya), Craig (Diane), and Randall (Susan Roy); grandchildren Elana, Dania, Jake and Matty Rothenberg and Dylan and Lauren Rothenberg; brothers Marvin Fives and David Fives and sister Ilene Kaplan and their families; and many cousins - all of whom look forward to joining her, and the Fair Lawn friends and Philly family who passed before her, at the endless dinner party she now is hosting.

SCHULMAN--Dr. Gerda Lang. Our family jewel, Gerda, passed away peacefully in her sleep at her home in Riverdale, NY on February 26, 2013, at 97. Extraordinarily bright and determined, Gerda was a prominent family therapist, professor of social work at Hunter and Adelphi, and author, who devoted her life to helping others. She lived her life with integrity, academic curiosity, selflessness, a generosity of spirit, and a deep commitment to family and friends. In her later years, Gerda would often be seen in her neighborhood taking long walks to Wave Hill and hiking up Riverdale Avenue with packages to prepare a gourmet meal. The hallmark of Gerda's remarkable life is the many people that she touched and the causes she championed. She left this world a little better than she found it. Gerda joins her beloved daughter, Monica, parents, Helen and Eugenio, and sister, Lily. Her beautiful smile, soft touch, sound advice, and stories of courage and inspiration will be missed, but never forgotten. Gerda is survived by Jodi Gollub, granddaughter, and her two best boys: Michael Gollub, grandson, and Zachary, great-grandson. A memorial service to celebrate her incredible life will be held at a time to be announced.

A tiny shop in Toronto, specializing in the arcane and the absurd, may just be publishing’s great new hope.

 
In the late 1930s, the Women’s Printing Society, in London, published a slim book with a curious title: “Life-Spark Stories for the Intelligent Young.” Attributed to the author “R. K.,” it tells the story of a “bright little Life-Spark living in the heart of the great Lord-King of the Sun,” who comes down to earth and embarks on a series of adventures. The Life-Spark meets Mother Earth, Nurse Destiny and other deities; it changes form, inhabiting various plants and animals — a pansy, a dog named Gipsie, a little boy. The book is an unusual literary hybrid, an illustrated children’s story and an occult tract: “Harold and the Purple Crayon” meets Aleister Crowley . To be precise, it’s a work of theosophy, offering lessons in karma, reincarnation and other precepts of that esoteric spiritual movement to its intelligent young readers.

If you prefer your jeans black and your hair messy, Richard Hell may be the most important musician you’ve never heard of. A founding father of the New York punk scene, Hell is often credited with establishing, along with the sound, the style of the movement. In his new memoir, “ I Dreamed I Was a Very Clean Tramp ” (Ecco, $26), he gives a candid, sometimes brutal tour of punk’s gritty early days: he dissects band dynamics, counts notches on his bedpost, relates his disturbing descent into addiction and debunks myths about his famously choppy hair. It’s like a testosterone-fueled “Just Kids.” Below, a few of the book’s juiciest bits.
 
Bad Blood The Ramones “were popular but were regarded by the core movers as intrinsically minor.” Of Blondie: “Hardly anyone” took them seriously. “They had a bland, occasionally quirky, urban-girl-group style but were primarily an excuse to look at their stunningly pretty singer.” On Patti Smith: “She was more charismatic than me and a better performer,” he writes, but she is “a hypocritical, pandering diva.”

The Dutch designer Sebastian Brajkovic deconstructs the historical elements of his tables, chairs and lamps while giving them a surreal, extruded quality that is only possible with high-tech machinery. He was barely out of school when pieces from his Lathe furniture series began to appear at design fairs and in the collections of major museums. The furniture, inspired by Brajkovic’s childhood interest in things that turned, like reel-to-reel tape decks, is the subject of an exhibition that opens on March 18 on the European campus of the Savannah College of Art and Design in Lacoste, France. Several of his pieces are available for purchase through the Carpenters Workshop Gallery in London and Paris.

Here comes another play with an asterisk in its title, but not for the usual reasons. The * in “The (*) Inn,” which opens on Monday at the Abrons Arts Center, isn’t a substitute for an obscenity. This is a production of the Target Margin Theater, a brave experimental troupe that would never be coy about a curse word. Instead the asterisk fills in for “haunted,” which is how the adjective in “Die Puste Kreshme,” by Peretz Hirschbein, is usually rendered in English.
 
But for David Herskovits, Target Margin’s feverishly inventive director, “haunted” is too restrictive to describe what happens in this seldom-seen classic of the early 20th century, part of the company’s “Beyond the Pale” season of Yiddish theater. Hirschbein melded symbolist and naturalist modes for his tale of love under siege in a tradition-bound shtetl. “In a way the writing begins in the 1890s, slides into the 1920s, appears to settle into a mid-20th-century existential landscape and lands finally right here today,” Mr. Herskovits said. Expect the play, which features the downtown favorite David Greenspan, to be worthy of several asterisks. (Through March 30, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, 212-598-0400, abronsartscenter.org ; $25.)

The British establishment is a notoriously tough guard to crack —particularly for the wave of oligarchs who have been making London their home. So how come Evgeny Lebedev makes it look so easy?

 
In the novels of Balzac, it often happens that a provincial writer, poor but brilliant, comes to Paris, where he talks his way into critical success. In the stories of Henry James, this outsider is often an American girl who charms her way into European society. Anthony Trollope created “foreign-born” fin­an­ciers who bulldozed their way into the Vic­torian establishment too.

How short is this lockout-abbreviated N.H.L. season? After seven weeks, it is half over, and the homestretch is about to begin. Here is a look at the best and worst of the 48-game schedule so far, and what to look for in the second half.
 
STRONG SUPPORT The lockout did not alienate fans. Instead, they came back in droves, as they did after the N.B.A. lockout in 2011. Television viewership so far is up from last season’s overall figures in the United States. NBC reported a 37 percent jump in viewers for N.H.L. telecasts on its main network and a 34 percent rise on cable. In Canada, TSN’s Wednesday telecast leaped 30 percent compared with last season’s overall figure and CBC’s early Saturday game is up 16 percent from this point last year.

Between loud surf Jams and ill-fitting board shorts, American guys too often err when it comes to beachside style. Adam Brown, the British designer behind the culty swimwear brand Orlebar Brown , offers a corrective. His classic trunks — trimly tailored with a fixed waist and adjustable side tabs — come in three decreasingly daring lengths: the thigh-exposing Setter, as modeled by Daniel Craig in the most recent Bond flick (here in the new-for-spring Fiorentina print by the late designer David Hicks); the midlength Bulldog, for shyer sorts; and the Dane, a slimmed-down board short that marries Old World prudery with a New World fit.

How a former professional basketball player from Stockholm has turned an amateur interest in fragrance into the cult brand of the fashion world. Go to interactive slide show -> 
 
With his lanky 6-foot-5 frame and sleeves of 1920s-era tattoos, Ben Gorham doesn’t look like your average perfumer. In fact, when the former professional basketball player first presented his fragrances in Paris seven years ago, a French journalist sniffed, “What gives you the right to do perfumes?” Gorham, whose Byredo line now has a devoted following that generates $30 million in global sales, smiles as he recalls that early snub: “I was a wild card. But I’m very competitive. I can do one thing really obsessively.”

For those wanting to own a piece of American pop art history without the million-dollar commitment, 1stdibs is selling original Andy Warhol photographs online next Wednesday starting at 11 a.m. Though photography was not the artist’s main focus — he mostly used the snapshots as a basis for his drawings, portraits, prints and famous silkscreen paintings that sell for $6 million to $100 million — his Polaroids, 8×10 black-and-white photographs and photo booth strips are one of a kind and have, in some instances, influenced his most famous works.
 
“If you’re a new, burgeoning collector who wants to own his or her first Warhol, this is the most inexpensive and highest-value entry point into collecting Warhol,” says Jim Hedges, the New York-based retired investment banker who has spent the past decade collecting the photographs featuring everyone from Giorgio Armani and Steven Spielberg to Diana Vreeland and Truman Capote. With this sale, Hedges is sharing his exclusive access with anyone with an Internet connection and anywhere from $10,000 to $50,000 to spend on the “unique objects” that he likens to “Picasso’s sketchpad or Matisse’s paintbrush.” As Hedges explains, “When Andy made a painting, those works always started with a photograph. That photograph would be copied and turned into the screenprint that Warhol used to make the painting. So this is the way he sketched.”

Pam Grier “can discuss philosophy in one scene and hit somebody with a bar stool in the next,” her “Foxy Brown” director, Jack Hill, once said. With “ Foxy, the Complete Pam Grier ,” a Film Society of Lincoln Center program running Friday through next Sunday, Ms. Grier’s potent action aura is on abundant display. She worked as a switchboard operator for American International Pictures before appearing in prison films like “The Big Bird Cage” (1972) and “Black Mama, White Mama” (1973). The urban one-two punch of Mr. Hill’s “Coffy” (1973) and “Foxy Brown” (1974) firmly established her credentials as a no-nonsense embodiment of female empowerment. 
 
Other films followed — including “Greased Lightning” from 1977 (opposite her future boyfriend Richard Pryor as an early black stock car racer) and “Escape From L.A.” from 1996 — directed by, among others, Jane Campion and Tim Burton. And then there was the title role in “Jackie Brown” (1997), Quentin Tarantino’s assured adaptation of Elmore Leonard’s “Rum Punch” and a fitting valentine to one of his all-time muses. Ms. Grier is appearing at several screenings to discuss her career. (Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, 144 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center; 212-875-5601, filmlinc.com .)
