Justin Timberlake says he plans to release new music in the near future: a second volume to his just-released album, “The 20/20 Experience.” 
 
During an album release party in Los Angeles on Monday, Mr. Timberlake confirmed reports that he plans to put out another album this year. He said that the album released last week was “only the first part.”

JPMorgan Chase will make changes to protect consumers who have borrowed money from a rising power on the Internet — payday lenders offering short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.
 
JPMorgan, the nation’s largest bank by assets, will give customers whose bank accounts are tapped by the online payday lenders more power to halt withdrawals and close their accounts.

GILSON--Louis. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Mr. Louis Gilson, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Gloria, and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President for the Board of Governors

10:12 p.m. | Updated 

 
 John C. Malone made his fortune by becoming one of the pioneering barons of the American cable industry. Now he is moving to re-enter the industry he largely left behind more than a decade ago.

An article on Thursday about the surprise among onlookers outside St. Peter’s Basilica when the new pope was revealed misstated the order of the names that Cardinal Jean-Louis Tauran used in making the announcement. He first identified the cardinal who had been chosen pope, Jorge Mario Bergoglio, archbishop of Buenos Aires, and then he gave the papal name Cardinal Bergoglio had selected, Francis — not the other way around.

People have learned their lesson.
 
We’ve been told that so many times since the near-death experiences of the financial crisis. Bankers and regulators have flipped roles: now it’s the bankers who are cautious and their overseers who are aggressive.

An entry in the Spare Times for Children listings in some editions on Friday about the clown Bello Nock’s show, “Bello Mania,” at the New Victory Theater in Manhattan, using information from a news release, misstated the age of Mr. Nock’s daughter Annaliese, who performs in the show. She is 18, not 16.

An art review on Friday about “The Hugo Boss Prize 2012: Danh Vo I M U U R 2,” at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan, an exhibition conceived by Mr. Vo, misstated the opening date of his first New York gallery show, at the Marian Goodman Gallery on West 57th Street. It is today, not Friday. The review also misidentified the city where the artist Martin Wong, to whom the Guggenheim exhibition pays homage, grew up. It is San Francisco, not Eureka, Calif. And the review described incorrectly the San Francisco residence of Mr. Wong’s mother, where some of the works now in the exhibition were once displayed. It is a house, not an apartment.

ROSS--Mary Riepma. A memorial service for Mary Riepma Ross (1910-2013) will take place in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, on Thursday, March 21, 2013 at 4:00pm. There will be a reception immediately following in the parish hall, but interment at Ferncliff Cemetery, will be private.

An article last Wednesday about monastic orders that sell specialty foods referred incorrectly to the wafers that Sister Cecelia Harvey of the Nuns of New Skete used to make. They were communion wafers, not communal.

An article on Tuesday about a critical self-critique of the Republican Party’s 2012 election efforts misidentified, in some editions, the home state of Glenn McCall, a Republican National Committee member. He is from South Carolina, not North Carolina.

ABUEVA--Teodoro Veloso (Teddy); died peacefully, March 11, 2013, at the home of his brother, Jose V. Abueva, in the Philippines. He was 89 years old. Teddy came from a family distinguished for its political activism, intellect and artistic talent ranging from statesmanship to the arts. He joined his parents, Teodoro and Purificacion Abueva, in resistance to the Japanese occupation. After the war ended, he completed studies at the University of the Philippines and worked in public relations. He did graduate work at the Fogg Art Museum in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Later, he was appointed Director of the Philippine Pavilion at the 1962 Seattle World's Fair. On his way back to Manila, he stopped in New York, decided to move there, and remained until 2001. A cultural omnivore, he reveled in all manner of art, theatre, dance, music and food, discoveries he shared with his many friends. He created fabulous feasts and gardens. His artistry, generosity, kindness, joie de vivre and sense of humor will be missed by his friends around the world and his loving family who cared for him in his last years. He is survived by his brothers, Jose and Napoleon Abueva, two sisters, Amelia Martiinez and Terasita Floro, and many nieces and nephews.

FIRSTENBERG--William, a loving father of Amy Yacobovsky and Sheldon Firstenberg, loving grandfather of Alona Yacobovsky, Daniella Yacobovsky and Edan Yacobovsky. We will miss his zest for life, his steadfast determination, and his sense of humor. Donations in his memory can be made to: Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., New York, NY 10024 or Midbar Kodesh Temple, 1940 Paseo Verde Pkwy, Henderson, NV 89012. Services Thursday March 21st at 1pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., corner West 91st St.

The third season of “Downton Abbey” was even more popular than previously believed. The season’s seven episodes averaged 11.5 million viewers a week, PBS said Tuesday after it received updated Nielsen numbers that included digital video recorder playback. Earlier numbers suggested that seven million to eight million viewers had tuned in for each episode. The total audience — up about 65 percent from the second season — makes the third season of “Downton” the most popular drama ever televised by PBS. The show’s online viewership was counted separately. But there, too, a record was set: the public broadcaster said there were 900,000 video streams on the “Masterpiece” Web site the day after the Season 3 finale, the most for the site.

You probably knew this already, but there was a time when there were regular goat beauty pageants in Central Park.
 
The time was the mid-1930s, when, in a fit of post-Prohibitionary giddiness, New York City provided space for the Brewers Board of Trade to choose the year’s mascot for the ubiquitous bock beer advertising poster (a billy goat is a geissbock in German, and a bock beer festival was a springtime staple).

Mary Jo White cleared an important hurdle on her path to becoming a top Wall Street regulator when a panel of lawmakers overwhelmingly backed her nomination on Tuesday.
 
Dismissing concerns about Ms. White’s close ties to Wall Street, the Senate Banking Committee cast a 21-to-1 vote in her favor, sending her nomination to the full Senate for a vote. The committee’s bipartisan support for Ms. White, President Obama’s pick to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission , suggests she is poised to sail through the Senate in the days ahead.

An article on Saturday about a patient who died of rabies contracted from a kidney transplant referred incompletely to the number of cases of rabies spread in the United States through transplantation of body parts. While there was just one other known case of the disease being spread through organ transplants — in 2004, when three people received organs from a single donor — there was also a case in 1979 when a patient was infected with rabies by a corneal transplant.

The Tony Award-winning Broadway musical “Once” is having a cast makeover. Sunday will mark the last scheduled appearance of the show’s Tony-winning star, Steve Kazee, and his colleagues Cristin Milioti, Elizabeth A. Davis and Will Connolly. 
 
Ben Hope, Mr. Kazee’s understudy as the Dublin street musician called simply “Guy,” will take over full time. “Girl” (Ms. Milioti’s role) will be played by Laura Dreyfuss, who appeared in the Broadway revival and national tour of “Hair.” Carlos Valdes will succeed Mr. Connolly as Andrej and Claire Wellin will play Reza, Ms. Davis’s part.

LONSDALE--Dr. Richard C.,Professor Emeritus at New York University, passed away on March 11, 2013 in Glenmoor Retirement Community, St. Augustine, FL where he resided for nine years. In 1942 Dr. Lonsdale was commissioned in the Navy as a Lieutenant JG and participated in the North Africa and in the Utah Beach D-Day landings. He received his doctorate in educational administration in 1952 from Syracuse University, where he taught until 1964. He then taught at New York University until his retirement in 1989. He is survived by his wife, Claire, son Bill, daughter-in-law Jackie, grandson Sam, stepsons John R. Glennon and David A. Glennon and their families. He is also survived by stepchildren Win Rockwell and Sandy Robinson and their families. He was predeceased by his first two wives Carolyn Kelley Lonsdale and Ruth Rockwell Lonsdale. Memorial donations may be made to the Glenmoor Scholarship Fund, 235 Towerview Dr, St. Augustine, FL 32092.
An array of newspapers protested a new press code on Tuesday that empowers a press watchdog to investigate abuses, order corrections and levy steep fines for misbehavior.

Halibut is the chardonnay of the fish family, essentially neutral in flavor but brilliant in transmitting external influences. In David Tanis’s recipe for halibut skewers with yogurt sauce , the dominant flavors will be the Turkish spices, along with the lemon, onion and cooling herbs. 
 
I suggest a good sauvignon blanc, which can show a spectrum of herbal and citrus flavors. What sort of sauvignon blanc? One that is intense but not flamboyant or brassy, in which the flavors are more herbal than tropical fruit, with substance to match the richness imparted by the yogurt. My ideal would be one of the Italian cult producers — yes, cult sauvignon blanc — like Miani (very expensive) or Meroi (less so). But those are very hard to find. A California bottle might work well, though you must choose carefully to avoid oaky wines.

DEMEO--Albert V. Brooklyn Law School mourns the passing of Professor Albert V. DeMeo. He was a beloved colleague, teacher and friend. A member of the Class of 1934, Professor DeMeo joined the faculty in 1961. He taught a wide variety of courses over the next four decades, before retiring in 1999. Prior to joining the faculty, Professor DeMeo was an Assistant United States Attorney in the EDNY and an Assistant District Attorney in Kings County. The Law School celebrated his 100th birthday on April 26, 2011 with his friends and former colleagues. Professor DeMeo touched the lives of thousands of Brooklyn Law students and friends over the years and he will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his son Robert and his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board Nicholas Allard, Dean Joan G. Wexler, President

KAPLAN--Bernard, of North Palm Beach, FL died peacefully in his sleep almost at age 94. Thank you for 20 years of love and affection, travel, good times and wonderful companionship. Mickey/Muriel Kaplan
How athletic pieces, when paired with crisp shirts and neat trousers, can add graphic interest to the most basic wardrobe.

The Yankees won a court order Tuesday temporarily preventing StubHub from opening a store near Yankee Stadium that is designed to allow customers to pick up their tickets before games.
 
The decision came days before StubHub was set to open the store on East 161st Street on Friday. The Yankees argued that the store was within 1,500 feet of the stadium, violating a New York State law that bans tickets from being resold that close to a venue.

Updated, 4:52 p.m. | The Statue of Liberty, which has been closed to visitors since Hurricane Sandy struck and open for only one day since the fall of 2011, will reopen by the Fourth of July holiday, federal officials said Tuesday.
 
Interior Secretary Ken Salazar and Senator Charles E. Schumer announced the plan three weeks after Mr. Salazar toured Liberty Island in New York Harbor. The secretary had planned to announce a reopening date on that trip, but after seeing the unrepaired damage, he held off.

LOS ANGELES — Junie Hoang, the actress who sued Amazon and its Internet Movie Database unit for posting her age, can take her complaint — or at least some of it — to a jury.
 
Judge Marsha J. Pechman, of the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington in Seattle, ruled on Monday that Ms. Hoang, whose legal name is Huong Hoang, could proceed to trial with a breach of contract claim and a request for damages related to her career.

To Shop: Chocolate for You, Coffee for Me

 
Coffee and chocolate, both bean-based crops, are on display at 2Beans, a rare Midtown resource for lovers of both. This unusual cafe and shop has an Illy coffee bar, where espresso and other brews are served in ceramic cups, European-style, on a small tray with a glass of water and a piece of chocolate or biscotti. Pastries from places like Tisserie are also available. There’s a chocolate display in the cafe, but turn the corner in the shop and you are confronted with a chocolate fantasy. Every inch of space is filled with bars and boxes of chocolates from around the world, more than 300 items by first-rate brands from Europe, the United States, Vietnam, Brazil and even the Middle East (Al Nassma camel-milk chocolates). A display case holds chocolate truffles and other bonbons from Chocolat Moderne in Manhattan and Aeschbach of Switzerland, sold by the piece, and slabs of chocolate bark made for the shop: 100 Park Avenue (41st Street), (212) 937-8914, 2beans.com . Closed Sundays.

“Give me a good thrashing because I’m such a bad girl,” says a young woman to her seductive male cousin. He later woos her with this sweet nothing: “Here is my heart. Take it and gulp down my blood.”
 
No, this isn’t a new episode of “True Blood.” It’s a translation of a century-old Yiddish play about shtetl life, “The (*) Inn,” that the adventurous Target Margin Theater has revived to mixed results. The director, David Herskovits , stymies any expectations of stodgy melodrama, which is apt because Peretz Hirschbein’s tempestuous drama has enough kinks, forbidden romance and hints of the supernatural to fill an HBO time slot. But in straining for a modern, lively update, Mr. Herskovits has staged a show that is more bold than coherent.

New York’s newest and tallest observation deck will offer an interactive immersion in all things New York as it shuttles visitors 102 floors into the sky and provides panoramic views of the city and beyond, from the harbor to Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
 
A projected 3.5 million visitors a year to the three-level observatory at 1 World Trade Center will be able see the history of New York City on video screens, punch up the number of available seats for a Broadway show or a Yankees game, and glimpse Rockefeller Center, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, West Point and MetLife Stadium in New Jersey.

DATER--Thomas E.,of Ramsey, NJ, and Pittstown, NY, passed away peacefully after a short bout of pneumonia. He was to celebrate his 84th birthday on March 19. Adopted son of John Young Dater and Eleanor Gott Dater of Ramsey. Survivors are his beloved wife, Joan Lutz Dater, and son, Christopher Edward, 39. He was predeceased by daughter, Gretchen Joyce, 20, a victim of the Libyan terrorist bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, December 21, 1988. Member of the Class of 1951 at Princeton University, he was publisher of the Ramsey Journal weekly newspaper in Ramsey, until 1994 and then established the Home and Store News weekly newspaper that circulated in 13 towns in Northwest Bergen and Rockland Counties. Very active in community life in Ramsey, having served as president of the Ramsey Free Public Library, The Chamber of Commerce, the Ramsey's Savings and Loan. He served as Bergen County Coroner in 1962-65. An exempt firefighter and former President of the Ramsey Fire Dept., the Dept. members rendered their honors during the committal service at the Lutheran Redeemer Cemetery in Mahwah. A Funeral Service was held at the First Presbyterian Church, Ramsey, where he was an elder and former Clerk of Session. Awarded several community honors and awards for his lifetime achievements. In 2008 he served as the Grand Marshall for the Ramsey Centennial Parade. He had been working as a property manager with his son. He also served as Ramsey's official historian. Funeral services were handled by the Van Emburgh-Sneider-Pernice Funeral Home in Ramsey. Donations may be made to the Ramsey Volunteer Fire Department in his name, P.O. Box 164, Ramsey, NJ 07446. He was beloved by all and will be sorely missed. Please send tributes, memories and condolences to: www.vanemburghsneider.com
KESSLER--Ruth. In memory of Ruth Kessler. Born June 18, 1928. Died March 15, 2013. Loving wife, mother, grandmother. She will be greatly missed.

This is the season of star vehicles on Broadway – Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson, Tom Hanks, Alec Baldwin, Bette Midler – but not all of them are burning rubber at the box office.
 
Ticket sales for the latest revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” starring Ms. Johansson as Maggie the Cat, have been relatively lackluster since the production opened on Jan. 17 to mixed-to-negative reviews. (StageGrade.com, which aggregates reviews, gave a median grade of C- to the show .) Before the reviews, the revival was grossing roughly $850,000 a week on average; since then the average has fallen by about $90,000.

CLEARWATER, Fla. — Derek Jeter described his mood as more frustrated than concerned, although the Yankees may feel otherwise. He complained Tuesday about more than the normal stiffness in his surgically repaired left ankle and was scratched from the starting lineup against the Philadelphia Phillies.
 
Jeter fractured the ankle on Oct. 13 in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series and had surgery a week later . The club has brought him along slowly this spring, playing him in only five games — two as the designated hitter and three in the field. He played consecutive games at shortstop for the first time Friday and Saturday, but had not played in a game since.

An article on Saturday about protests over the University of Tennessee’s proposal to lease land managed by the university for gas drilling quoted incorrectly from comments by Mark Emkes, the head of Tennessee’s Department of Finance and Administration who supported the university’s position.  At a hearing on Friday, he said, “I can assure you there is a lot more demands for money than there is supply,” comparing it to difficult decisions made to balance the state budget. He did not say, “There is a lot of demand for this supply,” and he was not referring to demands for natural gas.

McDONALD--James T. New York has lost one of the greatest New York Police Detectives and a great leader of security for Merrill-Lynch and HBO. He was courageous, dedicated, smart, and accomplished many things quietly for the New York Police Department, Merrill-Lynch and HBO. His personal life was exemplary and he is a hero to all of our team and myself. Ira A. Lipman, Chairman Guardsmark, LLC

A federal judge has set a May 28 trial date for the director Julie Taymor, Bono and the Edge of U2, and the producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” to battle in court over a lawsuit stemming from the spectacular implosion of their years-long collaboration on the show.
 
Judge Katherine B. Forrest of Federal District Court in Manhattan ordered on Friday that the parties may conduct discovery through May 1 and that “trial is and will be on May 28, 2013,” adding that no further meetings with the judge were necessary. The order came four days after the judge, during a closed-door session with the various sides, expressed frustration that they had not been able to settle disputes over copyright control and profits from the show in spite of coming to terms in principle in August.

An article on Friday about an Urban Institute study that found Americans up to the age of 40 had accumulated less wealth than their parents had at the same age misattributed a quotation. It was Caroline Ratcliffe, an author of the study — not Signe-Mary McKernan, also an author — who said: “In this country, the expectation is that every generation does better than the previous generation. This is no longer the case. This generation might have less.”

LANDES--Wendy Rosen. Our hearts are broken by the untimely death of our beloved daughter Wendy. Throughout her lifetime she made us so proud, graduating magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and the Benjamin Cardozo School of Law where she was made a Belkin Scholar. She went on to be an Assistant Westchester District Attorney and then a family law attorney dedicated to divorce with dignity to better the interests of the families of her clients in Los Angeles. She was such a loving wife and mother to her beloved husband Robert and her children Matthew, Alexandra and Jacqueline who together with Wendy helped her valiantly fight her dreadful cancer, Liposarcoma. They created the "Wendy Walk", an annual tri-state event to raise funds for research. To our daughter Phyllis and her husband Rick and to our son Michael and his wife Stephanie and their children and to all those people who fought by her side, we weep together. May she now rest in peace and may Wendy's name always be for a blessing! Rita and Philip Rosen

An article in some editions on March 12 about a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan who stopped the ban on large sugary drinks from taking effect misstated the action that the justice, Milton A. Tingling, took in another case. In that suit — a challenge to limits imposed on art vendors in city parks — Justice Tingling extended a temporary ban on the rules in August 2010; he did not issue a temporary ban. The article also misstated the year that the rules went back into effect. It was in 2011, not later in 2010. And the article misstated the current status of the challenge to those rules. The case is proceeding in Justice Tingling’s court; it is not on hold pending the outcome of a challenge in federal court.

GOULD--Blanche Marko, died peacefully at home in Congers, NY, on March 19 at the age of 99. Wife of the late William; beloved mother of Bruce and Jean, Warren and Laura, Wendy and Walter; grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of eleven. Sister of Ethel Marko Stern. "A woman of valor, who can find? She is far more precious than jewels." Interment private.

SPIRO--Arthur M. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL) Board of Trustees, faculty and administration mourn the passing of former trustee Arthur Spiro who served on the board from 1999-2006 and played an instrumental role in the expansion of the Lab's educational programs for students and teachers in grades 5-12. Arthur was chair of the DNA Learning Center (DNALC) Committee from 2001-2006 and facilitated the establishment of the DNALC West program in Lake Success with the North Shore LIJ Health System. Through his affiliation with Clemson University, Arthur and his wife Joan initiated the DNALC collaboration on the school's South Carolina campus. Our condolences to Joan, her daughters and grandchildren. Bruce Stillman, President and CEO Jamie C. Nicholls, Board Chairman James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus W. Dillaway Ayres, COO

Since 1995, when Tom Izzo became head coach at Michigan State, every incoming class has made at least one trip to the Final Four before graduating. Izzo has a 7.25 winning percentage (37-14) in the N.C.A.A. Tournament with one national championship (in 2000).

GURFEIN--Stuart "Jim", Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and loyal friend to many passed away at age 65 on March 17th surrounded by immediate family. Born in Scarsdale, NY, Jim graduated from Cornell University where he received a football scholarship. He continued his education with an MBA from Columbia Business School and went on to have a successful and diverse career as an advertising and diamond industry executive before pursuing more entrepreneurial endeavors, creating web based development companies RestaurantRow. com and Mediaspa. Beyond his professional accomplishments, he was an avid golfer, valiant, generous, charitable and fiercely determined. Jim's greatest passion was his family: his wife Kathy, of almost 32 years, whom he married after only knowing for six weeks; his children Scott, Heather and Kody; daughter-in-law, Alison; granddaughter Skye; sister Ronny; and guardian cats, Redford and Brando. Jim will be deeply missed and in our hearts forever. A memorial service is planned for Thursday, March 21st, at 1:00pm at Rye Golf Club, 330 Boston Post Road in Rye, NY.

SCHECTER--Karen, 59, of Stuart, FL passed away peacefully February 28, 2013 after a long battle with cancer. Born in Baltimore, MD she moved to Stuart from New York City. Besides a successful and fulfilling career in executive search consulting, Mrs. Schecter was very active in several philanthropic efforts, including the Juvenile Diabetes Research and the Alliance for Lupus Research. Her friends and family will remember her as a strong, compassionate, vibrant woman with a capacity to draw people to her and make them feel like the most important person in the room. Mrs. Schecter is survived by her two children, Thomas and Kathryn, her siblings, Debra, Jamie, and Brian; her father, Sam, her companion Bill Saltzman, and many close friends who will miss her terribly. A Memorial Celebration will be held on Friday, March 22, at The Princeton Club at 4PM.
An article on Tuesday about efforts to revive extinct species misstated the number of years ago that a now-extinct horse lived in the Yukon. It was 70,000 years ago, not 7,000.

FORTGANG--Ruth. Beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Wife of Oskar Fortgang, of blessed memory. Sister of Manfred Brust, of blessed memory. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her.

Richard D. Lyons, who covered science, Congress and the United Nations during almost 30 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died on Wednesday at his home in Charleston, S.C. He was 84. 
 
The cause was complications of vascular dementia, his wife, Susan, said.

Erwin Harris left behind a respectable record of achievement as an advertising executive, an estimable collection of Chinese antiquities (his lifelong hobby), a loving family and a remarkable if little-remembered role in the tortured history of diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba in the early 1960s. 
 
Mr. Harris, a Yonkers-born World War II veteran who died in Miami on March 9 at 91, probably did not tip the scales of history. But from 1960 to 1961, armed with nothing more than a court order from a Florida judge and accompanied by local sheriff’s deputies, he scoured the East Coast confiscating Cuban government property — including the state airplane Fidel Castro parked in New York while on a visit.

New York City Opera announced on Tuesday that its 2013-2014 season would feature the American premiere of two operas, “Anna Nicole,” by Mark-Anthony Turnage, based on the paparazzi-filled life and death of Anna Nicole Smith, and  “Endimione,” a little-known and rarely staged work composed by Johann Christian Bach in 1772.
 
The coming season, like the current one, consists of just four productions as the company, which left Lincoln Center after the 2010-11 season, continues a scaled-down, nomadic existence.

LANDES--Wendy. We are heart broken by the loss of our beautiful cousin. She fought her disease with grace and dignity. Her spirit will live on in all of us and she will always be loved. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Landes and Rosen families. Much love, Cheryl, Bill, Ian and David
WALSEY--Milton. I will never forget you and the wonderful 20 years we shared with each other. Doris Juster
GREENBERG--Adele Zelda (1929 - 2013). Memorial service Upper West Side of Manhattan on Saturday, March 23 at 1:30pm. For more info email Michele: mdg1929@gmail.com.
A sperm donor, played by Patrick Huard, gets in touch with his paternal side years later in “Starbuck,” directed by Ken Scott.
In “Hunky Dory,” a drama teacher persuades her pupils to stage a rock opera based on “The Tempest.”
“The Sapphires” chronicles a female quartet of Aboriginal singers on the way to stardom in the 1960s and the obstacles they face.
“The Croods” is an animated comedy about a Stone Age family, starring the voice of Emma Stone.
In the “Die Hard” tradition, the lead character in “Olympus Has Fallen” is a world-weary professional battling evil amid pyrotechnics.
Two Bronx graffiti artists go on a daylong quest to finance an ambitious project: the tagging of a big plastic apple at Citi Field.

Acrostic puzzle for March 24, 2013

With the top of the Billboard album chart this week looking like a bit of a flashback to 1986, Bon Jovi is No. 1 and David Bowie has landed at No. 2 with his first new album in a decade.
 
Bon Jovi’s “What About Now” (Island) sold 101,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, the band’s third in a row to reach No. 1. Mr. Bowie’s new album, “The Next Day” (Columbia), sold 85,000 copies, sending him higher than he has ever been on the American chart. (The closest he came before was in 1976, when “Station to Station” went to No. 3.)

LONDON — “David Bowie Is,” a major retrospective of the British singer’s career and cultural influence , which opens at the Victoria and Albert Museum on Saturday , has sold over 42,000 advance tickets, more than double the amount generated by any previous exhibition at the museum. 
 
The exhibition, which displays more than 60 costumes worn by Bowie in performances, as well as photographs, documents, song lyrics, album sleeve artworks, music videos and stage sets, has generated considerable buzz, with rave advance reviews from the British papers. Interest has no doubt been further augmented by the singer’s surprise release last week of a new album, “The Next Day,” which almost immediately went to No. 1 one on the British charts, selling 94,000 copies in less than a week.

TARZIAN--Harry. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend, passed away at age 83 on March 16th surrounded by loved ones. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Harry graduated from Manhattan College in 1951, served in the U.S. Army from 1951-1954, was the life-long proprietor of Park Slope's 92 year-old Tarzian Hardware, as well as an acclaimed photographer and accomplished sailor. A celebration of Harry's life is being planned for later this summer. Please visit www.harrytarzian.com for more information soon. Memorial donations may be made in Harry's name to Homes of Hope India-US. http://www.homeofhopeindia.org/donate/

The About New York column on Friday, about a death row case in Alabama that caught the attention of Robert M. Morgenthau, who spent 35 years as the Manhattan district attorney, misspelled part of the name of the firm where he now works. It is Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz (not Wachtel).

An article on Wednesday about the reaction of some Palestinians in the West Bank to President Obama’s scheduled visit misspelled the given name of the president of the board of the Al Bireh Youth Foundation, where several teenagers participated in a computer program and are to meet with Mr. Obama to discuss it. He is Samih Al-Abid, not Samiha.

An obituary on Wednesday about Murrey Marder, who reported extensively on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for The Washington Post, misstated the year the Senate censured McCarthy. It was in December 1954, not in 1955.

FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank on Wednesday revised its 2012 profit sharply downward as it set aside more money to cover the potential cost of legal proceedings.

Jens Grede and Erik Torstensson, editors of Industrie magazine and founders of the creative agency Saturday Group — it came up with the concept for Mr Porter — can now add denim designers to their C.V. Early this year, they quietly introduced a limited run of jeans called Frame Denim on Net-a-Porter; the jeans blew off the site in just two weeks. For spring, Frame Denim is no longer under the radar but a full-fledged line. Mr. Grede explains that its first style, Le Skinny de Jeanne, derives its name from “Frenglish — us being cheeky with the French, since it sounds like skinny jean.” The midrise, ankle-hitting skinny gives a girl a good backside and has become a favorite of the likes of Cara Delevingne (above left), Miranda Kerr (above right) and Anja Rubik. Trust a model to have her pick of the denim litter. The jeans are available in a nice array of blue washes, light and dark. 
 
Frame Denim Le Skinny de Jeanne, $180 to $196 at Barneys New York; barneys.com .

GONZALEZ-GANDOLFI--Mrs. Maria Leonor (Neneka), 95 years old, died on Saturday, March 16 in Somerset, NJ accompanied by her family. She was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina and lived in Colombia and Indonesia before coming to the United States in 1965. Along with her family, she lived many years in Rye Brook, NY before moving to Princeton, NJ in 1998. Upon the death of her husband, Alberto, she moved to Somerset, NJ in 2005 to be closer to her children. Although she left Argentina many years ago, her heart and soul remained in her native country. She kept abreast of the political and social issues of the day especially women's rights and education. Mrs. Gonzalez Gandolfi was predeceased by her husband of 58 years, Mr. Alberto Gonzalez Gandolfi, former Chief of Building and Planning for the United Nations, as well as her daughter Gloria Gonzalez Gandolfi Sardou and grandson Sebastian Salcedo. She is survived by her children Luz Maria Gonzalez Salcedo and her husband Estanislao, Diana Gonzalez Gandolfi and her husband Daniel Wolfson, Marcos Gonzalez Gandolfi and Pablo Gonzalez Gandolfi and his wife Ping Xiao Gonzalez as well as her six grandchildren. She is also survived by her sister Sara Gonzalez Llanos of Buenos Aires. Visitation on Friday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Gleason Funeral Home 1360 Hamilton Street, Somerset, NJ. Memorial Mass on Saturday at 9am at St. Matthias Church, 165 John F. Kennedy Blvd., Somerset, NJ. Contributions may be made to Resource Center of Somerset at 427 Homestead Road, Hillsborough, NJ 08844.

TAMPA, Fla. — It’s Derek Jeter, so people automatically assume he will exceed normal standards. But it is possible that not even Jeter will be able to make the Yankees’ opening day lineup less than sixth months after fracturing his left ankle and needing surgery to repair it.
 
After complaining of stiffness Tuesday, and being scratched from the lineup against Philadelphia , Jeter received a cortisone shot Wednesday morning and was not expected to resume baseball activities for two or three days.

With a film and TV movie about Alfred Hitchcock and even a new TV series based on his work, fans of the director have had a lot to check out recently. Now add nine more films, black-and-white silents that constitute his earliest-surviving work, which will be shown together on an American tour later this year. 
 
Made between 1925 and 1929, the movies, recently restored by the British Film Institute, include “The Pleasure Garden,” Hitchcock’s first film, about chorus girls in London. Even that movie displayed telltale signs of Hitchcock’s touch. “Already you have the obsession with blondes seen in ‘The Birds’ and ‘North by Northwest,’ the voyeurism of ‘Psycho’ and ‘Rear Window,’ even the theater setting he used again and again in his films,” Kieron Webb of the institute told the BBC last year.

Considering its purpose – a bag that coverts to a standing desk for the iPad – shouldn’t the Strotter Platforma look much, much nerdier?
 
The Platforma is an all-purpose black leather carrying case nearly 12 by 9 by 3 inches, about the size of a big city phone book. The company said the leather is treated for water resistance so the dye won’t transfer to clothing.

On a recent Saturday, Sandy Yu, protected by a red parka, was one of the few sidewalk vendors who showed up along a normally jammed Fifth Avenue commercial strip in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. 
 
“Battery change — how much?” asked a young woman, holding out her watch. “Five dollar,” said Ms. Yu, putting down her thermos.

MOSCOW — Grigory Chkhartishvili, the best-selling Russian writer known for his detective novels set in imperial Russia (written under the name Boris Akunin), and for his foray into opposition politics directed against Vladimir V. Putin announced that from now on he would devote himself to writing a multivolume history of Russia.
 
“Some writers dream of becoming the new Tolstoy, others the new Chekhov,” he wrote on his blog on Wednesday. “It’s come time to acknowledge that I have always dreamt of becoming the new Karamzin,” he said, referring to Nikolai Karamzin, who wrote an early-19th-century 12-volume “History of the Russian State.” “I am no longer a crime novelist,” he declared.

SALT LAKE CITY — Before New Mexico began its N.C.A.A. tournament practice Wednesday, in preparation for its West Region game against Harvard, Coach Steve Alford got a raise. Some job security as well.
 
The university announced a new 10-year contract that would bring Alford up around $2 million each season when base salary, incentives and bonuses were added up. Alford led the Lobos to 29 wins this season, second most in team history, good for their third N.C.A.A. appearance in the past four seasons.
KASE--Judith Glass, March 20, 2013. Loved and loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister, daughter, aunt, teacher, mentor and friend.

Maybe Instagram’s privacy blunder took the bloom off the rose, but that’s no reason to stop sharing photos through social media as Instagram alternatives continue to emerge.
 
Take Tadaa , an app with some serious photo editing features that can also share your images through your social networks or keep them privately on your phone.

Which cellular carrier’s LTE data service is the fastest?
 
Since LTE is a technical standard, you might expect them all to be pretty equal. But to paraphrase George Orwell, some LTE networks are more equal than others. And all of those fancy features on your smartphone are meaningless if they are on a balky network.

CAIRO — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority is so eager to return to peace talks with the Israelis that he may soften his demand that Israel’s president publicly pledge to halt construction of new settlements on Palestinian land before such negotiations can resume.
 
The shift in the Palestinian leader’s stance was laid out in a draft set of talking points prepared for Mr. Abbas by his negotiating team in advance of his private meeting on Thursday with President Obama .

The French technology company Parrot is known primarily for its hands-free systems for cars, but it has added to its lineup a pair of wireless headphones that blend design and comfort with some very clever features.
 
Designed by Philippe Starck, the $400 Parrot Zik is a luxurious combination of sleek chrome and soft, synthetic leather. But the design is not only visually appealing, it’s also smart.

An article on Wednesday about a strike by the San Francisco Symphony, resulting in the cancellation of an East Coast tour this week, misstated the size of the orchestra’s budget for the 2011-12 fiscal year. It was $79.2 million — not $70 million, which is the budget for the current fiscal year.

The Breton shirts once favored by French seamen and Picasso become so ubiquitous come spring that, sad to say, they’ve lost a bit of allure. They are a tried-and-true wardrobe staple, no question, but as the weather heats up, blue and white stripes multiply in ways that are not always so chic. But designers have stepped up, with tweaks on the classic. Stripes with jagged and broken lines, or painted on, add interest and, like the Céline top with broken stripes on the young woman here, will set you apart from the pack. Yet they still go with everything. Win-win.

Carnegie Hall has received a $10 million challenge grant from its chairman, Sanford I. Weill, and his wife, Joan, and their Weill Family Foundation toward the completion of its $230 million renovation . The project, known as the Studio Towers Renovation, will create new spaces for music education on the landmark building’s upper floors and upgrade the concert hall’s backstage areas. It is scheduled to be completed in 2014.
 
“It will really transform Carnegie Hall,” Mr. Weill said in a telephone interview. “It’s much more effective to run an organization where everything you’re doing is in one place.”

LIBOR REPERCUSSIONS The fallout from the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate , or Libor, has already cost banks $2.5 billion in penalties. 
 
But that sum pales in comparison with payouts that will come from private lawsuits, according to White Collar Watch. The latest salvo comes from Freddie Mac, which filed a lawsuit asserting that it was harmed by rate-rigging. PETER J. HENNING

An article on Saturday about turmoil at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco misidentified the organization for which Nancy Ewart, whose criticism of an exhibition at one museum was quoted in the article, writes. It is Examiner.com, not The San Francisco Chronicle.

In 2004, he received a MacArthur “genius” grant. Mr. Hemon’s new book, “The Book of My Lives,” collects nonfiction pieces about his upbringing in Sarajevo and his life in America. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hemon discussed displacement, visiting Sarajevo now, the purpose of art and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

“I don’t care if a guy played for the Steelers,” he said. “I don’t care if he played for the Browns or the Ravens. Once he becomes a Bengal, I root for him. You want success for your team.”

With all of the transparent bags on the street, the fashionable set clearly has little to hide. McCORMACK--Sandra Danenberg, Died at home on March 20, 2013, after more than eighteen years of living with - and dying with - Alzheimer's Disease. She attended the Birch Wathen School in Manhattan, and then went on to Sarah Lawrence College, graduating in 1957. She worked for a time in an art gallery, and then for a longer interval as an interior decorator. But her truest professional calling was as a senior editor at the book publisher, St. Martin's Press. She earned the reputation on both sides of the Atlantic of being a fiction-reader of unexcelled responsiveness and reliability. The only book ever written about the writing and editing of novels is dedicated to her with the line: "To Sandra - The Best Sensibility." Sandra was born in New York City the 20th of September, 1935, to Louis and Natalie Danenberg. All with continuing deep love for her, Sandra's survivors include her husband Tom; her son Daniel; her daughter Jessie; her sister Jacqueline Rado; her brother-in-law Peter Rado,; her niece Ferne Traeger; her nephew Michael Traeger and her grandniece Claudia Batkin. Sandra was predeceased by her son Jed McCormack who died at 22 months of age in 1972. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street in New York City on Sunday at 11:45am with interment at the Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

A headline on March 10 about Harvard’s secretly searching the e-mail accounts of its staff members, looking for the source of news media leaks about its recent cheating scandal, described the university’s action incorrectly. Administrators had access to the accounts because they were part of Harvard’s e-mail system; it is not the case that Harvard “hacked,” or gained illicit access, to the e-mails.

CBS announced Wednesday that it has renewed the biggest television hit of the past decade, “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation,” for a 14th season.
 
The network said it had extended the contract of the show’s star Ted Danson and secured most of the cast, including Elisabeth Shue, for another season of episodes.

Chris Kreider, the Rangers’ rookie forward, will get a third try at sticking with the team this season after being recalled from the American Hockey League Wednesday. Kreider scored six goals in eight games for Connecticut, the Rangers’ A.H.L. affiliate, since his latest demotion on Feb. 28.
 
To make room for Kreider, the Rangers returned winger Micheal Haley to Connecticut.

NEWARK – Goalie Martin Brodeur, whose monthlong absence triggered a tumble in the standings that has the Devils in danger of missing the playoffs, is expected to rejoin the lineup for Thursday night’s game at the Carolina Hurricanes.
 
Brodeur, 40, had been slowed by a pinched nerve in his back. He was activated Wednesday and said he was ready to make what would be his first start since Feb. 21. “It’s a week and a half or two weeks since I’ve been on the ice,” he said. “All of the symptoms have gone away. I’m ready to go.”

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — David Wright of the Mets was prescribed five days of rest and treatment Friday when he was diagnosed with a strained intercostal muscle in his left rib cage. Five days have passed, and Wright still cannot do much more than rest and receive treatment.
 
“It’s getting better,” Wright said Wednesday morning. “It’s just doing what the doctor said and getting treatment and resting.”

An article on Tuesday about online professional certificate programs, using information from a professor at Northwestern University, misstated the number of post-baccalaureate online courses offered by the university. It is 70, not 300. (About 300 sections of those 70 courses are offered.)

Joining a pantheon that includes Philip Roth, E.L. Doctorow and John Updike, Benjamin Alire Sáenz has won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for his short story collection, “Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club,” The Associated Press reported .
 
The author will receive $15,000 for “Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club,” published by Cincos Puntos Press of El Paso, the PEN/Faulkner Foundation announced on Tuesday.

The performers of DanceBrazil, as seen this week at the Joyce Theater, exist in a ravishing, hard-working paradise. They’re barefoot; their attire (T-shirts, loose trousers, light dresses or skirts) has no hint of luxury. What matters here above all is the gorgeously full physicality of movement, allied to music. While spines continually plunge beneath the level of the waist, legs kick explosively above it or maintain powerful extensions like searchlights. 
 
Their world looks idyllic because the eight men and two women appear deeply sensuous yet show little hint of eroticism. The two sexes share the stage without tension. At one point in the second half of the program seven men, crouching, gaze at two women who’ve just entered. The situation is provocative, charged by flirtatious potential. When the women leave, the men erupt in a happy frenzy — and yet it’s as if the women are no longer on their minds.

GARDNER--Allan D.,on March 19, at age 74. Devoted husband of Janet, with whom he built a beautiful family and full life during their 44 years together before her passing. Cherished father of Andrew, who died too soon but much loved, and Elisabeth, who will most miss her father's wisdom and unflagging optimism. In a long advertising career, Allan lent his talents to several agencies and a few political campaigns, including Robert Kennedy's presidential run. He was an accomplished photographer and his encyclopedic knowledge of history, Sondheim lyrics, film and current events kept conversations lively. His loyal friends spanned a lifetime. His grandchildren; Robbie, Annabel, Charlotte, Kyle, Jake and Juliet, will carry with them his lessons and love, as will son-in-law Jeffrey Ostrow, daughter-in-law Kimberley Gardner, and brother and sister-in-law, Richard and Alice Gochman. Memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributing to the Gordon Murray Initiative for Brain Cancer Research at UCSF.

SAN JOSE, Calif. — Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim played down the latest reports about investigations into his basketball program, suggesting that there was nothing new to revelations on Wednesday, the day before the Orange’s N.C.A.A. tournament opener against Montana.
 
“Same story they had last year at this time,” Boeheim said during a news conference. “I guess that’s annual. I guess next year we’ll get it again.”

One of the hottest Off Broadway tickets, the Vanessa Redgrave-Jesse Eisenberg play, “The Revisionist,” is adding an extra week of performances before its new closing date of April 27, Rattlestick Playwrights Theater announced on Wednesday. The theater’s leaders have also begun exploring transferring the production to Broadway during the 2013-14 season.
 
“The Revisionist,” written by Mr. Eisenberg (an Oscar nominee for “The Social Network”) and directed by Kip Fagan, is already on track to be the biggest moneymaker in the 17-year history of the Rattlestick company, according to its artistic director, David Van Asselt. In an interview he said that it was too soon to estimate total ticket sales for the 10-week run, but added that when the mostly positive reviews of “The Revisionist” were published on Feb. 28 the production sold $200,000 in tickets that day – a sizable number of those then available. Within two days the rest of the tickets were sold out.

The iTunes Store has millions of songs, videos and other digital goods that make it easy to run up the credit-card bill. If you find items you want to buy — but need to pace your spending — you can use the Wish List feature to set them aside for purchasing later. To use the Wish List when you are logged in and browsing the iTunes Store, click the triangle next to the price listed for a song, album, video, book or other content for sale, and choose “Add to Wish List” from the menu that appears. 
 
To see the items you’ve previously added to your Wish List, go to the iTunes Store home page by clicking the little house icon at the top of the Store window. On the left side of the iTunes Store home page, click the “My Wish List” link. The wish list page displays all your saved items. The top of the page also lists the total number of items on the wish list and a button to buy everything on the list with one click — which can be useful for those with slow Internet connections who want save their bandwidth for browsing and download all purchases at the end of the shopping session.

An article on Wednesday about the rejection of a bank bailout plan in Cyprus misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the Cypriot president in some references. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, he is Nicos Anastasiades, not Anastasiadis.

BRENMAN de TOLCHINSKY--Esther. Today marks "shloshim" since Esther Brenman de Tolchinsky's passing. Wife of Guillermo; mother of Liliana, Silvia, Daniel and Gabriel. Born 1920 in Alexandria, Egypt, Esther lived in Argentina, Israel and Barcelona. She lost a son, son-in-law, daughter-in-law and niece to the terror of the military junta that ruled Argentina 1976-1982. Esther was a beautiful, dignified and intelligent woman. Her surviving children, 11 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren remember her with love.

An article on Tuesday about the slow process of making many Hollywood movies included an outdated title for Bill Damaschke of DreamWorks, who commented on the time — more than nine years — it took to make “The Croods.” He is now chief creative officer, not co-president for production.

An article on Tuesday about the discovery of Medieval remains quoted incorrectly from a description by archaeologists of a sandstone slab found alongside the remains of a knight who lived during the 13th century in Edinburgh. They noted that the carvings on the slab were of the Calvary Cross, not the Cavalry Cross.

PEARSON--George E.,age 95, of West Cornwall, CT, formerly of North Massapequa, NY died peacefully on March 18, 2013. George led a long and wonderful life, surrounded with love by his family; wife Esther of 56 years (who predeceased him in 2002); his children George, Don (Ann), John (who predeceased him in 1952), Mary and his two grandchildren Joe and Laura Pearson. George worked from 17 until his retirement at 65 at Turtle & Hughes, an electrical distributor, where one of his favorite projects was supplying the lights for the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree. Starting as a mailroom clerk and progressing to Vice President, he worked tirelessly. If a client wanted something that wasn't available, he would make it himself in his basement workshop. His love of life, nature, creating and learning was an inspiration to those who knew him. He left his mark on so many. Gone, but he will live on in so many hearts. Reposing Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave., Westbury, NY on Friday 2-4pm and 7-9 PM. Memorial Service Saturday 9:30am at Funeral Home Chapel. Interment to follow with Military Honors in St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. www.donohue-cecere.com

Whatever Simon & Garfunkel meant by “Sounds of Silence,” those sounds will now reverberate in perpetuity — whether silently or otherwise — along with works by Van Cliburn, Pink Floyd, the Ramones and many other artists whose musical creations will be added to the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress .
 
The library is to announce on Thursday that it has added to its audio registry 25 new recordings, which were selected for preservation because of “their cultural, artistic and historic importance to the nation’s aural legacy,” according to a news release.

David Ranta walked out of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Thursday a free man, after spending more than two decades in a maximum-security prison for a crime he almost certainly did not commit.
 
Mr. Ranta, who was convicted in 1991 of one of New York City’s most notorious murders, only to spend years fighting to prove his innocence, was escorted by guards into a courtroom. His hands were bound in handcuffs, linked by a chain to a brown leather belt around his waist.

GARY--Howard C.,on March 21, in his 93rd year. Loving husband of Rhoni; father of Barbara (Fred Bass), Carol (Steve Tatti) and David (Terry Weiss); grandfather of Nicholas, Zachary, Francesca, Corey and JJ. He was an inspiration to generations and to the legion of those who loved him.

TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter’s availability for the Yankees’ season opener on April 1 is still a question mark. But General Manager Brian Cashman said with an exclamation point Thursday that Jeter would not see any more action in major league spring training games.
 
Any playing time that Jeter might see between now and opening day will be in minor league games. Cashman explained that should the Yankees need to place their 38-year-old shortstop on the 15-day disabled list, they can backdate the move to March 22, thus minimizing any regular-season games Jeter might miss.

Jon Niese will start the Mets’ season opener against the San Diego Padres on April 1. The role was handed to Johan Santana at the start of camp, but Santana has not pitched a single game during spring training because of shoulder fatigue.
 
“We feel very, very confident that he’s the right guy to start this off,” Manager Terry Collins said of Niese.

KASE--Judith Glass, March 20, 2013. Loved and loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister, daughter, aunt, teacher, mentor and friend.

LAZARUS--Richard Cecil, born April 8, 1920 in Brooklyn, NY and died March 10, 2013 in Cambridge, MA. Son of Arthur Lazarus and Frieda Langer Lazarus who accompanied Albert Einstein as delegates to the World Disarmament Conference in Geneva, 1932. A conscientious objector during World War II, life-long pacifist and peace activist, volunteer at SERVAS peace organization for international travelers, volunteer at Suicide Prevention Hotline, Planned Parenthood defender of abortion clinics, supported civil rights movement and integration, was early promoter of Prospect Heights and founder of Prospect Heights Neighborhood Association. Also a self-taught naturalist and conservationist. Graduate of Columbia College, was New York State civil service worker. Survived by Katherine Buchanan Lazarus, wife of 65 years; predeceased by son Richard Daniel. Other survivors in his loving family are son Douglas (Nattipat), daughters Maya (Roberto) and Donna; grandchildren Aurora, Diana, Diallo and Mint; and three great-grandchildren, Chyna, Joseph and Daryllyn. Survivors also include his brother Arthur Lazarus, Jr. and sister Margie Meyerson. Memorial to be announced. Submitted by Donna Lazarus, 24 Ft. Greene Place, Brooklyn, NY 11217.

AITKEN--Robert P. In loving memory of our Dad (3-21-13 to 9-12-81), who married our Mom, Marjorie Jackson Aitken (12-1-19 to 10-23-04), in 1942. He is survived by his three sons, Robert (Middletown, NY), Bruce (Houston, Tex.),; and Gerald (Maybrook, NY); and four grandchildren: Heather (Venice, Cal), Miles (Wash., DC), Jackie (Wash., D.C.) and Sean-Paul (San Juan, PR). For more info on his life and career, pls contact beaitken@aol.com.

Score one for private equity investors.
 
After suffering steep losses in one fund, the Yucaipa Companies, the money management firm run by the billionaire Ronald W. Burkle, has cut fees for investors in the portfolio. As part of the deal, Mr. Burkle agreed to forgo the firm’s annual management fee until the fund’s investors recoup their money, according to several people with knowledge of the matter. Such concessions reflect the broader pressure in the industry.

RIBATZKY (ROBBINS)--Isacc, died at home on March 21, 2013 after living life to the fullest for 73 years. Born in Jerusalem he came to the U.S. over 40 years ago to pursue his passion for interior design. His creative work is featured in many beautiful homes throughout the Tri-State area. New York City captured his love of aesthetics, music and the arts which is why he always called it home. He leaves behind his loving and devoted family and friends. Funeral will be held today, Friday, at Riverside Memorial Chapel in NYC at 1pm.

SHIPMAN--Elaine, died peacefully on Saturday, March 16. A dancer and choreographer, beautiful, brave, and generous spirit, she was surrounded in her last illness by many loving friends and colleagues. She continued with her life until the last possible moment, taking class at the Merce Cunningham Trust Studio, attending performances, spreading joy among all who knew her. Funeral services will be held at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker Street, New York City, at 10:30am on Sunday, March 24. A memorial will be held at Carl Seltzer's Studio, 185 East Broadway, at 2pm on Sunday, April 7. Further information, and post messages, at elaineshipman.tumblr.com.

Glen Sather, the Rangers’ president and general manager, had surgery to treat prostate cancer on Thursday at Weill-Cornell Medical Center in New York and was expected to be off the job for a few days.
 
With the April 3 trade deadline approaching, his duties are being handled by Jeff Gorton, the assistant general manager, who represented the club Wednesday at the N.H.L. general managers meeting in Toronto. The Rangers declined to issue any statements regarding Sather’s condition or the operation, which was first reported Wednesday by Newsday.

BIRNKRANT--Milton, 72. Died suddenly on March 19. Loving husband of Judy, adored father of Ted (Rebecca), Elizabeth and David. Doting grandfather of Michaela. He will be sorely missed by his brother, nieces, nephews, and many dear friends. Services 11:15am Friday, March 22 at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens would be appreciated.

A listing on Thursday of museum exhibitions misidentified the country that is home to the Albertina, the museum that has lent a collection of works by Albrecht Dürer to the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The museum is in Austria (in Vienna) — not in Germany.

SCHACTER--Herschel, American Jewish leader, rabbi, orator. Educated at Yeshiva Rabbi Chaim Berlin, Mesivta Torah Vodaath, and Yeshiva College. As a rabbinical student at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, he was the first rabbi to be ordained by Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik. While serving as chaplain in the VIII Corps of the Third Army of the United States Armed Forces, he participated in the liberation of the Buchenwald Concentration Camp and brought enormous comfort to many survivors. He led a UNRRA Kindertransport from Buchenwald to Switzerland after World War II. In 1956, he was a member of the first rabbinic delegation to the USSR and escorted a transport of Hungarian refugees from Austria to the United States. He served as rabbi of the Mosholu Jewish Center, Bronx, NY, for over 50 years, and as a distinguished leader of many American Jewish organizations. He was Chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, President of the Mizrachi-Hapoel Hamizrachi, Founding Chairman of the American Jewish Conference on Soviet Jewry, Chairman of the Chaplaincy Commission of the Jewish Welfare Board, and Director of Rabbinic Services at Yeshiva University. He is survived by his devoted and loving wife, Pnina G. Schacter; his children, Rabbi Jacob J. and Yocheved Schacter, Miriam Schacter and Dr. Benjamin R. Gampel; grandchildren, Dr. Leah and Rabbi Jonathan Knapp, Sarah and Corey Tarzik, Hannah Schacter-Gampel, and Abe Schacter-Gampel, and great grandchildren, Adina, Esti, Shira, Eli Knapp and Talia, Yonah, Aviva, Shaya Tarzik.

STEVENS--Rise. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of mezzo-soprano Rise Stevens, a consummate artist, treasured colleague, and devoted supporter of the company for 75 years. She sang 337 performances with the company, including 124 of her greatest role, the title character in Carmen. Critics and audiences praised her plush vocalism and riveting acting in the role, which she sang at the Met and on tour with the company between 1945 and 1961. She made her company debut on tour in Philadelphia in 1938 singing Octavian in Der Rosenkavalier, a peerless interpretation of a role she would perform 74 times, a company record. Later that year, she made an acclaimed house debut in the title role of Mignon. Among her cherished roles with the company were Dalila in Samson et Dalila, Cherubino in Le Nozze di Figaro, Orfeo in Orfeo ed Euridice, and Hansel in Hansel and Gretel. After her retirement from the stage, Stevens continued her work with the Met as a tireless advocate for both the company and for opera as an art form, serving as director of the Metropolitan Opera National Company and of the National Council Auditions, advisor to the Young Artist Development Program, and a managing director on the Met's board. We extend our sincerest condolences to her son and daughter-in-law, Nicolas and Marguerite Surovy; her granddaughter, Marisa; and her many friends and admirers. Ann Ziff, Chairman Kevin Kennedy, President Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association

SCHACTER--Rabbi Herschel. The Yeshiva University family is profoundly grieved by the passing of Rabbi Herschel Schacter, an outstanding alumnus of Yeshiva College and the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) who was the beloved husband of Pnina Schacter and cherished father of Rabbi Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, University Professor of Jewish History and Jewish Thought, and Senior Scholar at Yeshiva University's Center for the Jewish Future, (and Yocheved) Schacter, and Miriam (and Rabbi Benjamin) Schacter Gampel, and an adored grandfather and great grandfather. He served with distinction as the revered spiritual leader of the Mosholu Jewish Center in the Bronx, NY from 1947 until 1999 when the synagogue closed and established the Mosholu Jewish Center Rabbinic Fellowship at RIETS in his honor. Prior to joining the synagogue, Rabbi Herschel Schacter was a US Army Chaplain who participated in the liberation of Buchenwald Concentration Camp and played an important role in helping the resettlement of Displaced Persons after the Holocaust. He enjoyed national prominence as a brilliant and inspiring orator and was Chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish organizations and held many other significant leadership positions. His last professional role was as the Morris and Gertrude Bienenfeld Director of Rabbinic Services at the Community Service Division of RIETS. Beloved by congregants, Holocaust survivors and colleagues in the rabbinate, he will be sorely missed. May the entire Schacter family and all who loved him be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

STEVENS--Rise. The board and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and Opera News are profoundly saddened by the death of Rise Stevens Surovy. One of the greatest stars of the Metropolitan Opera, Rise served on the board of the Guild continuously since 1972, and for decades gave lovingly of her time, support and wisdom to all of our programs. She will be missed by opera lovers everywhere. Our deepest sympathies go to her son Nicolas, daughter-in-law Marguerite and granddaughter Marisa. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Richard J. Miller, Jr., President Stewart Pearce, Managing Director

Marie Ponsot , a poet known for her bold reimaginings of traditional forms, has been awarded the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, one of the most prestigious (and richest) in poetry, which comes with a $100,000 award.
 
Ms. Ponsot, 91, joins John Ashbery, W.S. Merwin, Lucille Clifton, Adrienne Rich and others on the list of winners of the prize, which was founded in 1986 to honor lifetime achievement. Her work includes the collections “Easy,” “Springing” and “The Bird Catcher” (winner of the 1998 National Book Critics Circle Award), as well as translations of more than 30 books from French.

SHERMAN--Alexander, long-time resident of Ossining, NY, died peacefully of heart failure on Saturday March 16 at the age of 87, surrounded by his close family. Alex is deeply missed by his wife of 62 years Ruth, son David, son-in-law Ed, brother Robert, nephews Steve and Peter and extended family. Born April 2, 1925 in New York City to pianist Nadia Reisenberg and financier Isaac Sherman, Alex was an electronics engineer with IBM until his retirement in 1987, and an avid folk dance teacher, square dance caller and recreation leader; along with Ruth, he was long affiliated with the Eastern Cooperative Recreation School and led dance and dramatic classes throughout Westchester. Alex had a long affiliation with Toastmasters, was a scuba diving enthusiast and was proud of his ping-pong game. Alex knew how to have fun. He was a warm, witty, gentle and happy man with a ready sense of humor and a twinkle in his eye. He enjoyed music and theater, and could often be found hiking in the woods or swimming in his favorite Stillwater Lake. Most of all, Alex loved his family, and together with Ruth, maintained a circle of devoted friends. He was a true inspiration to all who were fortunate enough to know him, and remains dearly loved by all. In memory of Alex, donations can be made to the National Kidney Foundation.
GITTLEMAN--Irwin. Missed greatly and remembered always. Kid sister Phyllis

Back in the 1970s, fans of Pink Floyd were known to gather in small groups around their stereos, often in darkened living rooms, imbibe their drug of choice and listen to “The Dark Side of the Moon” in its entirety.
 
How times have changed. As the album turns 40 on Sunday, the band has turned that stoner ritual into an online interactive activity. Starting after midnight in England (or 8:00 p.m. Saturday Eastern Time), fans are being invited to stream the album on PinkFloyd.com and to tweet their memories, photos and comments about the music with the hashtag #DarkSide40 . The Web site will monitor the tweets and slowly darken an image of the moon as they flood in, EMI Music announced on Wednesday.

Playwrights Horizons is once again putting women front and center in the company’s 2013-2014 season, staging four plays by women, including two world premieres. Three of the first five plays the Off Broadway company announced on Thursday will also be directed by women.
 
The season will begin with “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play,” a post-apocalyptic tale by Anne Washburn about a future in which the “Cape Feare” episode of the “The Simpsons” is all that remains of Western literature. The play was unveiled last year at Woolly Mammoth Theater Company in Washington, D.C., to good reviews. The New York production will have the same director, Steven Cosson, and previews will start Aug. 23.

ISAAC--Rabbi Dan, died at home on Wednesday (March 20). He is survived by his daughter Marina. A graveside service will be held Friday at 10:30 at Mt. Richmond Cemetery, 420 Clark Ave., Staten Island. Rabbi Isaac was ordained at Hebrew Union College (Cincinnati) and also holds a PhD in English Lit. (Chicago). Dan was a college professor, Rabbi, drama critic, playwright, and Cubs fan. Recently he edited the first publication of two Tennessee Williams plays, Spring Storm and Candles To The Sun. Dan travelled widely and thoroughly enjoyed his life as a scholar and a critic. Dan was a man of integrity who often took the road less traveled.

LAVIN--David E. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Professor David E. Lavin, a highly-respected sociologist at the CUNY Graduate Center and Lehman College. He was well known for his pioneering research on the sociology of education, social inequality and social psychology. His enduring devotion to CUNY students will be long remembered. He will be sorely missed. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson, CUNY Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

BACKTRACKING John W. Peace, below, the chairman of the British bank Standard Chartered, retracted statements on Thursday about the bank’s recent settlement with American authorities over violations of sanctions laws.
 
Last year, Standard Chartered agreed to a combined $667 million fine as part of a settlement with federal and state authorities, who claimed that Standard Chartered had illegally processed millions of dollars’ worth of transactions for Iranian and Sudanese clients. The bank admitted to “falsifying records” and “making false statements.”

GARDNER--Allan D.,on March 19, at age 74. Devoted husband of Janet, with whom he built a beautiful family and full life during their 44 years together before her passing. Cherished father of Andrew, who died too soon but much loved, and Elisabeth, who will most miss her father's wisdom and unflagging optimism. In a long advertising career, Allan lent his talents to several agencies and a few political campaigns, including Robert Kennedy's presidential run. He was an accomplished photographer and his encyclopedic knowledge of history, Sondheim lyrics, film and current events kept conversations lively. His loyal friends spanned a lifetime. His grandchildren; Robbie, Annabel, Charlotte, Kyle, Jake and Juliet, will carry with them his lessons and love, as will son-in-law Jeffrey Ostrow, daughter-in-law Kimberley Gardner, and brother and sister-in-law, Richard and Alice Gochman. Memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributing to the Gordon Murray Initiative for Brain Cancer Research at UCSF.

HURR--Doris, on March 20, 2013. Formerly of Bayside, NY. Loving mother to Cheryl Ivy, proud grandmother of Scott Bradley, previously married to the late Herbert. Funeral services private. For info www.jewish-funeral-home.com

QUINT--Barbara Gilder Born March 6, 1928; died after a brief illness March 20, 2013. Happily married to the late George Quint for 57 years. Loving mother of Andrew, Douglas, and Thomas; beloved mother-in-law of Marjie and Leslie; proud grandmother of Jillian, Kathryn, Mark, Jason, Theodore, and Daphne. Vassar College Class of 1947. She was among the first female brokers on Wall Street, at Dreyfus & Company, in the early 1950s. Former Finance/Money Editor of Glamour and Family Circle magazines; President of Barbara Quint Associates, a financial advising company. Funeral service at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains on Friday, March 22.

STEINHARDT--David. With great sorrow, the family of David Steinhardt announces his passing in Florida on Tuesday, March 19th. He was an adored son of Jane and Bob Steinhardt; father of Mara and Scott; brother of Debra and Judy; uncle of eight nieces and nephews; brother-in-law of Michael and Daniel, and friend to all. He was the kindest guy you've ever met. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, March 24, 2013, 10am at Woodlands Temple in White Plains, NY.

WASHINGTON — Albrecht Dürer had it all: the eye of a Raphael, the brains of a Leonardo, the looks of a cleaned-up Kurt Cobain. He produced the earliest known self-portrait drawing in European art when he was 13, and some of the first stand-alone landscapes. He brought the pliant warmth of Italian Classical painting to the shivery Gothic north, and transformed the woodcut medium from semi-folk art to fine art, and very fine art indeed.
 
Before he hit 30, he was the polymath star of what we now call the Northern European Renaissance. If he was personally vain — in his adult self-portraits he looks like Jesus — you can’t blame him.

McCORMACK--Sandra Danenberg, Died at home on March 20, 2013, after more than eighteen years of living with - and dying with - Alzheimer's Disease. She attended the Birch Wathen School in Manhattan, and then went on to Sarah Lawrence College, graduating in 1957. She worked for a time in an art gallery, and then for a longer interval as an interior decorator. But her truest professional calling was as a senior editor at the book publisher, St. Martin's Press. She earned the reputation on both sides of the Atlantic of being a fiction-reader of unexcelled responsiveness and reliability. The only book ever written about the writing and editing of novels is dedicated to her with the line: "To Sandra - The Best Sensibility." Sandra was born in New York City the 20th of September, 1935, to Louis and Natalie Danenberg. All with continuing deep love for her, Sandra's survivors include her husband Tom; her son Daniel; her daughter Jessie; her sister Jacqueline Rado; her brother-in-law Peter Rado,; her niece Ferne Traeger; her nephew Michael Traeger and her grandniece Claudia Batkin. Sandra was predeceased by her son Jed McCormack who died at 22 months of age in 1972. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street in New York City on Sunday at 11:45am with interment at the Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

ACHEBE--Chinua. Chinua Achebe was a brilliant novelist, story teller, and eloquent voice of opposition to the portrayal of Africa's relationship with the West by authors such as Joseph Conrad. He was also a gracious colleague to those of us fortunate enough to have known and worked with him and his family during their many years at Bard College, where he was Charles P. Stevenson Jr. Professor of Languages and Literature for nearly 20 years. He taught undergraduates in small classes, touching all of his students with his intellect and his warmth. His importance to literature and to those he taught and knew personally will never be forgotten. It was Bard's privilege that Chinua Achebe accepted our invitation to live and teach here. We send our deepest condolences to his family. He will be sorely missed. David E. Schwab II, Chair Emeritus Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chair Leon Botstein, President
